project_title: EJSG / ARP - Dwight, Healthy and Just Neighborhood
event_timeline:
- 2022-06-16: Grant awarded; Obligation of $74,965
- 2024-06-10: End date extended from 2024-06-30 to 2025-06-30
- 2025-03-28: End date cut off from 2025-06-30 to 2025-03-28
project_description: Description The purpose of this ARP funded grant agreement is to use American Rescue Plan ARP appropriations to partner with the Yale University Urban Design Workgroup to conduct a community engagement and planning process to address air quality and urban heat island issues impacting local residents The project conducted by the Greater Dwight Development Corporation based in New Haven CT will develop research on local environmental conditions in the neighborhood including air quality monitoring and develop a web based neighborhood planning document including a Geographic Information System GIS real time dashboard of air quality in the neighborhood for use by local residents This project will improve resident understanding of environment and public health issues improve air quality and green space from added trees plants and shade and expand socialization opportunities through activities with other residents families and neighbors This project supports the Clean Air Act CAA 103 b 3 People with moderate to severe or uncontrolled asthma are more likely to be hospitalized from COVID 19 Air pollution may contribute to asthma By addressing air pollution in CAA 103 b 3 projects the chances of severe illness from COVID 19 are reduced Activities The project has three components to research and document urban and nbsp environmental conditions in the neighborhood which impact resident health contributing to a nbsp comprehensive understanding of underlying environmental conditions including expanding a nbsp neighborhood scale air quality monitoring network to provide a new community owned dataset that nbsp will be used for ongoing and future planning efforts to engage and inform neighborhood nbsp residents in a planning process that creates learning for planners and community nbsp members through a series of open charrette style activities open houses walking tours a scavenger nbsp hunt and meetings focused on health and the urban environment including a nbsp youth education component to develop an actionable neighborhood plan with priorities that guides future activities to improve health and the environment Activities to be performed include conducting six planning sessions purchasing and installing seven air monitors collecting air quality data conducting research to develop an environmental history of the Greater Dwight neighborhood create a new website and post air quality data and analysis of the neighborhood study to the new website to educate local residents Outcomes Anticipated deliverables and expected outcomes of this project include 1 increased understanding and knowledge on ambient air quality issues to 20 community leaders and 250 community members 2 identifying determinants of a healthy neighborhood 3 providing a clear understanding of community priorities as they relate to improving public health and environment 4 raising awareness within neighborhood municipal and state governments about opportunities in Greater Dwight to improve air quality 5 identify how urban form and use impacts health empowering neighborhood advocacy and 6 identify future projects including tree canopy and improving both open space and pedestrian infrastructure Intended beneficiaries of this project include families and local residents living in the community neighborhood of Greater Dwight within New Haven Connecticut An involved and educated community is better equipped to participate in efforts to protect themselves and improve the quality of the environment Subrecipient A sub award to Yale University Urban Design Workshop to collect air monitoring data analyze trends and publish their study on a new website
gs_org: Ofc Of The Regional Administrator R1

program: Environmental Justice Government-to-Government (EJG2G) Program - Implementation Projects
project_title: Addressing Inequities through a Comprehensive CHW Home Visiting Model (AIM)
event_timeline:
- 2024-06-17: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,000,000
- 2024-08-06: Other amendment
- 2025-01-13: Other amendment

project_description: Description The agreement provides funding to the Massachusetts Department of Public Health Specifically the recipient will utilize these funds to support an asthma home visiting and asthma trigger remediation model that addresses the complex needs of vulnerable residents and communities The recipient will expand access to services that traditional funding mechanisms often exclude such as mold remediation carpet flooring replacement integrated pest management duct vent cleaning and more Additionally the project will include at least six stakeholder convenings and 3 4 community engagement sessions per year to educate stakeholders and to discuss community needs Activities During the course of this project the recipient and their subrecipients will conduct 3 4 community engagement sessions per year These community engagement sessions will be focused on providing the Massachusetts Department of Public Health and other relevant stakeholders with a greater understanding of community concerns and needs related to topics such as indoor air quality Additionally the the subrecipient of this award Revitalize Community Development Corporation will conduct 14 30 home asthma trigger remediation services such as mold remediation and pest control for each year of the project Lastly the recipient will host six total stakeholder convenings These convenings will provide an opportunity for key stakeholders to share information related to evidence based strategies for addressing asthma inequities Three of these convenings will be focused on the state of Massachusetts with the remaining three convenings focusing on Springfield Holyoke and Chicopee Outcomes The anticipated deliverables in this project include 14 30 home asthma trigger remediation services provided per year 6 stakeholder convenings hosted and 3 4 community engagement sessions hosted per year The deliverables are expected to increase knowledge of the environmental and behavioral triggers of asthma increase in the number of Clinical Health Workers with knowledge of asthma and lead increase in the lead and asthma awareness among local stakeholders increased community engagement regarding asthma and many more The intended beneficiaries of this project are the residents of the Springfield Chicopee and Holyoke Subrecipient Revitalize Community Development Corporation CDC will meaningfully engage community members by hosting 3 4 community engagement sessions The format of these sessions will include a mix of virtual and in person meetings and will be tailored for a variety of audiences including community residents clinicians community health workers and more Revitalize CDC will also provide 14 30 home asthma trigger remediation services per year This will involve conducting intake providing home assessment services maintaining relevant record and data elements and coordinating with tenants landlords and or homeowners on the scope of remediation Revitalize CDC will participate in Healthy Home Environment Meetings and Partner Convenings

project_description: Description The cooperative agreement provides funding to the Vermont Agency of Human Services to improve the health and well being of low income immigrants refugees and asylum seekers asylee households in Burlington and Winooski Vermont by creating a Community Ambassador led Healthy and Energy Efficient Homes Program The proposed activities will expand the Champlain Valley Office of Economic Opportunity rsquo s Community Ambassador program to include environmental  work The Healthy and Energy Efficient Homes Program will provide home assessments education repairs and improvements to support climate change resiliency and home environmental health improvement particularly for community members with poorly controlled asthma or other conditions affected by home environmental conditions The project includes engaging with residents and community organizations to learn more about environmental burdens through community forums and community based participatory research and evaluation This project will provide direct services training and education engaging local residents to identify and plan for long term environmental  action The goal of this project is to build a Community Ambassador Environmental  model for expansion into a statewide Community Inclusion Network designed to increase engagement and increase services for underserved residents Activities The activities include expanding Champlain Valley Office of Economic Opportunity rsquo s CVOEO Community Ambassador Program to include Environmental  programming and creating the Healthy and Energy Efficient Homes program The Community Ambassadors will receive training to improve awareness and understanding of environmental  challenges and opportunities Following the training CVOEO Community Ambassadors will conduct small group outreach through in home gatherings facilitate nine language specific gatherings which each will have four sessions with people from the same culture community coming together Along with CVOEO and the University of Vermont the recipient will develop a community based participatory research and evaluation approach and engage in the broader community through surveys and annual community forums The recipient will collect community input on healthy housing and energy efficiency needs to inform the launch of the Healthy and Energy Efficient Homes program This program will offer healthy housing and energy efficiency assessments to 100 homes and support repairs improvements and supplies to 50 of those homes Home assessments will include a professional walk through and interview with the occupants to identify potential environmental hazards and energy efficiency opportunities Repairs will be tailored to specific needs of each home and may include lab supplies testing maintenance carpet replacement cleaning supplies pest control appliance replacements and heating ventilation and or air conditioning upgrades The recipient will also establish the Community Ambassador Inclusion Network which will support immigrants refugees and Black Indigenous and other people of color community members and organizations to use in home gatherings and established social networks to increase learning engagement and share resources Outcomes The anticipated deliverables include training sessions research and evaluation plans home assessments and repairs community forums language specific gatherings development of a community network and reports on community takeaways The Champlain Valley Office of Economic Opportunity rsquo s CVOEO Community Ambassadors will receive 4 trainings on environmental  topics Each year the Community Ambassadors will conduct 2 community forums to learn more about housing related challenges They will facilitate 9 language specific in home gatherings annually which each consist of 4 sessions of at least 4 people of the same cultural community to discuss h

organization: The Rhode Island Department of Health

- 2024-06-25: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,000,000

project_description: Description The agreement provides funding to the Rhode Island Department of Health for the Rhode Island Asthma Control Program RIACP Specifically the recipient will monitor and improve indoor air quality by providing education outreach training and assistance including installing passive air quality sensors electric stoves and air purifiers in 50 single and multi family public housing residences The goal of which is to reduce exposure to nitrogen oxide NO2 semivolatile organic compounds SVOCs and particulate matter PM2 5 in residences experiencing a high burden of asthma and poor air quality RIACP will use the air quality monitoring data community input and a cost benefit analysis to develop a health impact assessment for housing authorities to address poor indoor air quality in their properties Activities The activities include developing a Quality Assurance Project Plan QAPP hiring a Healthy Housing Facilities Manager for Providence Housing Authority PHA creating a Health Impact Assessment HIA providing education outreach training and recruiting 50 PHA households to participate RICAP will install 50 air quality monitoring sensors in the participating households that will upload real time air quality data to regional air quality dashboard RICAP will replace 50 gas ranges with electric stoves and will install 50 air purifiers at the participating households RICAP will provide 3 Asthma Control Tests one to establish a baseline one to measure change after installation of electric stoves and the final one to measure change with installation of air purifiers RICAP will host community meetings to provide information share findings after each year of the project and to collect feedback RICAP will meet with RI Healthy Air Collaborative to disseminate information will present findings from the HIA to PHA and other housing authorities in the Core Cities of RI and will share final findings with the community PHA and other stakeholders Outcomes The anticipated deliverables include replacement of 50 gas ranges with electric stoves 50 air purifiers for participating households data briefings health impact assessment materials mailers on local air quality and additional data added to the regional air quality dashboard The expected outcomes include improved air quality for the 50 participating households mitigate the impact that poor air quality has on those with asthma reduce emergency department visits for children with asthma and increase awareness of asthma and air quality issues in the community The intended beneficiaries include 50 PHA households families burdened by asthma Health Equity Zones and Providence Housing Authority residents in Rhode Island Subrecipient Providence Housing Authority PHA will conduct outreach recruit project participants from PHA properties and will hire a Healthy Homes Facilities Manager to coordinate project implementation West Elmwood Health Equity Zone HEZ will assist in project planning community outreach and hosting community meetings to disseminate findings Central Providence HEZ will assist in project planning community outreach and hosting community meetings to disseminate findings South Providence HEZ will assist in project planning community outreach and hosting community meetings to disseminate findings Rhode Island Public Health Association will conduct a health impact assessment HIA and will host associated community meetings for input data assessment and disseminating information Yale School of Public Health will calibrate air quality sensors and manage the air quality database generated through the project Dr Goedel of Brown University will serve as the project evaluator supporting the program manager in evaluating the project rsquo s activities and outcomes The American Lung Association will expand the Rhode Island Healthy Air Collaborative through additional outreach to potential member

program: Environmental Justice Government-to-Government (EJG2G) Program - Implementation Projects
project_title: Prairie Island G2G Tribal Home Energy Project
event_timeline:
- 2024-05-30: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,000,000
- 2024-10-16: Other amendment
- 2025-05-01: End date cut off from 2027-03-31 to 2025-05-01
project_description: Description This agreement provides funding under Consolidated Appropriations The agreement provides funding to Prairie Island Indian Community Specifically the recipient will utilize contractors to perform on reservation and trust land Tribal member owned home energy audits with subsequent installation and or renovation of those homes based on conclusions and recommendations from the audits These upgrades renovations and or installations will assist households to be more energy effective and efficient thus reducing the cost of utility bills to allow tribal members to allocate more financial resources to other priorities like food healthcare education transportation and personal spending and reducing green house gas GHG emissions along with their related negative respiratory health impacts This project would also overall support the Tribe s goal of becoming a Net Zero carbon emitter which directly reflects their cultural values of ecological stewardship of their ancestral lands and the economic spiritual and cultural well being of their people Activities Please note that the term quot the Project quot refers to the entire project and all of its individual aspects under the Government to Government grant The activities to be performed by Prairie Island Indian Community through this G2G grant are as follows Project design where Prairie Island Indian Community PIIC Project leaders working with PIIC Tribal Council staff and Minnesota Center for Energy and Environment CEE will discuss and decide on key parameters of the Project such as participant eligibility per participant budgets final list of energy measures to be offered to participants among other items CEE will also set up key Project management tools and systems Solicitation of comments ideas needs from the Tribal community under the guidance of the Prairie Island Housing Advisory Committee This information will inform the technologies used for home energy upgrades Such upgrades will assist in the transition of Tribal home energy systems relying on fossil fuels to electric systems Community meetings events social media and direct interactions to create enrolled member awareness of the project These platforms will further feature information on how community members can participate and benefit from the project and after work has begun updates on project progress and long term results of such progress Contractor Agreements ndash PIIC will execute agreements with contractors for Project administration audits and home upgrades QAPP Development ndash PIIC will develop a Quality Assurance Project Plan QAPP and receive final approval from the EPA A campaign to enroll Tribal home owners in this project will occur enrollment in the home audits project is voluntary and if enrolling participants will have the opportunity to authorize their electric and gas utilities to be shared for insight on their energy use data which will assist in tracking project performance measurements such as GHG emissions change in utility costs and respiratory health outcomes Energy audits will be performed by contractors to Assess enrolled participants homes for energy efficiency and electrification potential Document home conditions fuel sources health and safety measures Calculate cost of utilities and long term savings Reporting the findings and recommendations for home updates based on such audits to the home owners Tribal homes enrolled in the project will have the opportunity to have their homes upgraded based on the findings and recommendations from the audits Contractors will do such upgrades at no cost to the resident including direct installation of energy efficiency weatherization and electrification measures such as installation of new energy efficient equipment water heaters heat pumps LED lighting and more based on the audit recommendations Installation of other
gs_org: Ofc Of The Regional Administrator R5

project_description: Description The agreement provides funding to The North Dakota Department Of Environmental Quality NDDEQ the North Dakota Department Of Health and Human Services NDDHHS the North Dakota Cancer Coalition NDCC and the Community Action Partnerships of North Dakota CAPND to implement its own project to fill gaps in radon awareness testing and mitigation in a campaign to reduce radon rsquo s impacts in low income homes in three pilot regions Direct beneficiaries of this project are low income and limited English speaking LEP households in North Dakota who are living in unhealthy homes in the pilot areas Specifically the recipient will receive a radon testing kit and directions on where to return the kit and also remove barriers for low income homeowners allowing for the installation of a radon mitigation system to create a healthy home Activities The activities include creating new partnerships between state and Community Based Organizations CBO that can reduce radon rsquo s impacts by distributing an additional 600 radon test kits over the project period improve existing and create new radon information in Plain Language for ease of translation for Limited English Proficiency LEP individuals and create healthy homes for 50 low income families by providing radon testing and mitigation services The project goals align with the U S Environmental Protection Agency EPA Strategic Plan Goal 4 which is to ensure clean and healthy air for communities specifically improvements in indoor air quality These activities are allowable under Statutory Authority Citation Consolidated Appropriations Act 2023 Public Law 117 328 Outcomes The anticipated deliverables include the NDDEQ procuring an award to a contractor for a meeting facilitator facilitation of ND Radon Coalition Organizational Meeting s establish a statutory partnership agreement for sustainable radon education outreach testing mitigation and mitigation reimbursement Establish mitigation reimbursement criteria and eligibility Establish project schedule and establish Project Partnership Agreement between Community Action Partnerships of North Dakota CAPND a non profit and the NDDEQ for subaward The NDDEQ will promote advertise and distribute radon test kits Advertise availability of radon test kits in the CAPND pilot regional areas Deploy test kits to CAPND pilot regional areas Distribute newly available radon information for LEP individuals Promote education and outreach in schools by promoting the Radon Poster contest The expected outcomes include ND Radon Coalition MOU signed ND Radon Coalition Semi Annual Progress Meeting Radon outreach documents to translation services Promote radon awareness month and announce winners of poster contest Estimated 25 homes have radon mitigation systems installed Promote radon awareness month Announce winners of poster contest Install winning poster contest billboards in each pilot project regional areas Social media boosts NDDEQ conduct outreach at home shows ND Radon Coalition semi annual progress meeting amp report Final 25 homes have radon mitigation systems installed Pilot project evaluation review and report preparation Review and revise if needed Radon Coalition MOU and final project report due to the EPA The intended beneficiaries include low income and limited English speaking LEP households in North organization: STATE OF UTAH DEPT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY
event_timeline:

- 2024-09-27: Project description changed; Program manager changed from Craig Silotti to Lexie Wilson

project_description: Description The agreement provides funding to address air pollution inequities in underserved urban rural and tribal communities in Utah through 1 Radon testing remediation and mitigation and 2 Enhanced PM2 5 PM10 and ozone monitoring using low cost sensors This work follows a community engaged approach and leverages close community partnerships and an existing low cost air quality sensing network infrastructure We will engage communities through our community advisory group community meetings and presentations educational modules training and air quality visualizations This work will help strengthen relationships between impacted communities and regulatory agencies leading to increased trust effective collaboration shared decision making and development of mitigation strategies Activities The activities included in the proposed work will focus on specific disadvantaged urban rural and tribal communities The proposed project will reduce air quality inequities impacting underserved communities in urban rural and tribal areas in Utah by adding more PM2 5 PM10 and ozone sensors to address measurement gaps in these areas Through radon testing and mitigation of roughly 300 500 homes and schools the project will also lead to an immediate reduction in lung cancer risk especially among vulnerable school children Increased public awareness on radon exposure will also empower urban rural and tribal communities to make behavioral changes that will directly benefit their health such as changing the operation of their Heating Ventilation and Air Conditioning HVAC systems to reduce indoor radon concentrations Outcomes The anticipated deliverables include adding more PM2 5 PM10 and ozone sensors to address measurement gaps in areas radon testing and mitigation at homes and schools and engage communities through our community advisory group community meetings and presentations educational modules training and air quality visualizations The expected outcomes include radon testing and mitigation as needed air pollution sensor expansion and mapping efforts and education to the public Long term behavioral changes will reduce the number of asthma related hospital visits and pulmonary health complications A reduction in lung cancer incidence and deaths especially in these underserved urban and rural communities where cancer cases and deaths are greater than the statewide average is also expected The intended beneficiaries include underserved urban rural and tribal communities where cancer cases and deaths are greater than the statewide average due to air pollution and radon exposure Subrecipient UCAIR 50 837 00 community based organization will act as a liaison between the data gathering team and local community stakeholders facilitating key community meetings and presentations assisting in the development of educational modules and establishing and leading a community advisory board URC 448 200 00 community based organization will facilitate radon testing in low income households in our target communities They will also identify households eligible for radon mitigation and will lead the installation of radon mitigation systems URC will also conduct community outreach activities including providing training on how to test for radon and reduce risk of exposure to radon and engaging elected and appointed officials to promote radiation and radon awareness Westside Coalition community based organization will share and discuss their findings with the coalition and at community council meetings University of Utah 140 765 00 academic will assist with testing rural and low income schools for radon and have collaborated with BYU to work on determining the associations between the characteristics of HVAC systems in schools and radon levels They will lead the laboratory calibration field calibration deployment and troubleshooting of the ozone and PM sensors This t

project_description: Description This action approves an award in the amount of 75 000 to support GASP to launch a community needs assessment survey to gauge residents health concerns and deploy at least 20 digital air sensors PurpleAir in the community and train residents to report air quality incidents Activities to be performed To study Air Pollution and collect particle pollution data using Purple Air or comparable low cost digital air sensors We will also sample for toxic air pollution using sorbent tubes and or summa cannisters This information will help residents understand what rsquo s in the air their breathing and what impact that may have on their health Plan to do the following 1 conduct 2 week passive sorbent tube sampling 2 collect a smaller number of SUMMA canister samples collocated with sorbent tubes to assess measurement precision and 3 conduct two 3 month sampling campaigns during summer and winter The Anticipated Deliverables and Expected Outcomes will be under the categories of studying of air pollution which will be accompanied by public outreach and education The main projected outcomes will include short term increase in knowledge of residents on outdoor air pollution and risks to public health intermediate education of residents that can better report increased air pollution events to non profits and regulatory agencies long term better controls reduction in air pollution 2 years after the project The Intended Beneficiaries will be the residents of Birmingham especially those living near the fence line of an assortment of manufacturing industry which emits air pollution Activities Outcomes Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

project_description: Description The purpose of this Environmental  and American Rescue Plan funded small grant is to educate community members near refineries and petrochemical facilities particularly those communities where COVID 19 fatalities have been disproportionately high about available air quality information including its connection to COVID 19 morbidity and greenhouse gas emissions Project activities include engaging and training 20 30 residents per parish over three parishes to become aware of air quality via air sampling and reports to the Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality LDEQ hotline synthesizing data including demographics COVID 19 rates and emissions information and compiling incident data into a report to understand the frequency of incidents and their connection with bad weather events Activities Project activities include engaging and training 20 30 residents per parish over three parishes to become aware of air quality via air sampling and reports to the Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality LDEQ hotline synthesizing data including demographics COVID 19 rates and emissions information and compiling incident data into a report to understand the frequency of incidents and their connection with bad weather events Outcomes Anticipated deliverables include 20 30 residents per parish over three parishes trained on air quality sampling and a completed report on air incident data Expected outcomes include increased community awareness about greenhouse gas emissions air quality and respiratory illnesses such as COVID 19 and community generated documentation of air quality and industry incidents that is shared with governmental agencies People with moderate to severe or uncontrolled asthma are more likely to be hospitalized from COVID 19 Air pollution may contribute to asthma By addressing air pollution in Clean Air Act CAA 103 b 3 projects the chances of severe illness from COVID 19 are reduced Direct beneficiaries are residents of the St John St James and Caddo Parishes in Louisiana Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

project_description: Description The agreement provides funding to Louisiana Department of Health Specifically the recipient will fund virtual home visits with certified asthma educators conduct indoor air quality monitoring and conduct in person home assessments The program objective is to promote healthy homes to improve asthma outcomes in vulnerable Louisiana communities Louisiana Department of Health will partner with community based organizations to improve referrals to the program to help those most affected by asthma and to provide information to partners to advocate for policy change to improve housing quality in the state of Louisiana thereby reducing the disparity of the state rsquo s asthma burden Activities The activities include conducting virtual home visits in Bossier Caddo Calcasieu East Baton Rouge Jefferson and Orleans parishes with certified asthma educators indoor home assessments that collect indoor and outdoor air quality data community outreach through project partners with the objective of improving awareness of the link between indoor air quality and asthma and conducting a health impact assessment Outcomes The anticipated deliverables include 300 virtual home visits conducted by certified asthma educators 150 indoor home assessments that will evaluate building materials and Heating Ventilation and Air Conditioning style and will collect indoor air quality data for the pollutants Nitrogen Dioxide Ozone Volatile Organic Compounds Carbon Monoxide Carbon Dioxide and Particulate Matter 2 5 as well as outdoor air quality data hold interdisciplinary events to discuss how to encourage and develop healthy housing in Louisiana and conduct a health impact assessment The expected outcomes include promotion of health homes to improve asthma outcomes in vulnerable Louisiana communities to improve air quality by increasing data that would lead to improved policies and asthma outcomes and to improve awareness of the link between indoor air quality and asthma within heavily burdened communities The intended beneficiaries include vulnerable community members experiencing asthma as a result of poor indoor air quality within their homes Subrecipient The Louisiana State University Ag Center will analyze air quality data and provide an asthma educator with an established background in healthy homes education to provide in person assessments and virtual home visits for participants in Northwest Louisiana The Louisiana State University Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering will provide support on installing air monitors and analyzing collected data as part of our efforts to provide a Health Impact Assessment The New Orleans Health Department will assist with home assessments setting up indoor monitors and monitoring outdoor air Louisiana Department of Health will partner with Our Lady of the Lake Hospital Inc OLOL a 501 c 3 in East Baton Rouge Parish who will provide virtual home visits that include Heathy Homes and asthma education OLOL will also provide 300 copies of their asthma education booklet for BREATHE participants The Louisiana Center for Health Equity will serve as a strategic partner on project activities involving community outreach including planning implementation and evaluation act as a liaison to community organizations participate in organizing and lending expertise and input towards community level initiatives The Move Project will produce and record interviews with community members who participated in the BREATHE program HousingNOLA will provide legal expertise regarding housing policies serve as a referral base for participants with asthma and provide a focus group comprised of community members to provide feedback for educational materials created Louisiana Department of Health will partner with Green and Healthy Homes Initiative for training and technical assistance on Healthy Homes topics and programming

event_timeline:

project_description: Description The purpose of the Yakutat Subsistence Consumption Assessment project is to strengthen the Yakutat Tlingit Tribes rsquo ability to participate in developing water quality standards WQSs that are more protective of subsistence harvesters The scope of this project is to conduct research that provides a quantitative assessment of the current fish consumption rate of the Yakutat Tlingit tribal members who live in Yakutat Alaska This project will provide outreach to the community and other Tribes to show the connection between safe subsistence foods and Water Quality Standards The results of this research will be used to promote awareness of the importance of traditional foods and train other Tribes on how to conduct a Fish Consumption Rate survey Activities This project will provide outreach to the community and other Tribes to show the connection between safe subsistence foods and Water Quality Standards Outcomes The results of this research will be used to promote awareness of the importance of traditional foods and train other Tribes on how to conduct a Fish Consumption Rate survey Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

project_description: Description The objectives of this study are to osteogenically differentiate hESCs with concomitant chemical exposure Detrimental effects of the chemical will be evaluated based on a reduction in matrix mineralization as a surrogate of skeletal maturation The proposed work is expected to achieve a classification of test chemicals by toxicologically relevant Adverse Outcome Pathways AOPs and based on an improved understanding of targeted effects on organogenesis while at the same time achieving high predictivity at reduced labor and cost Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

project_description: Description Immortalized cell lines will be developed to investigate three objectives 1 Develop assays complementary to fish early life stage and larval growth for a euryhaline model 2 Quantify internal exposure concentrations of model pesticides across a salinity gradient and 3 Use a combination of genomic tools and demographic modeling link in vivo phenotypic anchors to biomarker candidates and population level outcomes The project will reduce the sacrifice of animals and allow for parallel high throughput testing to determine the effects of environmentally ubiquitous compounds Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

project_description: Description The project will update the chemical mechanisms related to dinitrogen pentoxide N2O5 chemistry in the CMAQ air quality model and use the improved CMAQ model to investigate the influence of N2O5 chemistry on NOx ozone and fine PM The research will generate publications and findings that lead to improved understanding of N2O5 chemistry and its impacts on the formation fate and transport of NOx ozone and fine particulate matter PM which are air pollutants associated with adverse health impacts Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

project_description: Description The primary outcomes of this project will be improvement of data and tools used for generating explicit and detailed chemical mechanisms Specific focus of this work will be on atmospheric chemistry of air pollutants from emerging sources such as wildland fires and volatile consumer products The updated data and tools are expected to lead to a greatly improved understanding of atmospheric chemistry and improved air quality models Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

project_title: Mechnisms for Secondary Organic Aerosol from VOCs
event_timeline:

project_description: Description The goal of the proposed research is to improve the chemical mechanism representation of secondary organic aerosol SOA formation from oxygenated volatile organic compounds VOCs in biomass burning and volatile chemical products VCP sources This proposal hypothesizes that the inclusion of oxygenated VOCs particularly phenols furans glycols and glycol ethers in chemical mechanisms will improve predictions of SOA formation and properties by air quality models AQMs Activities This research will lead to improved chemical mechanisms to represent oxygenated volatile organic compounds in air quality modeling The primary tool we will use in this work is the SOM TOMAS Statistical Oxidation Model Two Moment Aerosol Sectional model that simulates the multigenerational chemistry thermodynamic properties and microphysics of secondary organic aerosols The recipient will develop an improved representation of secondary organic aerosol formation from oxygenated volatile organic compounds in biomass burning and volatile chemical product sources which will lead to improved performance of air quality models thereby prioritizing robust science Outcomes The outcomes of this research will improve the ability of chemical mechanisms to more accurately represent how secondary organic aerosols contribute to fine particle pollution from biomass burning and volatile chemical products Direct beneficiaries of this program include the scientific community state local and tribal air quality agencies and the general public Subrecipient

project_description: Description The objective of the proposed project is to develop a diagnostic software package based on machine learning to identify the key elements of a chemical mechanism to aid the future development of air quality models AQMs as well as to create a chemical mechanism emulator that can be used as an alternative computationally inexpensive method to simulate atmospheric chemistry This project aims to greatly simplify application specific model development as will be demonstrated using the regional CMAQ and global GEOS Chem air quality models Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

project_description: Description This project will fill a fundamental gap on organ on a chip toxicity screening devices to assess how chemical to device substrate contact affect their toxicokinetics A Quantitative Structure Property Relationship QSPR model will be developed to predict chemical polydimethylsiloxane PDMS interactions After initial testing of a set of 54 chemicals the new QSPR model will be used to predict sequestration into PDMS for a wider set of chemicals and should enable prospective toxicokinetic modeling for any chemical Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

project_description: Description This project will establish methods within a risk based decision framework for using new approach methodologies NAMs by integrating new biological i e tissue chips analytical and computational modeling methods for data driven In Vitro ndash In Vivo Extrapolations IVIVE The data driven toxicokinetic modeling developed will be tested with a wide range of chemical compounds and chemical mixtures devised to model realistic real world exposures Activities This research aims to integrate newly validated biological assays microphysiological systems of the liver kidney and gut with demonstrated analytical ion mobility spectrometry mass spectrometry IMS MS method and to couple them with a recently developed database of thousands of environmental chemicals Consistent with the statutory activities above this project will allow for refined data driven IVIVE in vitro to in vivo extrapolations further improve risk based decisions on environmental chemicals and mixtures and allow for more robust and standardized new approach methodologies NAMs This project relates to Toxic Substances Control Act TSCA section a conduct research development and monitoring as necessary Outcomes This grant provides financial assistance to the Texas A amp M University to implement its own project to further develop improved High Throughput Screening methods In particular the integrated set of novel biological assays i e tissue chips analytical techniques i e IMS MS and computational methods that result will be used to enable high fidelity data driven toxicokinetic models for use in predictive chemical screens Direct Beneficiaries of this program include the general public who will benefit from improved chemical safety decisions and scientists and risk assessors who will have access to better faster and more informative testing of chemical substances Subrecipient

project_description: Description This project aims to understand how flooding caused by hurricanes influences distribution of PFAS and how societal factors can exacerbate impacts of PFAS exposure Researchers will characterize PFAS species diversity and concentration ranges in water soil sediments and biological samples before and immediately after a flooding event Research will design a simulation model to forecast PFAS transport and risk exposure of different communities after flooding events Researchers will also build community resilience to reduce exposure and possible health effects of PFAS Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

project_description: Description The objective of this project is to develop a model using machine learned Bayesian networks to analyze data samples to predict per and polyfluoroalkyl substances PFASs contamination sources and create fate and transport models in rural drinking water systems This research focuses on a model approach integrated with risk assessment risk communication and PFAS testing to improve the accuracy of risk predictions and to facilitate informed risk management decisions for PFAS contamination in rural agricultural communities Activities Outcomes Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

project_description: Description The proposed project will demonstrate the effectiveness of farm runoff treatment systems in reducing nutrient discharges to coastal waterways and provide a blueprint for scaling up treatment systems within two key agricultural watersheds of the Monterey Bay CA In addition this project will examine the potential link between agricultural nutrient discharges and the growth of harmful algal blooms HABs Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

event_timeline:

project_description: Description The project aims to develop a novel technology that will prevent harmful algal blooms in watering ponds The research involves the synthesis of eight candidate magnesium aluminum oxide and magnesium iron oxide sorbent medias for the uptake of urea ammonium phosphate and nitrate ions The technology will allow for the absorbed nutrients to be used as a time release fertilizer The goal will be to create a sustainable solution for the prevention of harmful algal blooms and reduce the environmental and financial costs associated with fertilizer production and decontamination of ponds Activities This project conduct and promote the coordination and acceleration of research investigations experiments training demonstrations surveys and studies relating to the causes effects extent prevention reduction and elimination of pollution Specifically to prevent eutrophication and be applied as a time release fertilizer This will improve the understanding of environmental drivers of harmful algal blooms and contribute to the understanding of the chemical and this project will develop a highly scalable low cost sorbent media that will efficiently capture excess plant nutrients biological integrity of the Upper Ohio River basin By understanding and predicting harmful algal blooms this project will enable state and local resource managers to reduce their occurrence and thereby contribute to the protection of clean water Outcomes The project aims to develop a novel technology that will prevent harmful algal blooms in watering ponds The research involves the synthesis of eight candidate magnesium aluminum oxide and magnesium iron oxide sorbent medias for the uptake of urea ammonium phosphate and nitrate ions The technology will allow for the absorbed nutrients to be used as a time release fertilizer The goal will be to create a sustainable solution for the prevention of harmful algal blooms and reduce the environmental and financial costs associated with fertilizer production and decontamination of ponds Direct Beneficiaries of this program include the general public sate and local regulators public health departments water utilities and communities impacted by differing sources of PFASs Subrecipient

project_description: Description This project proposes to improve full scale applications of shortcut nitrogen removal processes by increasing nitrite availability for anaerobic ammonium oxidizing bacteria anammox in mainstream systems With the opportunity for innovative full scale process deployment over the timeframe of this three year project the project includes a Utility Advisory Committee UAC engaging technical representatives from 8 progressive utilities in HAB hotspot regions including the Great Lakes Midwest and Florida Activities This project seeks to facilitate implementation of new treatment technologies through collaboration with over 90 water utilities that include drinking water facilities to ultimately reduce the occurrence of Harmful Algal Blooms and their associated toxins which affect water bodies designated for drinking water supply Outcomes The Water Research Foundation will implement its own project to close several key knowledge gaps and develop guidance and communication tools for utilities and design Engineers that will facilitate widespread adoption of Partial denitrification anammox PdNA at a time when many utilities across the US and globally are considering upgrades to their water resource recovery facilities to reduce nutrient discharges Direct beneficiaries of this project are water utilities state and local regulators public health departments and the general public Subrecipient

project_description: Description The goal of this project is to understand and mitigate the current and possible future soil heavy metal and metalloid and other chemical contaminant exposure among children in West Atlanta by estimating children rsquo s soil ingestion rates Using targeted and non targeted soil analyses researchers will create a detailed map showing the soil abundances of lead and other chemical contaminants in West Atlanta where high contamination was recently found Children rsquo s exposure to lead and other chemicals will also be quantified using survey data and biological samples Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

project_description: Description This project aims to implement an innovative methodology based on non targeted screening approach to identify specific tracers of dust and soil exposure Researchers will combine this with relevant information on children rsquo s behavior and other characteristics to provide a more accurate estimate of soil and dust ingestion rates The study includes families with children from 6 months to 6 years Researchers will conduct surveys interviews and collect environmental biological samples to identify health risks associated with chemical exposure to young children via soil and dust ingestion Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

project_description: Description Researchers will assess dust and soil exposures for children ages six months to six years via macro and micro activity pattern and tracer studies Researchers will create a novel integrated toolset based on major innovations in activity patterns and tracer studies that will address all four key components needed to quantify children rsquo s soil and dust exposure This proposed work will yield novel insights necessary to refine and increase confidence in soil and dust ingestion estimates for young children Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

project_description: Description Researchers will perform studies to quantify dust loading on children rsquo s hands and indoor home surfaces and will also deliver a household dust survey to families for analysis of key variables influencing dust loading on children rsquo s hands and in homes and ingestion rates By collecting children rsquo s hand contact and mouthing activities in homes through video methods researchers will expand the database of children rsquo s micro activities to include key environments locations and sociodemographic groups Finally researchers will enhance an existing model to capture additional soil dust pathways for children rsquo s dermal and non dietary ingestion Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

project_description: Description This project will elucidate determinants of indoor dust ingestion in 6 to 24 month old infants Researchers will test if the frequency and characteristics of indoor dust and non dust mouthing events change with age and motor development stage for different micro environments and how home characteristics and demographic factors affect indoor dust mass loading and dust toxicant concentration The project also examines how dust transfer is influenced by dust properties surface features and contact dynamics and contributions of developmental behavioral and socio environmental factors to dust and toxicant resolved dust ingestion rates Amendment budget revision nbsp https www epa gov grants epa office research and development research terms and conditions effective december 15 2021 Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

project_description: Description Researchers will apply new technologies in both dust and urine analysis to determine child specific dust ingestion rates under an experimental design that includes multiple geographic and socioeconomic status SES groups Key outcomes will be to identify a set of compounds that serve as optimal tracers of dust ingestion that can easily be applied in future monitoring illustrate geographic and SES based differences in children rsquo s dust ingestion rates and chemical exposures measure dust concentrations and overall chemical exposures for children in geographic and SES groups not frequently studied and significantly improve risk assessment calculations involving dust ingestion by children Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

project_description: Description This research seeks to develop an innovative integrative approach which fuses analytical computational observational and statistical methods to estimate dust soil ingestion rates of children aged 6 months through 6 years with demographic and environmental variabilities This project will provide exposure scientists with a hybrid approach to estimate the dust soil ingestion rate in a defensible and accurate manner and will provide health and risk assessors tabulated stratified estimates of dust soil ingestion rates for subgroups of children of interest and a holistic computational tool for population or site specific assessments Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

project_description: Description Researchers will use longitudinal study data and urine samples from children to examine the impacts of early life exposure to phthalates The study will evaluate exposures in relation to neurobehavior development with attention to the potential for sex specific effects Additionally they will examine how prenatal toxicant exposures relate to 3rd trimester fetal brain imaging features and their trajectories of development postnatally using postnatal imaging scans Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

project_description: Description The overarching objective of this Center is to make causal linkages between cumulative environmental exposures caregiving environments in early childhood and changes in neurodevelopment for preschoolers The study will complete environmental exposure analyses at both the home and childcare center along with neurodevelopmental and caregiving environment evaluations With this data researchers will leverage objective performance based measures of children rsquo s cognitive function and behavior ratings to index neurodevelopmental functioning to causally relate them to chemical exposure Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

project_title: Informing School Decision-Making during Wildfire Events: Evaluation of Indoor PM2.5 Exposures and Associated Health Impacts in Children
organization: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

project_description: Description The goal of the project is to inform public health guidance on if based on school and nearby home characteristics and when i e at what Air Quality Index AQI or PM2 5 concentration levels schools should close during wildfire smoke events to protect the health of students Activities To achieve the goal researchers will 1 investigate factors that influence the outdoor to indoor transport of PM2 5 into schools and students rsquo homes during wildfire events and 2 assess the relationship between PM2 5 levels inside and outside of schools and children rsquo s respiratory health Outcomes Direct beneficiaries of this program include the scientific community state and local entities working with school districts and school aged children and their families Subrecipient

project_title: School Resilience to Wildland Smoke and Outdoor Sources of Fine and Ultrafine Particles
event_timeline:
- 2021-07-23: Grant awarded; Obligation of $548,537
- 2022-02-16: Project description changed
- 2024-11-20: End date extended from 2024-08-31 to 2025-08-31
- 2025-04-23: End date cut off from 2025-08-31 to 2025-04-23
project_description: Description The purpose of the proposed research is to enhance existing efforts taking place in Washington state to identify evidence based solutions utilizing portable air cleaners to improve indoor air quality in schools Activities The project will 1 Implement a classroom based intervention using portable air cleaners to reduce exposure to wildland fire smoke across 10 schools in Washington state 2 Observe the impact of the intervention using portable air cleaners on respiratory health of students using a randomized controlled study design within school and 3 Engage with participating schools to adapt an existing hands on air quality curriculum aimed at increasing environmental health literacy on the topic of ambient smoke air quality and health Outcomes The expected outputs include 1 a model of size fractioned particle infiltration in both rural and urban schools that takes into account building type ventilation parameters and existing filtration type 2 direct evaluation of the efficacy of reducing exposure to wildland fire smoke using an appropriately sized portable air cleaners with auto mode in classroom settings and 3 measures of the association between indoor air quality and respiratory health in a diverse cohort of elementary school children Direct beneficiaries of this program include the scientific community state and local entities working with school districts and elementary school children and their families Yakama Nation Air Quality Section will work with the University of Washington researchers to respond to tribal program need ensure relevance to the community participate in developing culturally aware educational material that is in line with requirements and regulations applicable on Yakama Nation Tribal land and help ensure that the research team does not inadvertently violate tribal sovereignty Subrecipient

project_description: Description The goal of the project is to increase wildfire smoke risk mitigation in rural communities northern Nevada through the development implementation and evaluation of stakeholder driven monitoring and messaging Researchers will evaluate the performance of selected portable air quality sensors and place them in three rural Nevada counties to monitor air quality develop education materials to reduce knowledge gaps in wildfire smoke risk among emergency managers and the public and evaluate the effectiveness of in air quality monitoring and messaging to mitigate wildfire smoke risk Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

project_title: Assessing the Transport of Wildfire-Generated Particulate Matter Into Homes and Developing Practical Interventions to Reduce Human Exposure (WildPM)
organization: Regents of the University of Colorado

project_description: Description The goal of the project is to assess practical and effective approaches to reduce indoor exposure to particulate matter PM of outdoor wildland fire origin in single family housing in the western U S The project will conduct field studies to assess a variety of sustainable and practical interventions for reducing indoor PM levels such as indoor particle filtration ventilation strategies and building sealing strategies In addition model simulations will be used to infer the effectiveness of the interventions for various single family homes types found in the western US Activities The project will conduct field studies to assess a variety of sustainable and practical interventions for reducing indoor PM levels such as indoor particle filtration ventilation strategies and building sealing strategies In addition model simulations will be used to infer the effectiveness of the interventions for various single family homes types found in the western US Outcomes The project will conduct field studies to assess a variety of sustainable and practical interventions for reducing indoor PM levels such as indoor particle filtration ventilation strategies and building sealing strategies In addition model simulations will be used to infer the effectiveness of the interventions for various single family homes types found in the western US Subrecipient

- 2025-05-10: End date cut off from 2025-08-31 to 2025-05-10
project_description: Description The overall objective of this research is to conduct field and laboratory research to enable accurate modeling of interventions intended to reduce indoor woodsmoke exposures The project will improve understanding of outdoor to indoor air pollutant transport in single family detached homes evaluate commercial and low cost air cleaning approaches for particle and gas phase pollutants characterize polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons PAHs on indoor surfaces to elucidate how indoor woodsmoke may cause long term exposure to PAHs indoors Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

project_title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Reducing Wildfire Smoke Exposure and Health Risks in Low-Income Hard-to-Reach Communities in California
event_timeline:
- 2021-07-12: Grant awarded; Obligation of $999,846
- 2024-07-17: End date extended from 2024-08-31 to 2026-08-31; Program manager changed from Gabrielle Wong-Parodi to Gabrielle Wong-Parondi
- 2025-04-28: End date cut off from 2026-08-31 to 2025-04-28; Program manager changed from Gabrielle Wong-Parondi to Gabrielle Wong-Parodi
project_description: Description The purpose of the proposed research is to study the effectiveness of several methods of smoke exposure reduction The recipient will conduct a two year longitudinal randomized controlled trial of 265 San Francisco Bay Area residents from low income and non English speaking communities in San Mateo and Santa Clara counties The project goals are to 1 Evaluate if and how much app delivered native language messaging air sealing or portable high efficiency particulate air filters can effectively reduce smoke exposure and associated health risks 2 Evaluate how the effectiveness is moderated by behavior over time and 3 Evaluate how and why behavior is affected by use of the app delivered native language messaging The results of this study will identify affordable and actionable intervention steps for individuals and communities and inform policies programs and risk communication strategies for community partners local governments and local state agencies that are behaviorally realistic for the hard to reach communities they serve Methods results and lessons learned from this project can be used to conduct future evaluations of the effectiveness of interventions for wildfire smoke exposure in other settings e g multi family work places and among other hard to reach populations e g rural communities reservations in California and beyond Direct beneficiaries of this project include the scientific community state and local entities working to reduce wildfire smoke exposures and communities affected by wildfire smoke exposures RTI International will provide technical expertise for the personal exposure and air quality assessment by designing the exposure study training field staff on air sensor deployment and data extraction assessing the air quality and exposures for particulate matter and assessing sleep quality of a sub population who has existing health problems Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

project_description: Description The goal of the research is to decrease smoke exposures and associated health impacts from prescribed burn events Main output of the research is a risk communication toolkit that can be used to 1 facilitate communication to reinforce the smoke management goal associated with the careful planning of prescribed burns and 2 effectively inform the public about interventions that can be taken to reduce smoke exposure during prescribed burns Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

program: Office of Research and Development Consolidated Research
project_title: Unregulated Organic Chemicals in Biosolids: Prioritization, Fate and Risk Evaluation for Land Applications
event_timeline:

- 2022-02-10: Project description changed

- 2025-05-07: End date cut off from 2026-09-30 to 2025-05-07
- 2025-07-14: End date extended from 2025-05-07 to 2026-09-30
project_description: Description The purpose of the proposed research is to produce a prioritized list of unregulated organic chemicals UOCs that have the greatest potential to pose elevated risks to human health and the environment and standard rapid assays to measure mobile and bioavailable fractions of these chemicals in biosolids Activities Activities include prioritizing UOCs in biosolids based on their occurrence mobility persistence and bioaccumulation developing simple standard assays to measure mobile and bioavailable fractions of priority UOCs in biosolids and carrying out field studies at multiple locations to evaluate plant and earthworm accumulation leaching and runoff risks of priority UOCs under different biosolids application soil climate and planting conditions Outcomes The expected outcome of this research is a decrease in associated public health and ecosystem risks Direct beneficiaries of this research include the scientific community agriculture and water sectors and the broader community in ensuring the safe reuse of biosolids through land applications in the U S UC Riverside Purdue University and the University of Cincinnati are integrally involved in conducting all aspects of the research in the work plan Subrecipient

project_title: Integrated Communication and Intervention Strategies to Reduce Exposure to Prescribed Wildland Fire Emissions in Schools and Communities

- 2024-08-06: End date extended from 2024-08-31 to 2025-08-31
- 2025-05-08: End date cut off from 2025-08-31 to 2025-05-08
project_description: Description The project goals are to 1 evaluate an integrated strategy containing both interventions and communications to reduce wildland fire pollution exposure 2 establish that targeted intervention can be used to effectively reduce exposures of school community members to wildland fire burn emissions and 3 investigate how wildland fire impact forecasting can be used to reduce exposures both by adjusting the timing of burn activities and providing guidance to potentially impacted areas in advance The expected outcomes include an assessment of approaches to reduce exposures to air pollution from wildland fires reduce exposures of schoolchildren and advance an operation prescribed fire impact forecasting system Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

program: Office of Research and Development Consolidated Research
project_title: Fate and Transport of Unregulated Organic Contaminants in Biosolids - Development of a Human and Environmental Exposure Risk Framework

- 2025-05-13: End date cut off from 2026-07-31 to 2025-05-13
project_description: Description The purpose of this research is to 1 characterize the occurrence fate and transport of biosolid associated organic compounds BOCs after land application of biosolids 2 model BOC exposures and perform hazard and risk assessments to identify high priority BOCs and 3 utilize an array of communication channels to translate research findings and methodology Activities include combining laboratory and field experiments to characterize the occurrence and transformation of BOCs in biosolids amended soils assess their potential to contaminate surface and groundwater and quantify bioaccumulation into and metabolism within edible produce Deliverables include a new flexible framework for the identification of high priority BOCs in biosolids which can form the basis for future interventions and development of best risk management practices aimed at protecting public health and ecosystems Direct beneficiaries of this program include the scientific community local and regional governments wastewater and agricultural communities and the general public affected by BOCs Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

program: Office of Research and Development Consolidated Research
project_title: Elucidating The Occurrence of Known and Emerging Chemical Contaminants in Wastewater Biosolids and The Influence of Treatment and Management processes on their fate, mobility and bioavailability
event_timeline:
- 2021-07-30: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,486,562
- 2024-08-26: End date extended from 2024-07-31 to 2026-07-31; Project description changed; Obligation of $171,670
- 2025-05-13: End date cut off from 2026-07-31 to 2025-05-13
- 2025-07-03: End date extended from 2025-05-13 to 2026-07-31
project_description: Description The purpose of the proposed research is to use a series of controlled lab experiments and field investigations to optimize treatment processes and reduce contaminant levels in U S biosolids and receiving soils The three primary goals are to 1 advance understanding of the composition bioaccessibility bioavailability persistence toxicity and mobility of chemical pollutants in sludges biosolids and soils 2 evaluate the influence of wastewater source and treatment choice on these 3 assess sludge pollutant effects on critical wastewater treatment and soil microbial processes Activities Research will explore validate methods for detecting chemicals of emerging concern polar and nonpolar organics microplastics and microbially derived endotoxins in sludges and biosolids Researchers will then identify and quantify legacy and emerging contaminants in sludges and biosolids from multiple wastewater treatment plants in the Hampton Roads Sanitation District Laboratory work will include evaluating the influence of select sludge treatment processes on the above contaminants Researchers will also investigate impact of sludge treatment processes on contaminant mobility and toxicity to microbial processes as well as mobility and persistence of chemical pollutants in biosolids applied soil Hampton Roads Sanitary District will conduct wastewater treatment plant sample collection and consultations and also make available a bench top chemical reactor for high temperature and pressure experiments with wastewater solids to examine thermal hydrolysis process effects on pollutant bioaccessibility Outcomes Expected deliverables include annual progress and final reports scientific data scientific publications and presentations New validated methods for detecting chemicals of emerging concern including microplastics and microbially derived endotoxins will be developed Improved methods will generate data on emerging contaminants in sludges and biosolids including differences in chemical pollutants in sludges collected from different sources with different biosolids treatment processes Thermal hydrolysis processes anerobic digestion liming and thermal drying and wastewater inputs municipal commercial and industrial Outcomes include improved strategies for monitoring sludge related pollutants selecting optimal treatment processes and reducing contaminant levels in U S biosolids and receiving soils These improvements will decrease associated public health and ecosystem risks Intended beneficiaries of this program include wastewater utilities and water quality program managers the scientific community and communities effected by the chemicals of emerging concern in biosolids Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: Office of Research and Development Consolidated Research
project_title: Assessing Biosolid Treatment Processes On Environmental Fate And Plant Uptake Of Pollutants From Land Application Of Biosolids
event_timeline:

project_description: Description The purpose of this research is to 1 fill the knowledge gaps on the occurrence fate transport and plant uptake of pharmaceuticals and personal care products PPCPs and per and polyfluoroalkyl substances PFASs at the nexus of biosolids soil water and crops via performing systematically designed laboratory and field experiments 2 integrate the data to develop quantitative models for evaluating human exposure through biosolids application pathway and 3 communicate the research results through extension activities Direct beneficiaries of this program include the scientific community local and regional governments agricultural communities and the general public affected by PFASs and PPCPs Expected deliverables include data and user friendly models useful for evaluating occurrence fate transport and plant uptake of PPCPs and PFASs released from biosolids as well as a field guide summarizing risk factors contributing to human exposure to PPCPs and PFASs from biosolids application The expected outcome is a decrease in associated public health and ecosystem risks Colorado State U will conduct field experiments University of Georgia will analyze PFAS in biosolids and the Great Lakes Water Authority is supporting fellowships at the Michigan State University Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

organization: Regents of the University of Michigan

project_description: Description The purpose of this research is to expand the current understanding of virus fate during wastewater treatment and develop surrogate based crediting frameworks for unit processes that have largely been uncredited or under credited in nonpotable and potable reuse applications Deliverables will elucidate potential relationships between culture and molecular data for human enteric viruses surrogate bacteriophages and fecal indicator viruses Outcomes of the research include surrogate based predictive models and regulatory crediting frameworks that can be readily adopted by states and the water industry Direct beneficiaries of this program include residents of communities in Nevada Virginia and Florida served by CBAT facilities covered by the study wastewater operators state and local regulators and the general public Subawardee Southern Nevada Water Authority will conduct laboratory scale sequencing batch reactors and analyze the corresponding samples for microbiological targets and general water quality parameters Subawardee Drexel University will work on mathematical model development Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

project_title: A Cross-Regional, Cross-Laboratory Investigation of Viral Pathogens and Surrogates in Wastewater for Non-Potable Reuse

- 2025-07-11: End date extended from 2025-04-28 to 2025-07-31
project_description: Description The purpose of this project is to address public health concerns about human viral pathogens in treated wastewater for non potable reuse across the United States Activities include identifying a suite of viral pathogens and surrogates and detection methods that may best serve as an indication of viral risk in water reuse The outcome of this project will be a list of best methods for identifying the viral risk for non potable water reuse and Standard Operating Protocols SOPs for these methods Direct Beneficiaries of this program include wastewater operators state and local regulators and the general public The University of Miami will participate in wastewater sample and water quality data collection Tulane University the University of Hawaii UC Davis and the University of Utah will participate in the cross laboratory study to compare methods for detection of selective viral pathogens and surrogates Activities Outcomes Subrecipient

project_description: Description The purpose of this project is to better understand virus attenuation in wastewater and water treatment systems through the development of new quantitative tools with novel surrogates to improve sensitivity reduce analysis turnaround time and reduce the cost of measuring viruses in wastewater for validating treatment performance Activities include a comprehensive characterization of indigenous viruses in wastewater using metagenomics to identify improved surrogates for assessing treatment performance the design and development of new analytical methods to provide not only rapid and precise quantification of viruses in wastewater but also the ability to assess viability and validation of new quantitative detection assays for estimating reduction of viruses using both full scale advanced water reclamation treatment facilities and bench scale disinfection experiments Deliverables include advanced knowledge on the abundance diversity persistence and fate of viruses and viral vesicles in wastewater and will thus contribute to the outcome of improved strategies for risk assessment and control Direct Beneficiaries of this program include wastewater operators state and local regulators residents of communities in Ohio California and Florida with Water Reuse Facilities and the general public Subawardee Michigan State University will recover and concentrate viruses in wastewater and water samples and subawardee UC Riverside will prepare viral vesicles and conduct bench scale experiments to determine their log reduction during wastewater treatment Activities Activities include a comprehensive characterization of indigenous viruses in wastewater using metagenomics to identify improved surrogates for assessing treatment performance the design and development of new analytical methods to provide not only rapid and precise quantification of viruses in wastewater but also the ability to assess viability and validation of new quantitative detection assays for estimating reduction of viruses using both full scale advanced water reclamation treatment facilities and bench scale disinfection experiments Outcomes Deliverables include advanced knowledge on the abundance diversity persistence and fate of viruses and viral vesicles in wastewater and will thus contribute to the outcome of improved strategies for risk assessment and control Direct Beneficiaries of this program include wastewater operators state and local regulators residents of communities in Ohio California and Florida with Water Reuse Facilities and the general public Subawardee Michigan State University will recover and concentrate viruses in wastewater and water samples and subawardee UC Riverside will prepare viral vesicles and conduct bench scale experiments to determine their log reduction during wastewater treatment Subrecipient

project_description: Description The purpose of this study is to identify decentralized wastewater technologies and municipal treatment unit processes capable of removing human enteric viruses to allow safe reuse of the treated wastewater and to evaluate the use of five surrogates as possible indicators for presence of human enteric viruses during treatment processes Activities include using two culturable and three non culturable surrogate indicators for human enteric viruses to evaluate each technology rsquo s performance and to concurrently validate the use of these surrogates by parallel measurements of indigenous human adenoviruses and human noroviruses using state of the art analytical methods Deliverables include a rating of eight wastewater treatment processes with respect to removals inactivation of human enteric viruses and data with the outcome of ultimately informing policies and guidelines relative to testing of wastewater treatment technologies being considered for reuse of treated wastewater Direct Beneficiaries of this program include wastewater operators state and local regulators residents of Barnstable County MA and the general public Activities Outcomes Subrecipient
