- 2025-05-12: End date cut off from 2025-08-31 to 2025-05-12
- 2025-07-08: End date extended from 2025-05-12 to 2025-08-31
project_description: Description The purpose of this project is to use a combination of in silico in vitro and in vivo tools to test the overarching hypothesis that binding of per and polyfluoroalkyl substances PFAS to hemoglobin is a physiological signal for predicting the toxicity of PFAS mixtures Activities Using PFAS concentrations and ratios of mixtures found in surface and drinking water across the country researchers will quantify the binding of single PFAS and their mixtures to hemoglobin The specific objectives are to 1 develop mechanistic models to determine whether the toxicity of PFAS mixtures deviates from additivity 2 inform and validate in silico models using PFAS and hemoglobin binding affinity data and 3 inform and validate in silico models using in vivo toxicity tests The long term goal of the project is to produce mechanistic toxicity data for PFAS mixtures to support human and environmental health risk assessment Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports and the development of a novel simple cost effective and ecologically relevant approach for testing the toxicity of PFAS mixtures Direct beneficiaries of this project include communities across the U S exposed to PFAS mixtures human health the environment and the general public Subrecipient A subaward to Jackson State University for 166 223 to conduct computational protein docking and QSAR modeling of PFAS and their mixtures A subaward to Hendrix University for 36 964 to run equilibrium dialyses general toxicity testing with midges and hemoglobin content

project_title: Oral Toxicity Assessment of PAH Mixtures Using an In Vitro 3D Cell Culture Bioreactor Mimicking the In Vivo Intestinal Tract Environment
event_timeline:
- 2022-07-19: Grant awarded; Obligation of $749,926
- 2025-05-01: End date cut off from 2025-08-31 to 2025-05-01
project_description: Description The purpose this study is to design and engineer an in vitro 3D cell culture integrated into a flow cell bioreactor to conduct the toxicological assessment of environmental polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon PAH mixtures that can be found in food Activities The recipient will use human mice and pig intestinal cells to analyze toxicological markers and pathways of PAH mixtures This will allow researchers to evaluate the ability of the gut microbiome to biodegrade PAHs and whether the biodegradation by products can cause toxic effects to the intestinal tract Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports as well as a novel validated 3D cell culture that can be integrated with in vitro and in vivo results to identify toxicological markers and pathways of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon PAH mixtures in humans Direct beneficiaries of this program include people who are exposed to PAHs via food human health the environment and the general public Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

project_title: Wildfire Smoke Mixtures Toxicity Testing
organization: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHAPEL HILL
event_timeline:
- 2022-09-26: Grant awarded; Obligation of $376,846
- 2022-11-04: Other amendment
- 2023-06-13: Obligation of $223,153
- 2025-05-09: End date cut off from 2025-09-30 to 2025-05-09
project_description: Description The purpose of this project is to understand how individual chemicals in wildlife smoke induce in vitro responses that group according to biological pathways and inform mixtures based joint toxicities that overlap with in vivo pulmonary responses and disease outcomes Activities The objectives of this project are to 1 establish qualitative membership of wildfire mixture components into pathway groupings through in vitro transcriptomic screening 2 quantify joint toxicities across pathway groupings and compare to whole biomass smoke mixture effects through in silico modeling and 3 relate in vitro wildfire chemical induced signatures to similarly exposed mice and human pulmonary disease tissues to evaluate events along adverse outcome pathways AOPs Researchers will leverage existing chemical characterization results from variable biomass burn scenarios representing wildfire events to prioritize chemicals that co occur in wildfire smoke to test for chemical groupings and joint toxicities Lung cells from human donors will be exposed to individual chemicals and transcriptomic signatures from exposed cells will be used to group chemicals These chemical groups will then be tested using the same in vitro model alongside the full chemical mixture and whole biomass smoke mixtures to compare individual chemicals chemical groups and whole mixture effects on pathway level responses Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports as well as an improved mechanistic understanding and health risk quantification of wildfire smoke Results from this study may help identify geographic locations and vulnerable populations at increased risk of most harmful exposure conditions based on biomass composition burn scenarios Direct beneficiaries of this program include geographic locations and vulnerable populations at increased risk of wildfires human health the environment and the general public Subrecipient A subaward to North Carolina State University 45 000 will contribute towards overall data processing and statistical evaluation incorporating Bayesian based methodologies and advanced mixtures modeling

project_title: Assessment of Underlying Molecular Mechanisms Promoting Adipogenic Outcomes in Complex Mixtures
event_timeline:
- 2022-07-18: Grant awarded; Obligation of $598,487
- 2025-05-12: End date cut off from 2025-08-31 to 2025-05-12
project_description: Description The purpose of this project is to examine chemical mixtures of increasing complexity for their deviations from expected adipogenic effects using concentration addition and independent action models Activities The recipient will interrogate the comparability of joint toxicity as well as the development of methods focused various levels of biological organization The specific objectives are to 1 evaluate mixtures of increasing complexity for ability to promote adipogenesis 2 assess available mixture models through controlled assessments of contaminants acting through shared distinct and mixed mechanisms and 3 promote a greater functional understanding of complex mixture effects that can be utilized to bolster risk assessments of diverse contaminant exposures Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports as well as a new method of mixture risk assessments through using component mechanistic effect levels to determine cooperative effects on complex health endpoints and or outcomes The research team will utilize environmental samples household dust to develop a receptor bioactivity component model to predict adipogenic health outcomes The results of this project may promote a greater functional understanding of complex mixture effects that can be utilized to bolster risk assessments of diverse contaminant exposures Direct beneficiaries of this program include people at risk of metabolic health conditions human health the environment and the general public Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

project_title: Developing an Integrated Framework for Evaluating Toxicity of Real-Life Chemical Mixtures
organization: MedUniSC - THE MEDICAL UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA
event_timeline:
- 2022-08-16: Grant awarded; Obligation of $376,846
- 2023-06-29: Obligation of $223,152
- 2025-05-09: End date cut off from 2025-09-30 to 2025-05-09
project_description: Description The purpose of this project is to improve how real life exposure to multiple chemicals is considered in toxicity assessments of chemical mixtures Activities Researchers will identify real life chemical mixtures from biological samples taken during a large epidemiologic birth cohort study The research team will then prioritize exposure mixtures using epidemiologic analysis to identify mixtures most strongly associated with child health Researchers will also develop mixture toxicity assessments for prioritized exposures Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports as well as an innovative framework for toxicological assessment of real world exposure mixtures across a broad range of biological endpoints The resulting tools may provide a valuable resource to risk assessors and the broader scientific community interested in risk assessment of chemical mixtures Direct beneficiaries of this program include children s health nbsp human health the environment and the general public Subrecipient The subaward to Clemson University will be responsible for Aim 3 which involves testing the toxicity of the chemical mixtures using cell lines The goals are to first screen individual chemicals to assess whether they can cause or inhibit adipogensis Then researchers will develop a set of transfected mesenchymal stem cells that has five different receptors of interest to test whether the selected chemicals bind to them and determine the potency or strength of the binding Finally the Clemson lab will use the prioritized chemicals and mixtures from Aims 1 and 2 to examine altered adipocyte formation and triglyceride deposition while simultaneously examining mechanistic effects in the transfected cells

program: Office of Research and Development Consolidated Research
project_title: Accelerating Technical and Community Readiness for Beneficial Water Reuse in Small Systems
organization: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY
event_timeline:
- 2022-08-03: Grant awarded; Obligation of $3,246,000
- 2025-05-12: End date cut off from 2026-08-31 to 2025-05-12
- 2025-07-11: End date extended from 2025-05-12 to 2026-08-31
project_description: Description The objective of this project is to accelerate water reuse adoption in rural communities by increasing technical and community readiness The general hypothesis is that community readiness for water reuse in small systems can be accelerated by a convergence of technical informational social and institutional innovation Activities The research project aims for an integrated research and engagement program that will 1 address knowledge gaps and generate frameworks for overcoming these barriers and 2 use research outputs to evaluate and accelerate community readiness for reuse in five case studies Both general activities will be executed in parallel such that knowledge can be co produced with decision makers Specific methods to address knowledge gaps include community surveys the use of a prototype calculation engine and desktop bench scale and pilot scale evaluations of treatment technologies Specific methods to accelerate community readiness include legal and policy analyses and case study evaluations of five small water systems Outcomes This project rsquo s outputs include annual and final reports as well as modular decision support tools such as water inventories technology databases cost and demand curves for water reuse These outputs will be integrated into institutional and state and local regulatory decision making processes in small rural and underserved communities Intended beneficiaries include stakeholders in small communities such as utilities and local resource managers state and tribal decision makers as well as customers of small water systems Subrecipient The subaward to the University of Rhode Island Requested 681 965 Cost share 171 319 is for analyses for Objectives 2 Develop validated list of fit for purpose technologies 4 Identify ways to overcome social barriers to public acceptance and 6 Conduct case studies The subaward to the University of California Berkeley Requested 559 941 is for work on organizational barriers in Objective 5 Foster institutional innovation to overcome organizational barriers and support for Objective 6 Conduct case studies

program: Office of Research and Development Consolidated Research
project_title: Unlocking the Nationwide Potential of Water Reuse
event_timeline:
- 2022-07-27: Grant awarded; Obligation of $3,245,999
- 2025-05-07: End date cut off from 2026-08-31 to 2025-05-07; Program manager changed from Miriam Hacker to Sanjana Yagnambhatt
project_description: Description This project aims to enhance water technology innovation and water resources information availability to advance clean and safe water reuse goals at a national scale The research objectives and approach align development of science and technology with advances in sociological understanding of opportunities and barriers to unlock the full nationwide potential of water reuse Activities The project will A use wastewater based epidemiology WBE and surveillance to understand pathogen loading and enable rapid identification and response in reuse systems develop quantitative microbial risk assessment tools for application to under appreciated reuse applications and identify opportunities for chemical health risk reduction B Develop a comprehensive model for reuse treatment processes that includes predictive algorithms integrated to evaluate treatment train performance for microbial and chemical water quality goals incorporating pilot demonstration and techno economic analysis to support real time monitoring and risk mitigation C Quantify water reuse potential across the nation and identify barriers drivers and pathways to successful reuse through a rigorous case study evaluation process D Partner with community leaders to synthesize and address organizational and social barriers to advancing reuse across diverse contexts and for traditionally marginalized communities and E Evaluate planned and potential reuse projects through a quantitative sustainable design process to identify strategies for water reuse capacity building efforts expanding reuse across a diversity of contexts Outcomes This project rsquo s outputs include annual and final reports as well as national data on viruses and antimicrobial resistance hazards in sewage an Outbreak Readiness Response Plan for the reuse sector a Quantitative Microbial Risk Assessment tool case studies for potable and agricultural reuse and a demonstration of the relative health index tool for constituents of concern in reuse applications Additional outputs include deterministic algorithms for critical processes and constituents of concern an Integrated Water Reuse Treatment Plant Model interactive maps showing water reuse availability and potential case study and cross case comparison reports and a sustainability assessment framework applied to multiple water reuse scenarios These outputs will be integrated as best practices for community engagement strategies and institutional state and local regulatory decision making processes including a synthesis of identified barriers and drivers for reuse and a compendium of national and regional needs for organizational and social factors related to uptake of water reuse highlighting the needs of underserved communities Intended beneficiaries include a diverse group of stakeholders of utilities states tribes local communities and end users of water reuse systems especially in underserved communities Subrecipient University of Colorado Boulder ndash Overall total 1 942 982 1 335 508 federal 607 474 cost share costs include support for work related to wastewater epidemiology and developing predictive algorithms Southern Nevada Water Authority ndash Overall total 305 855 237 731 federal 68 124 Cost Share for support of wastewater based epidemiology and quantitative microbial risk assessment activities University of Washington ndash Overall total 198 798 193 798 federal plus 5 000 Cost Share work associated with wastewater based epidemiology Colorado School of Mines ndash Overall total 813 660 650 928 federal plus 162 732 Cost Share support for the operation of the mobile demonstration trailer for Online monitoring and control as risk mitigation techniques Water Center at UPenn ndash Total subaward 642 458 cost include support for facilitating twelve 12 regional workshops and for expert assistance with quantifying water availability

project_title: Developing Tools and Resources to Enable Economic, Institutional, and Technical Clarity in Support of Enhanced Aquifer Recharge Implementation
organization: Regents of the University of California, The
event_timeline:

- 2025-05-07: End date cut off from 2025-08-31 to 2025-05-07
- 2025-07-11: End date extended from 2025-05-07 to 2025-08-31
- 2025-09-11: End date extended from 2025-08-31 to 2027-08-31
project_description: Description This project will strategically combine applied research decision support innovations and public engagement to lower barriers to widespread adoption of enhanced aquifer recharge EAR and unlock its potential to provide multiple water security benefits Activities This project will develop a life cycle view of EAR to encompass three pillars of decision making geochemical and physical considerations legal and institutional considerations and cost benefit analysis and life cycle assessment The project will a generalize and contextualize cutting edge research contributions b produce a comprehensive picture of the life cycle of EAR implementation and c create actionable recommendations for practitioners and develop and formalize best practices for EAR Outcomes The deliverables of this project include annual and final reports as well as an EAR Lifecycle map that can be used as a tool for state and local decision makers contemplating EAR projects and as a repository from which key resources and tools can be found and evaluated Direct beneficiaries of this project will be water quality managers state and local decision makers and the general public especially in areas susceptible to drought Subrecipient The subaward to UC Davis 82 259 is for research and synthesis on geophysical elements and technical methods for EAR The subaward to UC Santa Cruz 254 912 is for research and synthesis on geophysical elements and technical methods for EAR as well as work on methods and considerations for managing water quality The subaward to UC Hastings 59 994 supports research on legal policy and institutional topics

project_title: Investigating the Distribution and Value of Water Quality benefits Along the Mississippi River
organization: Regents of the University of Minnesota
event_timeline:
- 2022-08-15: Grant awarded; Obligation of $742,000
- 2025-01-06: End date extended from 2025-08-31 to 2027-08-31
- 2025-05-12: End date cut off from 2027-08-31 to 2025-05-12
project_description: Description The goal of the proposed research is to develop a non market valuation survey administered to residents along the Mississippi River to evaluate how benefits vary across socioeconomic and geographic scales and populations of concern Research will evaluate tradeoffs between equity and efficiency with respect to water quality improvements and river restoration and will also explore how different methods lead to alternative policy conclusions resulting in better approaches tools for potential policy actions Overall the research will empower communities to advocate for their priorities and will lead to improved understanding of the benefits and distribution of water quality changes Activities Activities to be performed include a non market valuation survey administered to residents of the 246 counties and parishes that border or are adjacent to the Mississippi River The survey will ask respondents to report day and overnight trips to the River and will include a discrete choice referendum based on proposed changes in watershed restoration and management recreational cultural and or ecological values In addition to a ldquo push to web rdquo approach based on postcard mailers to a randomly selected address 8208 based sample potential survey participants will be identified via social media profiles and signage at river locations will direct visitors to an online survey Engagement with community organizations working on environmental  along the River will take the form of participatory workshops and co design of citizen science approaches that address community articulated priorities for restoration or management Outcomes Grant results include new methods of eliciting environmental values and insights into how different methods lead to alternative policy conclusions across equity and efficiency objectives In addition to peer reviewed papers and presentations the research will make contributions to benefit cost analyses and will inform the development of next generation integrated assessment models by testing the generalizability and scalability of new methods for valuation across spatial and demographic gradients Last the project will deliver beneficial outcomes to partner communities along the Mississippi River Intended beneficiaries include the public state and local environmental agencies regulators and partner communities along the Mississippi River Subrecipient University of Washington Lead PI Spencer Wood Team members from the University of Washington will Develop test and deploy approaches for using new technology and data sources to elicit information from communities within the study corridor Store and aggregate raw data to characterize populations Summarize findings in reports and publications Michigan State University Lead PI Dr Frank Lupi Team members from Michigan State University will Contribute to the design testing and implementation of water quality values using the survey data and available secondary data Advise o n and contribute to the economic modeling of water quality values using the survey data and available secondary data contribute to and co author project related publications

project_title: Valuing Water Quality Improvements in Nationwide Ecosystems: Total Value Based on the Biological Condition Gradient
organization: Univ of Wisconsin System-UN of WI-Madison dba Research & Sponsored Programs
event_timeline:
- 2022-08-26: Grant awarded; Obligation of $741,864
- 2025-03-24: End date extended from 2025-08-31 to 2027-01-31
- 2025-05-02: End date cut off from 2027-01-31 to 2025-05-02
project_description: Description The study seeks to provide insight on the extent of the market willingness to pay WTP and distance decay in representative watersheds within each of the nine ecoregions of the US The project also seeks to develop data and models to quantify a ldquo Biological Condition Gradient BCG rdquo in watersheds by using stated and revealed preference surveys across the country Biological index data from state tribal and local environmental agencies will be assembled to predict place specific baseline BCG scores and integrate these into the survey protocols Once completed the researchers will apply the benefit functions from surveys in a national Integrated Assessment Modeling IAM framework to consider the efficiency and distributional consequences of potential policy actions Activities The research will first expand the assessment of baseline biological condition gradient conditions to a nationwide scale which will allow the research team to adapt the survey instrument to measure and compare total values for major ecoregions across the country including regions that are underrepresented in the body of prior valuation research Second the team will supplement the stated preference estimates of total value with revealed preference recreation demand estimates Last the team will incorporate a nationwide BCG valuation module into their ongoing Integrated Assessment Model development work that aims to provide broadscale water quality valuation capabilities Outcomes The research will generate scientific knowledge and production of estimates that may contribute to cost benefit analyses and more efficient public policy Outputs from the project include a valuation framework to recover scientifically valid estimates of the economic benefits of surface water quality improvements at nationwide locations and an integrated assessment module to allow prediction of the total benefits environmental  consequences and other distributional features of specific water quality policies Deliverables include research papers conference presentations policy briefings and informal updates Intended beneficiaries include state tribal and local environmental agencies environmental economists and the public Subrecipient University of Minnesota PI Finlay and Researcher Dolph will be working on all objectives of the project PI Finlay will advise on the study design interpret for lay audiences and supervise the project Researcher Dolph will oversee assembly and compilation of datasets co supervise the UW PhD student conduct analyses assist in summarization for lay audiences and author peer reviewed research for publication Iowa State University Dr Ji will collaborate with the research team in the development and implementation of the proposed nationwide non market valuation survey especially the revealed preference part This includes such tasks as developing survey questions writing and implementing the online survey data analysis and writing research results University of Massachusetts PI Kaiser will contribute to the study design oversee efforts to use results from the studies to update an national integrated assessment model University of Tennessee PI Vossler will assist with the development and implementation of the proposal nation wide survey data analysis and writing the research results He will also aid with efforts to obtain IRB approval for human subjects research Cornell PI Kling will assist in survey design focus groups and survey implementation She will work with team members to provide needed linkages between the survey results and modules of the Integrated Assessment Model She is not requesting any funds from this project

project_title: Estimating the Missing Benefits of Water Quality by Nesting Recreation Demand and Hedonic Modeling
event_timeline:
- 2022-08-03: Grant awarded; Obligation of $741,054
- 2025-01-15: Program manager changed from Sheila Olmstead to Jr Deshazo
- 2025-03-13: End date extended from 2025-08-31 to 2027-08-31
- 2025-05-02: End date cut off from 2027-08-31 to 2025-05-02
project_description: Description This project focuses on developing models to determine the impacts of water quality changes on property values by studying three larger somewhat understudied bodies of water including Puget Sound Long Island Sound and the Texas Gulf Coast Activities The research team will implement a two stage econometric model of recreation and housing demand to evaluate the recreational and amenity value of water quality changes in the three regions The team will also compare estimates across waterbody types regions and socioeconomic characteristics of property owners and recreators Outcomes The team will produce regional water quality valuation estimates for three under studied regions at least three peer reviewed journal articles at least six scholarly presentations two doctoral dissertations and broad dissemination of results via policy oriented publications presentations and social media Beneficiaries include the public state and local regulators water quality program managers and communities surrounding Puget Sound Long Island Sound and the Texas Gulf Coast Subrecipient Subaward 1 University of Maryland Baltimore Country Activities will include collaborating with the other PIs to collect data on water quality recreation behavior and housing markets from four major US coastal areas estimating a two stage econometric model to quantify capitalization effects of both local and recreational water quality improvements in these regions preparing manuscripts detailing the research approach and results and presenting results to USEPA and at academic conferences Subaward 2 University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign Activities will include collecting data on water quality recreation activity and housing markets for four major U S coastal areas estimating a two stage econometric model to estimate the benefits of ambient water quality improvements preparing academic manuscripts and presenting results at academic conferences

project_title: Valuing Water Quality Improvements in Heartland Reservoirs
event_timeline:
- 2022-08-10: Grant awarded; Obligation of $740,014
- 2025-05-10: End date cut off from 2025-08-31 to 2025-05-10
project_description: Description The focus of this proposed project is to study willingness to pay WTP for water quality improvements in Midwestern reservoirs Researchers will be measuring linkages between water quality and provision of ecosystem services to inform potential scenarios and ecosystem attributes WTP will be measured by incorporating choice experiments to determine impacts of water quality restoration along with scenarios and accounting for ecosystem services bundling Lastly research will evaluate demographic and spatial characteristics that may inform the extent to which water quality changes impact WTP Activities Non market valuation techniques will be used to characterize the market extent The grantee will also incorporate ecosystem services modeling to inform plausible scenarios and ecosystem attributes in valuation questionnaires Finally the grantee will integrate demographic and spatial characteristics that may inform the extent to which water quality changes impact WTP Outcomes The expected outcome will be to forecast the realistic future of Midwest reservoirs This includes publications describing research results and willingness to pay estimates for water quality improvement In addition SWAT BATHTUB models for three reservoirs and their respective watershed areas will be made available Beneficiaries include the public state and local regulators water quality program managers and communities located close to the reservoirs to be studied Subrecipient Subaward to Kansas State University Co PIs Dr Trisha Moore and Dr Aleksey Sheshukov will be responsible for creation calibration and validation and generation of scenarios and results for a coupled watershed hydrology reservoir eutrophication model The model framework developed by Moore and Sheshukov will be applied to up to 3 study reservoirs

project_title: Analysis of Climate Change Related Chemical and Non-Chemical Stressor Exposures: Cumulative Health Impacts and Risk Trajectories in Vulnerable Ohio Census Tracts
event_timeline:

- 2023-06-28: Obligation of $604,249
- 2025-05-08: End date cut off from 2025-11-30 to 2025-05-08
project_description: Description The goal of this project is to analyze the impact of climate change related chemical and non chemical stressor exposures on personal health outcomes of residents living in underserved communities Specifically the project will assess the independent latent cumulative and interactive effects of climate change related environmental contaminants PM2 5 criteria air pollutants indoor air contaminants traffic related pollution combustion related contaminants and non chemical stressors from the built natural physical and social environments inherent personal characteristics activities and behaviors on the progression of disparate health outcomes Activities The project will compare the array of available data in broad categories of chemical and non chemical stressor exposures and four sources of de identified personal health data will be cross examined to places of residence in low income underserved and high income community cohorts for the years 2014 2020 The health outcomes investigated will include mental health substance abuse outpatient dialysis stroke respiratory disease heart disease diabetes obesity hypertension cancer kidney disease osteoporosis and adverse pregnancy outcomes The research will reveal important knowledge regarding which residents exhibit differential risk trajectories for disparate health and policy outcomes at the population level in response to climate change related chemical and non chemical stressor exposures from the built natural physical and social environment Outcomes Anticipated deliverables include annual and final reports scientific publications and communication documents to both community leaders and local public health policy professionals The expected outcomes are improved knowledge and understanding about the health risks threatening underserved communities in Ohio Intended beneficiaries include underserved communities in Ohio and other similar communities as well as community leaders and state and local public health officials Subrecipient MEHARRY MEDICAL COLLEGE 91 055 will provide the data curation for the project UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE 89 665 will lead the effort to design develop synthesize and implement novel combinatorial algorithms required for the analysis of highly heterogeneous data relevant to this project UNIVERSITY OF MISSISSIPPI 116 308 will provide expertise in the application of remote sensing and GIS techniques

project_title: Understanding Pediatric Susceptibility Across Temperature and Environment in New York

project_description: Description The goal of this research project is to identify community stressors and resilience enhancing assets that shape relationships between climate change related exposures heat ozone O3 fine particulate matter PM2 5 and child health Activities This project will 1 work with NY Pediatric Environmental Health Specialty Units PEHSU and community and government partners to prioritize stressors and assets 2 leverage complete patient level data on all child age 0 17 emergency department visits and hospitalizations in Upstate NY over 2005 2019 3 examine stressors identified by the NYS Department of Environmental Conservation Climate  Working Group and apply the Resilience Activation Framework which organizes assets in five domains human economic social political environmental capital 4 generate daily fine scale exposure estimates for heat O3 and PM2 5 and examine variation in exposure health relationships using case crossover methods and 5 apply climate projections to estimate impacts under varying emissions scenarios and with partners integrate findings into local and state climate adaptation and pediatric clinical initiatives Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports as well as indicators and maps of critical environmental stressors to provide public health agencies pediatric specialists community leaders and parents with evidence that tailored investments in environmental  communities today can alleviate current and future climate impacts on children s health Intended beneficiaries include parents and children in underserved communities in New York State and similar communities across the country Subrecipient University of Pittsburg 120 551 will support all aspects of data management and Geographic Information System GIS analysis for the project Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai 527 838 will provide local clinical expertise in child health outcomes environmental exposures and community assets input on use of NY Children s Health data and assist analysis of asset indicators and advise on the implementation of statistical analysis

project_description: Description The goal of the research is to examine relationships among basement indoor air quality air pathogens and contaminants basement moisture daily rainfall extremes housing and neighborhood conditions and cumulative health impacts for residents across the lifespan under the context of increased rainfalls and flooding due to climate changes Activities This research project will 1 Characterize bacterial and fungal pathogens and indoor air quality e g radon concentrations humidity in residential basements in two predominantly Black low income urban neighborhoods in Pittsburgh 2 Characterize respiratory and behavioral health conditions of residents exposed to microbial pathogens 3 Examine associations between basement pathogens and contaminants basement moisture daily rainfall extremes housing and neighborhood conditions and cumulative health impacts for residents across the lifespan and 4 Develop and disseminate community based solutions to address cumulative health impacts of pathogen contaminant exposure related to wet basements and heavy rainfall events Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports as well as critical scientific information for public health agencies indoor air specialists community leaders and housing authorities including potential evidence that housing and weather conditions and indoor air quality can have adverse health impacts due to climate changes Intended beneficiaries include residents in low income predominantly black underserved communities in the Pittsburg area and similar communities across the country Subrecipient Black Environmental Collective 45 000 will facilitate networking and collaboration with community members and organizations in the Homewood and Hill District neighborhoods The collaboration will enhance efforts to develop community based solutions to heavy rainfall events wet basements and related health challenges The University of Pittsburgh 464 575 will collect and analyze all environmental data in the project The Homewood Children rsquo s Village 160 000 will manage community engagement and support for participants of the leadership initiative

project_description: Description The goal of the project is to engage S E Queens residents in the measurements of key air pollutants NO2 O3 SO2 PM2 5 toxic metals and PFAS through community based participatory research CBPR increasing their understanding of climatic factors and air pollution impacts on health and empowering them to use such knowledge to inform policy on alleviating climate impacts and sustaining good health Activities The project will test the hypothesis that CBPR is a powerful driver in promoting air pollution reduction with the aim of protecting the health of S E Queens Residents and the environment The project will 1 demonstrate the impact of pollutant emissions from nearby waste stations on air quality in S E Queens through research field measurements 2 train residents to develop community science strategies such as crowdsourcing tools with new knowledge gained from the measurements enabling residents facing environmental in to mobilize new innovative low cost replicable strategies leading to the development of policy recommendations for better management of waste transfer stations and 3 translate the research data and community input into state and local climate and policy solutions for traffic emission reduction and relief from current health stressors improving quality of life Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final research reports as well as journal publications with critical data addressing urgent issues associated with urban minority and underserved communities that have never been investigated in New York City Expected outcomes include improved health and well being for residents living in low income urban minority communities Intended beneficiaries include health professionals state and local policy makers environmental managers and community leaders Subrecipient CUNY Medgar Evers College 245 629 will provide measurement monitoring of air pollutants including PM2 5 and PFAS Rutgers University 335 076 will 1 lead sampling efforts at three sites to determine toxic metals associated with PM2 5 2 participate in sampling preparation and analytical lab procedures 3 supervise a graduate student and 4 lead lab tour to promote community engagement

project_description: Description The goal of this research is to investigate the relationship between wildfire smoke exposure during pregnancy and the health of the newborn baby and mother as well as to provide education and other preventive solutions to underserved communities Activities The project will utilize an existing spatiotemporally resolved lower cost air monitoring network in Richmond CA and aggregate data from other networks across Contra Costa County for three aims 1 characterizing local disparities in exposure to air pollution heat and humidity and the impact of wildfires on exacerbating these disparities 2 assessing relationships between exposure and perinatal outcomes and 3 developing model community driven interventions and policies to reduce exposures and health impacts Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports as well as critical environmental information on the impacts of wildfire smoke on infant and maternal health communicated to public health agencies pediatric specialists community leaders and pregnant mothers Intended beneficiaries include mothers children and public health agencies in underserved communities in the State of California and similar communities across the country Subrecipient UC Berkeley 486 995 will assist with analysis cleaning and management for exposure data and will establish automated quality assurance for all sources of data

- 2023-07-07: Obligation of $659,990
- 2025-05-12: End date cut off from 2026-01-31 to 2025-05-12
project_description: Description The overarching goal of this research is to engage small communities that are reliant on small water supply systems and empower them to identify strategies that sustain water quality quantity and accessibility and provide resilient continuous access to potable water This project will provide an opportunity to better understand the challenges and problems climate variability and change pose to water distribution and quality that might impact public health through waterborne diseases Activities Meteorological observations will establish climate relationships important to pathogen exposure and provide information to understand high resolution climate change projections for microclimates Community engagement methods key informant interviews data collection of rainfall water quality and surveillance of waterborne pathogens will be conducted Results will be shared with water operators and stakeholders to determine community led science based solutions appropriate for each context to mitigate health impacts Observed factors like number served financial status accumulated rainfall water source water treatment and power source when used with high resolution climate change projections will provide holistic solutions for risk assessment and building resilience Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports as well as scientific information regarding water quality and quantity risk assessments for capacity building Expected outcomes include advancing the science and understanding of impacts of weather and climatic change on rural communities and microclimates Intended beneficiaries include residents and resource managers in Puerto Rico and other similar communities Subrecipient The Inter American University 490 660 will provide expertise on water sampling design community visits design of water quality related data collection and forms for self reported health data from community members and will conduct community visits and analyze data related to water quality and human health North Carolina State University 180 649 will provide expertise on climate related data collection and design this aspect of information collection and analyses This includes training community leaders and members to collect and report data on rain quantity and frequency temperature and other indicators

project_title: Septic to Sewer
organization: University of Maryland - Office of Research Adminstration
event_timeline:

- 2025-03-27: End date extended from 2025-08-31 to 2026-08-31
- 2025-05-12: End date cut off from 2026-08-31 to 2025-05-12
project_description: Description The goal of the project is to research and bring environmental  focused strategies to mitigate septic failures in coastal communities under the environmental conditions of rising sea levels and increased flooding Activities Researchers will 1 identify and partner with vulnerable underserved communities that are at risk of septic system failures now and in the future due to climate changes 2 address the antecedent conditions including historical settlement patterns and exclusion from municipal sewers that potentially exacerbate contaminant exposure by collecting primary data on septic health and the environment to develop composite risks and 3 evaluate where and how specific policy and technology solutions can address the compounded risks while ensuring that benefits accrue in a way that addresses past discriminatory practices Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final research reports as well as scientific publications educational information and solutions for public health agencies and community planners to prevent and mitigate septic failures in underserved coastal communities Expected outcomes are prevention of water contamination from septic failures and improved public health Intended beneficiaries include underserved coastal communities in Eastern Maryland state and local water resource managers and state and local public health agencies Subrecipient Resources for the Future 477 000 will measure the value of sewer as captured in property values and as measured by the preferences of local residents and community leaders George Mason University 226 000 will be responsible for the flood hazards modeling component of the proposed work including climate induced coastal flooding and sea level rise inundation Southeast Rural Community Assistance Project 117 705 will co produce research e g guiding research questions to ensure they are relevant support data sharing where appropriate administer a survey or support resident interviews support collection of water soil samples and support research outreach

project_title: Advancing Sanitation
event_timeline:
- 2022-07-25: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,350,000
- 2025-04-28: End date cut off from 2025-08-31 to 2025-04-28
project_description: Description The overarching goal of the proposed project is to advance the theory and practice of sanitation  equitable access agency and adaptive capacity for sanitation infrastructure amidst intensifying climate stressors for marginalized U S communities Activities The project will 1 compare sanitation related exposure to environmental contaminants for an urban and rural community 2 prioritize effects of climate change stressors on sanitation infrastructure and contaminant health impacts in underserved communities 3 design and evaluate improved sanitation infrastructure to reduce exposure while maximizing economic viability and community engagement Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final research reports as well as scientific information for community leaders and planners regarding demographics and contaminant exposure as well as open source datasets on sanitation quality and climate resilience Intended beneficiaries include public health agencies and residents of underserved communities Subrecipient Baylor College of Medicine 340 000 will lead Objective 1 and in particular Task 1 1 focused on parasite quantification Center for Rural Enterprise and Environmental CREEJ 340 000 will co lead Objectives 2 and 3 specifically the sanitation infrastructure survey Task 2 1 workshops focused on technology down selection Task 3 1 and pilot scale investigations Task 3 2

project_title: Development of a Community-Centered Tool for Assessing Health Impacts of Intersecting Climate Hazards, Wildfire Smoke Exposure, and Social Disparities in Rural Tribal and Aging Communities in Alaska
event_timeline:
- 2022-10-27: Grant awarded; Obligation of $690,000
- 2023-06-09: Obligation of $634,131
- 2025-05-13: End date cut off from 2025-10-31 to 2025-05-13
project_description: Description The goal of the project is to fill scientific data gaps that are essential for developing community centered tools to assess health impacts of wildfire smoke exposure climate change and social disparities in rural tribal and aging communities in Alaska Activities The project will 1 use a co development process that engages academic researchers state tribal wildfire management and public health entities and community partners to envision develop and test locally relevant and practical tools to access the state of the art climate and environmental data 2 model projections and information on health and social vulnerability in a useful and understandable way that allows communities to assess compounding climate hazards and social vulnerabilities 3 prioritize climate related health impacts and vulnerable demographic groups and 4 design effective interventions and apply to the tribal communities in Alaska Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final research reports as well as community based assessment tools for public agencies community leaders and planners and wildfire management specialists Expected outputs include 1 a statewide community driven spatially explicit web based tool in Alaska to assess the cumulative health impacts of climate change 2 an assessment of major contributing factors to vulnerability to wildfire smoke exposure from the perspective of tribal public health and wildfire management stakeholders 3 scenarios to showcase examples of community driven approaches to use the co developed tool including to assess vulnerability and guide responsive interventions and 4 an understanding of major challenges and facilitators for deployment of low cost air quality sensors in Alaskan communities Expected outcomes include improved health of the residents in tribal communities in Alaska Intended beneficiaries include tribal communities and public health officials in Alaska and other similar communities Subrecipient University of Washington 270 000 will assist with design and facilitation of workshops and summarizing key findings from each workshop UW collaborators will lead the development of the user guide and evaluation of the low cost sensor implementation Alaska Native Tribal Health Consortium ANTHC 45 000 will help recruit community partners participate in project team workshops and support and review the story based user guide to ensure that the final tool and guide are culturally appropriate and generalizable for the Alaskan communities they work with University of Alaska Fairbanks UAF 301 617 will assist with community partner recruitment design and facilitation of workshops and summarizing key findings from each workshop They will also take the lead on data management modeling and web design aspects of the project and will work with all project team members to make these data and model outputs fully accessible to the public They will be responsible for data curation quality control and storage and metadata creation

project_title: Advancing Community Resilience to Cumulative Climate Impacts in the Mystic River Watershed
event_timeline:
- 2022-11-02: Grant awarded; Obligation of $690,000
- 2023-06-22: Obligation of $659,151
- 2025-05-10: End date cut off from 2025-10-31 to 2025-05-10
project_description: Description The goal of the project is to build community level resilience against increased air and water pollution due to climate changes in underserved communities in the Mystic River watershed Activities The project will 1 use a novel multi stressor health impact assessment HIA framework to encode community insights into a high resolution geospatial database characterizing chemical exposures vulnerability and geographic sociodemographic co occurrence of hazards 2 develop impact models to highlight locations prone to cumulative climate risks and chemical exposures 3 use multi stressor epidemiological analyses to evaluate conjoint or cascading hazards to vulnerable people and neighborhoods and 4 apply the research findings to refine health risks and to inform state and local policies and investments to protect human health and the environment Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final research reports and scientific publications Outputs include a high resolution geospatial database and mapping tool that is readily responsive to community interests and concerns The tool will be used by public health professionals and community planners to prioritize operational and capital improvements needed to prevent and decrease chemical exposures and improve climate resilience among vulnerable people and neighborhoods over time Expected outcomes include improved human health of the residents in underserved communities in the Mystic River watershed Intended beneficiaries include communities in the Mystic River watershed as well as other similar communities across the nation as well as public health professionals and state and local resource managers Subrecipient Mystic River Watershed Association MyRWA 180 000 will partner with BU to develop and implement survey instruments in the community convene meetings of external stakeholders to assess community preferences provide contact with local decision makers to facilitate solutions oriented work and engage with advisory committee members to solicit feedback on grant progress

project_title: Partnering for Resilient Opportunities To Eliminate Cumulative Toxic  Health Effects from Wildfire
organization: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, SAN FRANCISCO, THE
event_timeline:
- 2022-11-17: Grant awarded; Obligation of $690,000
- 2023-06-15: Obligation of $640,536
- 2025-04-28: End date cut off from 2025-11-30 to 2025-04-28
- 2025-07-11: End date extended from 2025-04-28 to 2025-11-30
- 2025-10-01: End date extended from 2025-11-30 to 2026-11-30
project_description: Description The goal of the project is to understand the cascading impacts of recurrent and prolonged wildfire smoke exposure on health and well being of the residents in underserved communities in conjunction with other relevant environmental factors such as social adversity in low income minority communities in California Activities The project will 1 estimate the health effects of sub daily exposure to wildfire specific PM2 5 in California including across social vulnerability factors with particular focus on effects withincommunities 2 analyze community recovery from short term health effects following exposure 3 quantify indoor infiltration of wildfire smoke and the mitigating effect of housing quality and behaviors and 4 work with communities to develop mitigation interventions to fit the specific needs of the communities Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final research reports as well as scientific publications with more accurate estimates of wildfire specific PM2 5 distributions across communities and smoke infiltration data for housing across California Expected outcomes include the reduction of wildfire related PM exposure Intended beneficiaries include low income minority residents living in underserved communities across California public health professionals environmental managers air quality specialists and community planners Subrecipient University of California Berkeley 705 047 will 1 quantify wildfire specific fine particulate matter for fire seasons 2 estimate magnitude of effect by wildfire PM on health outcomes and 3 determine indoor penetration based on housing attributes data Central California Asthma Collaboration CCAC 60 000 will coordinate engagement efforts including recruiting stakeholders administrating surveys and conducting focus groups 23 100 to seven subawardees TBD to co develop and implement pilot adaptation strategies

project_title: Building Adaptive Capacity to Climate Change in Alaska Native Communities by Reducing Health Risks from Water Infrastructure, Quality, and Security
organization: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY
event_timeline:
- 2022-08-10: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,350,000
- 2025-05-10: End date cut off from 2025-08-31 to 2025-05-10
project_description: Description The goal of this project is to assess the relationships between diverse climate induced concerns related to water infrastructure and water quality and their effects on health in Alaska Native communities The project aims to build capacity against climate change risks by addressing water infrastructure issues in Alaska Native communities Activities The project will 1 conduct community based monitoring CBM and direct sampling to assess water quality 2 gather surveys and interviews and photovoice submissions to capture water insecurity and local vulnerabilities 3 assess the cumulative effects of water quality water insecurity and local vulnerabilities on health mental health and non Western perspective of health using statistical analyses and fuzzy set qualitative comparative analysis and 4 build resilient water infrastructure capacity Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final research reports as well as 1 hydraulic models of the water distribution system and open source data driven algorithms and codes for leak detection and localization 2 maps of the most vulnerable households at risk of water quality and insecurity and 3 comprehensive models showing the factors that are the most significant in determining health mental health and non Western health outcomes Expected outcomes are resilient water infrastructures and improved health in Alaska Native communities Direct beneficiaries include tribal communities as well as state and local public health and environmental resource managers in Alaska Subrecipient University of Texas 303 681 will identify technology and techniques for reducing climate based risks to water infrastructure identified in Task 1 1 Water Infrastructure and Task 3 1 Build Adaptive Capacity of Water Infrastructure

project_title: The Duwamish Valley Research Coordination Network: Building Capacity for Tribal, Community, and Agency Research on Contaminants in Urban Watersheds
event_timeline:
- 2022-11-09: Grant awarded; Obligation of $690,000
- 2023-06-22: Obligation of $577,559
- 2025-05-10: End date cut off from 2025-10-31 to 2025-05-10
project_description: Description The goal of this project is to identify and expand community water and soil testing programs by integrating historical data with local knowledge and the community goals and assets and facilitate decision making for targeting future work including community visioning for storm water management in the face of climate change Activities The project will build capacity within the underserved tribal communities in Duwamish Valley so they may have ownership over environmental testing and cleanup process that truly support community needs The project will 1 ensure that the project will meet the needs of the communities by thorough surveys interviews and sharing of previously collected data 2 determine the extent and degree of contamination at the site as well as the research guidance and reports that will be most useful to community leaders 3 monitor soil water and sediment contaminants PAH PCB metals dioxin furans throughout the watershed during storm water surges to identify and map high risk areas and 4 inform communities of viable solutions to build resilience and capacity against migration of water contaminants Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final research reports as well as database and publications for making sound evidence based decisions on mitigating water contaminants exacerbated by climate change Expected outcomes include improved health for the tribal communities and residents in Duwamish Valley Intended beneficiaries include community decision makers public health professionals environmental cleanup managers community planners and tribal leaders in the Duwamish Valley and other similar communities Subrecipient Duwamish River Cleanup Coalition 32 000 will convene community science workshops and ensure the community needs are prioritized and centered Environmental Coalition of South Seattle ECOSS 15 000 ndash As a community based organization they will assist in convening community science workshops throughout the project

project_title: Early Life Vulnerability to Climate-driven Wildfire Events on Pregnancy and Child Developmental Health Outcomes in Underserved Populations
event_timeline:

- 2025-03-13: End date extended from 2025-08-31 to 2026-08-31
- 2025-04-23: End date cut off from 2026-08-31 to 2025-04-23
- 2025-07-11: End date extended from 2025-04-23 to 2026-08-31
project_description: Description The goal of the project is to identify which populations are most impacted by wildfire associated air pollution exposures and determine whether these exposures increase risk for adverse birth and child neurodevelopmental outcomes Activities This project will 1 build a comprehensive database to understand the distribution of wildfire related air pollution in California across a range of family neighborhood and community factors that could indicate increased vulnerability 2 examine perinatal wildfire exposures in association with birth outcomes including gestational age and weight at birth 3 link exposures to California Department of Developmental Services data to evaluate associations with diagnoses of autism and developmental delays and 4 evaluate exposure windows exposure mixtures and compounding vulnerability factors associated with higher risk Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final research reports as well as scientific information and publications to educate and train air quality managers public health professionals pediatric specialists parents clinicians and community leaders on identifying the most vulnerable groups for wildfire related pollutants and reducing their exposure Expected outcomes include a reduction in harmful exposure to wildfire related air pollutants and improved health of vulnerable residents Intended beneficiaries include state and local air quality managers public health specialists pediatricians community leaders and young children and other vulnerable residents in underserved communities throughout California Subrecipient UCLA 100 001 will evaluate exposure windows exposure mixtures and compounding vulnerability factors associated with higher risk It will train members of vulnerable communities to lead educational activities on building low cost and effective Corsi Rosenthal Air Filter Boxes and other ways to mitigate exposures

project_title: Leveraging Community Knowledge to Understand and Map the Health Impacts of Cumulative Environmental Exposures and Social Vulnerability in the Context of Climate Change
event_timeline:
- 2022-08-03: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,349,998
- 2025-05-09: End date cut off from 2025-08-31 to 2025-05-09
project_description: Description The goal of the project is to understand the cumulative health impacts of chemical and non chemical exposures exacerbated by climate change among the most vulnerable communities in Atlanta and to develop suitable intervention programs to reduce exposures Activities This project will 1 create an index and map at the neighborhood level focused on the cumulative chemical and non chemical exposure of individuals in Atlanta and how their health is adversely impacted by elevated air pollution due to climate change 2 seek to understand how highly susceptible individuals with chronic disease perceive and manage the effects of chemical non chemical and climate related factors on their mental health asthma and obesity sensitive conditions and 3 facilitate community led education initiatives and interventions to empower the community and increase resilience against climate change and its health effects Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final research reports peer reviewed journal publications and scientific reports as well as educational materials and policy recommendations for state and local public health agencies environmental managers health professionals and community planners and leaders Expected outcomes include a reduction of harmful pollutant exposures and a general improvement in environmental health among residents with preexisting health conditions in the Atlanta area Intended beneficiaries include state and local public health agencies environmental managers health professionals community leaders and vulnerable subpopulations in the Atlanta area Subrecipient Subaward to ECO Action 455 773 for leading community engagement activities as listed in the community engagement plan Subaward to Spelman College 134 408 to provide the preliminary data on cumulative environmental vulnerability analysis needed for objective 1 In addition Spelman will lead the community level environmental hazard data collection using the Proctor Creek Citizen Science App

project_title: Leveraging a Public School District and Schoolyard Spaces to Confront Climate Health Inequities in a Low-Income, Urban Community of Color
