project_description: Description The goal of the project is to leverage the Milwaukee Public Schools district personnel and facilities to build community resilience against adverse impacts of climate change on air pollution levels and reduce environmental health inequities in Milwaukee and other communities Activities The project will 1 engage Milwaukee Public School students staff and families in a climate change and health curriculum and dialogue focused on the health impacts of global climate change and how students staff and families can support implementation of the Milwaukee Climate and Equity Plan in order to safeguard community health and 2 quantify the impact of MPS schoolyard greening as an effective community based solution to mitigate climate impacts on heat exposure air pollution educational engagement and achievement and mental emotional health and well being Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final research reports as well as an evidence based curriculum to support teachers in teaching climate health equity in K 12 schools and scientific evidence of the impact of schoolyard greening on climate health among low income urban minority children Expected outcomes include improved health and well being of low income urban minority school age children and environmental equity in Milwaukee area and other underserved communities Direct beneficiaries are teachers and students in Milwaukee public schools public health professionals and state and local environmental managers Subrecipient Milwaukee Public Schools 435 000 will review and implement the climate  resolution curriculum with teachers across grade levels and content areas MPS will provide professional development for teachers provide teachers with coaching on the climate  curriculum and support teachers in the classroom on using the curriculum and resources effectively

program: Office of Research and Development Consolidated Research
project_title: Development of a Wastewater Hierarchical Sentinel Site Identification for Future Pandemic Surveillance Systems
organization: Board of Trustees University of Illinois - Urbana-Champaign
event_timeline:
- 2022-07-27: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,000,000
- 2025-04-29: End date cut off from 2025-08-31 to 2025-04-29
project_description: Description Future pandemics will require that wastewater surveillance for potentially harmful pathogens such as SARS CoV 2 the virus that causes COVID 19 be deployed quickly and effectively and with results that can be applied locally The purpose of this project is to develop a hierarchical wastewater surveillance sentinel site identification system for detection of pathogens that could cause future pandemics Activities The research team will identify wastewater sentinel sites using data driven predictions of infection risk levels at various spatial resolutions based on an integrated analysis of data including weather human mobility health care infrastructure population density sociodemographics and data from the current COVID 19 pandemic Outcomes The recipient will submit annual and final reports on their efforts to develop a hierarchical wastewater sentinel site identification system The expected outcome is that wastewater sentinel sites would be identified hierarchically from the county level the city town village level and ideally to building level depending on pathogen transmission characteristics Direct beneficiaries of this project will be public health departments across the U S and the general public Subrecipient Funds are requested for a total of 124 902 99 996 requested plus 24 906 cost share for a subaward to the University of Florida to develop a risk forecasting map In addition 124 681 99 631 requested plus 25 050 cost share is requested for a subaward to Portland State University to analyze traffic networks and incorporate the data and analysis into the risk forecasting model In addition 70 000 is budgeted for a subaward to the National Association of County and City Health Officials NACCHO to develop a strategy to verify the sampling method developed by the grantee and to contribute in the development of the computational platform

project_title: Culinary Home Empowerment for Food Waste Prevention and Minimization (CHEF-WPM)
event_timeline:
- 2023-03-24: Grant awarded; Obligation of $739,381
- 2025-05-13: End date cut off from 2026-03-31 to 2025-05-13
project_description: Description The proposed research investigates a highly innovative and scalable approach to strengthen consumers rsquo motivation opportunity and ability to reduce food waste by adapting professional culinary education interventions to the home kitchen Activities The project will develop and evaluate the effectiveness of a series of innovative food waste prevention and minimization culinary education videos and supplementary materials for home cooks The videos will be developed by nationally renowned food preparers and food waste educators in collaboration with Drexel Food Lab The community based education session with 100 selected households will be comprised of 8 educational culinary videos designed to empower consumers by providing the motivation knowledge and skills to reduce household food waste throughout the process including meal planning shopping consuming storing and disposing The project will measure the impacts of educational materials on food waste reduction at household and community levels and test national scalability and applicability Outcomes The deliverables include peer reviewed scientific research publications communication and education materials and multi media video training materials to educate and motivate communities and individuals to reduce household consumer food waste The expected outcomes would be meaningful reduction in food waste through consumer behavior changes involved in food shopping preparation consumption and post consumption disposal The intended beneficiaries are the households and communities in Philadelphia area and other regions and public in the United States Subrecipient Johns Hopkins University 76 386 will provide expertise in evaluation design and will also act as a scientific advisor

project_title: Preventing Consumer Food Waste: Developing and Evaluating Household-Level Interventions
organization: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHAPEL HILL
event_timeline:
- 2023-03-21: Grant awarded; Obligation of $732,045
- 2025-05-09: End date cut off from 2026-03-31 to 2025-05-09
project_description: Description This project aims to evaluate a set of household food waste prevention interventions researchers have developed with local health food and environmental organizations in North Carolina Activities The project will enroll 200 low income households in the Raleigh NC area to implement an intervention that is based on each household rsquo s root causes of food waste It aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention by measuring the impacts on avoidable food waste grams household week food waste prevention behaviors psychosocial drivers of food waste and food security The project will also simulate the impact of the interventions on environmental outcomes e g greenhouse gas emissions blue water withdrawal land use and energy use and cost effectiveness for national scale application Outcomes The deliverables include peer reviewed scientific publications communication materials and education training materials to help communities and individuals to prevent and reduce household consumer food waste Outputs include an intervention toolkit for households estimates of environmental impact and cost effectiveness dissemination materials and at least three scientific publications Outcomes will include widespread dissemination of intervention materials resulting in extensive reduction in household food waste nationally The intended beneficiaries are individual consumers and communities in the state of North Carolina and other regions in the United States Subrecipient RTI International 149 979 will provide scientific guidance and expertise for designing and implementing the research methods as a research partner

project_title: Quantification and Modeling of Perchlorate Impacts from Fireworks on Drinking Water Sources
event_timeline:
- 2023-04-28: Grant awarded; Obligation of $2,499,579
- 2025-05-02: End date cut off from 2026-04-30 to 2025-05-02
project_description: Description This project aims to evaluate the relative impacts of perchlorate from fireworks on surface drinking water sources and groundwater drinking sources across the US by measuring perchlorate at six sites two rivers three lakes and a groundwater site during July 4th events as well as periodic firework displays from baseball stadiums on the two rivers selected Seven specific objectives will be addressed through a combination of field and laboratory studies combined with modeling efforts to fill critical knowledge gaps Activities Drinking water sources in the watersheds will be evaluated before and after major periods of fireworks and during subsequent rain events In addition to measuring the perchlorate inputs due to runoff or infiltration the research will also measure the direct deposition into water bodies Aerial deposition will be measured by limited direct air and deposition sampling at some sites To expand the reach of the study additional samples will be requested from CASTNET and NADP two existing sampling networks and the project will also include nation wide surveys of public water supply intakes before and after periods of fireworks All chemical physical and biological observations from the six sites will be integrated into a widely applied watershed model Soil and Water Assessment Tool SWAT which will expand the tool rsquo s ability to assess the impact of firework driven perchlorate emissions Outcomes Anticipated deliverables include new information and data on 1 concentrations masses attenuation rates of perchlorate from fireworks use in diverse surface waters as well as relative contributions from commercial displays and public use and direct inputs and indirect from runoff 2 deposition rates aerial extents and local and regional impacts of perchlorate deposition 3 the relationship between density of fireworks use mass or cost population and resultant residual perchlorate that enters the environment 4 the biological attenuation rate as a function of the characteristics of water sources and 5 the impact of fireworks use on groundwater resources Additional outputs include refined and calibrated models to evaluate perchlorate input and fate in surface water resources a national survey of the impact of perchlorate in drinking water sources identification of key predictive variables to predict perchlorate impact and development of a screening tool to evaluate impacts Potential beneficiaries of this program include drinking water utilities as well as state and local governments and communities whose drinking water is affected by pollution from the use of fireworks Subrecipient Penn State University 620 000 Subaward for 1 sampling of the Pittsburgh location and 2 model development and validation Objectives 5 6 and 7 Georgia State University 174 165 Subaward for 1 sampling the Atlanta location and 2 model development Objectives 1 5 and 6 University of California Berkley 375 098 Subaward for 1 sampling the Lake Tahoe location and 2 studies on perchlorate reduction University of Delaware 319 999 Subaward for 1 sampling the Massachusetts location and 2 stable isotope analyses Objectives 4 and 5 University of Nevada Las Vegas 329 985 Subaward for 1 sampling the Las Vegas location and 2 studies on Air Deposition Citizen Scientist Lake Survey Lake Modeling Objectives 1 2 and 6

project_title: FLEETS for All: Facilitating Local Electrified Energy and Transportation Services for All
event_timeline:
- 2023-06-05: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,120,313
- 2025-05-12: End date cut off from 2026-06-30 to 2025-05-12
project_description: Description The goal is to address air pollution and subsequent health impacts while considering the challenges for energy mobility accessibility and equitability in fifteen underserved communities in the Columbus Metropolitan Area CMA Activities The project will 1 partner with underserved communities in the CMA to understand their needs for electrification and mobility and evaluate the effectiveness of current efforts 2 develop strategies to guide transition investment and deployment to improve health environmental and social conditions over time for the CMA communities across the urban exurban rural gradient and 3 understand how knowledge perception and values vary and design and evaluate informational interventions that inform individual and domicile level decisions Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final research reports Other expected deliverables include community assessments and toolkits to support local and regional decision makers on transitions to electrified energy and mobility and electricity and mobility infrastructure planning white papers and presentations Expected outcomes are tested informational interventions for use in helping marginalized communities understand the decisions facing their households during electrified energy and mobility transitions Direct beneficiaries of this project include underserved communities in the Columbus Metropolitan Area as well as researchers working with similar communities to address air quality public health and cost concerns associated with electrified energy and transportation services Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

project_title: Environmental  Impacts Across The Life Cycle Of Energy Storage
event_timeline:
- 2023-06-22: Grant awarded; Obligation of $649,492
- 2025-05-02: End date cut off from 2027-06-30 to 2025-05-02
project_description: Description The purpose of this project is to inform how energy transitions can be improved to be more attentive to environmental  and community concerns by improving the understanding of the environmental  impacts throughout the life cycle of renewable energy storage infrastructures and activities from a community engaged perspective Activities The objective of the research is to understand how renewable energy transitions can occur in ways that maximize potential positive impacts and minimize potential negative impacts on underserved communities Outcomes Deliverables will include annual and final reports The anticipated outputs include recommendations for just and sustainable renewable energy storage presentations for a variety of forums e g academic conferences public agencies and series of entries for the Environmental  Atlas and other community engaged research products The project is expected to inform how renewable energy transitions can occur in ways that maximize potential positive impacts and minimize potential negative impacts on underserved communities as well as strengthen community capacity and build working relationships that will continue beyond the life of the project Direct beneficiaries of this program include communities in the western U S affected by activities or infrastructure associated with renewable energy storage such as mineral extraction activities battery manufacturing and assembly utility scale energy storage and battery recycling Subrecipient The subaward to University of Nevada Reno will be for 117 168 They will be working on community engaged case study research and contributing to research implementation and sharing results The subaward to San Jose State University will be for 98 140 They will be working on community engaged case study research and contributing to research implementation and sharing results The subaward to Cal Poly Pomona will be for 115 000 They will be working on community engaged case study research and contributing to research implementation and sharing results

project_description: Description The goal is to understand the role of statewide Local Energy Action Networks LEANs in supporting and advancing renewable energy and energy efficiency REE in underserved communities with community engaged state and local pilot projects focusing on indigenous rural and low income communities Activities The project will 1 identify and compare barriers opportunities decision drivers of renewable energy and energy efficiency REE adoption for individuals community and government of underserved communities 2 examine benefits challenges and effectiveness of statewide local energy action networks LEANs in supporting REE adoption in underserved communities and 3 examine the role of targeted interventions capacity education ownership in advancing REE awareness engagement and adoption in underserved communities Outcomes Anticipated deliverables include community co created research instruments and research products including reports communities effective methods for engagement and co production of knowledge with communities best practices for state networks and state policy program design to support local sustainable energy adoption Additional outcomes include increased adoption and diffusion of sustainable energy in underserved communities as well as improved risk management for underserved communities in climate and energy resilience Intended beneficiaries include ten underserved indigenous low income and or rural Maine communities as well as similar communities in other states Subrecipient Subawardee Penobscot Nation PN Tribal Government will have a Sustainable Energy Coordinator to serve all Wabanaki tribes build capacity and accelerate implementation of local energy solutions oversee project development
