project_title: Deliberative Valuation and Integrated Modeling to Accelerate Equitable Decarbonization in New England
organization: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
event_timeline:
- 2023-06-27: Grant awarded; Obligation of $649,328
- 2025-05-13: End date cut off from 2026-07-31 to 2025-05-13
project_description: Description The purpose of this project is to accelerate decarbonization of the electrical grid by delivering information and tools that empower community based environmental organizations to identify and advocate for renewable energy projects that are consistent with community values Activities The project will synthesize existing modeling tools into an integrated wrapper that can screen alternative decarbonization scenarios in terms of the various ecological environmental and health outcomes of interests Researchers will recruit rural and urban community members into deliberative workshops in order to quantify the relative importance of competing attributes and identify the information that is most influential in the formation of attitudes The research team will also incorporate quantitative and qualitative information into cost benefit analyses which will be performed on renewable energy projects under consideration for New England Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final research reports Other expected deliverables and outcomes include 1 increased capacity for community organizations to generate independent characterizations of renewable energy products 2 increased credibility of available information 3 increased capacity for community organizations to identify and advocate for projects and 4 enhanced cost benefit analysis tools that can explicitly value public preference regarding competing attributes for alternative renewable energy scenarios Direct beneficiaries of this project include New England communities in rural low income environments most affected by renewables transmission and or generation infrastructure human health and the environment Subrecipient The subaward to Clean Energy NH will be for 33 038 They will support their provision of input on scenario development survey instruments and characterizations of impacts and benefits of renewable energy projects under consideration in Year 3 The subaward to Dartmouth College will be for 114 055 They will support co mentorship of the postdoc and analysis of data collected The subaward to UMass Boston will be for 224 961 They will support deliberative valuation study design graduate student recruitment and workshop administration

project_title: Environmental  implications of public transit electrification and changing generation portfolios in Arizona
event_timeline:
- 2023-08-04: Grant awarded; Obligation of $649,998
- 2025-04-23: End date cut off from 2026-09-30 to 2025-04-23
project_description: Description The goal of this project is to develop a framework for evaluating changes in neighborhood air pollution distributions arising from alternative future scenarios for public transportation and electricity generation utilizing an atmospheric pollution dispersion modeling to estimate public transportation and electricity generation impacts on air pollution concentrations Activities Specific objectives are to 1 quantify the existing disparities in air pollution exposure to public transportation and electricity generation in Maricopa County 2 collect data on planned public transit interventions for decarbonization of the transportation fleet in Maricopa County 3 evaluate air quality and environmental  impacts of future public transit scenarios and 4 develop a visualization tool of proposed planned infrastructure for stakeholders and communities Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports Other expected deliverables include a database of pollution concentrations due to existing electricity generation and public transit infrastructure in underserved communities an inventory of planned public transit developments and community survey about potential programs and interventions with associated emissions in Maricopa County and a database of pollution exposure and environmental  status at the Census Block Group level Expected outcomes include increased knowledge that the project rsquo s stakeholders can incorporate in their future energy transition decisions and help cities identify which planned electrification and transportation policies can reduce environmental disparities in underserved communities Direct beneficiaries of this project include the residents of Maricopa County in Arizona human health and the environment and the general public Subrecipient 314 618 is budgeted to Unlimited Potential They will provide input to develop a framework for analyzing proposed transportation infrastructure projects create community focus groups to understand the local perceptions of air quality and preferences over certain programs to reduce air pollution and coordinate community outreach activities to disseminate the results

project_title: Community-Engaged Co-Design for a Just and Sustainable Energy Transition
event_timeline:
- 2023-07-25: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,111,418
- 2025-05-10: End date cut off from 2027-08-31 to 2025-05-10
project_description: Description The goal of this research is to understand how social and institutional factors drive individual and household electrification decisions in underserved communities and how these factors affect environmental co benefits of energy efficient electrification Activities The project will use community based participatory research CBPR approach and integrate ethnographic and behavioral economic methods with engineering analysis and air quality testing to 1 to understand how low and moderate income LMI households and neighborhoods in an environmental  community experience and envision the 21st century energy transition and identify community priorities 2 develop a robust community based research platform for designing scalable solutions to the challenge of energy efficient electrification of aging housing infrastructure and 3 work with local housing partners to implement and test community co designed interventions and prototypes to assess their efficacy in addressing household priorities including indoor air quality comfort and cost Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final research reports as well as co designed scalable adaptable solutions for household electrification Expected outcomes include increased knowledge regarding the drivers barriers and environmental co benefits of household electrification in underserved communities Direct beneficiaries of this project include low and moderate income LMI households in Massachusetts as well as researchers working with similar communities to study drivers and impacts of household electrification Subrecipient Subawardee Northeastern University will oversee the co design and implementation of a series of participatory causal loop diagramming CLD workshops to inform and facilitate stakeholder led input to identify barriers to just energy transition towards decarbonization train facilitators for the workshops co design and supervise the execution of participatory CLD sessions to draw a systems representation of the current energy systems and co design and supervise debriefing sessions to identify barriers to just transitions and identify opportunities for intervention The requested amount is 50 314 Subawardee Neighbor to Neighbor will do resident recruitment host group sessions and assist in planning workshops meetings and a community forum The requested amount is 199 720

project_title: Community Health and Air Quality Implications of Refinery Retrofits and Retirements
organization: The Regents of the University of CA - Los Angeles
event_timeline:
- 2023-05-01: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,125,000
- 2025-04-23: End date cut off from 2026-05-31 to 2025-04-23
- 2025-07-11: End date extended from 2025-04-23 to 2026-05-31
project_description: Description This project will leverage the natural experiment afforded by a recent oil refinery closure in northern CA state of the science air quality modeling and a unique dataset of ambient air pollution monitoring data to quantify the impacts of refinery emissions on local air quality and community health and compare present conditions to alternate scenarios of refinery retirement and biofuel conversion Activities Specifically the project will 1 utilize the 2020 closure of the Marathon oil refinery in Martinez California as a natural experiment to quantify the impacts of oil refining on rates of preterm birth emergency room visits and hospitalizations 2 model the air quality health and economic impacts of retiring the four operational oil refineries in the San Francisco Bay Area and compare them to alternative scenarios of retrofit to biofuel production and 3 engage community members and advocates in study design and results dissemination and the development of a web based interactive tool to inform petroleum refinery conversion or retirement Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final research reports Other expected deliverables include journal publications documenting research findings on link between health and air quality impacts of oil refinery operations Expected outcomes include improved understanding of the aggregate air quality and health benefits of retiring or retrofitting multiple petroleum refineries in a disproportionately impacted region Direct beneficiaries of this project include the residents living near oil refineries in the San Francisco Bay area as well as researchers working with similar communities to address air quality degradation and public health concerns associated with oil refining for energy production Subrecipient Subawardee University of California Berkeley will be involved in the development and implementation of the study design as well as in the data analysis interpretation and dissemination of study results The requested amount is 196 558 Subawardee PSE Energy will be involved in air quality modeling health impact assessment and development of an online refinery retirement and retrofit data visualization tool The requested amount is 390 000 Subawardee Asian Pacific Environmental Network will support the project by providing advice to the study team assisting in results translation and dissemination and participating in and coordinating regular community advisory committee meetings The requested amount is 200 440

project_title: Drivers of Energy Service Transitions and Impacts on Well-Being in Forest Dependent Rural Communities
event_timeline:
- 2023-06-09: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,124,999
- 2025-05-12: End date cut off from 2027-06-30 to 2025-05-12
project_description: Description The goal is to analyze impacts of current energy systems and pathways for energy transitions that enhance well being through improved public health economic opportunity and energy  outcomes with a focus on underserved communities including a Tribal Nation and rural communities in a forest dependent region in northern Michigan Activities The project will 1 quantify the impacts of wood paper plastics and tire derived fuels WPPT energy generation in terms of economic well being at the household and community scale and of air quality affecting human health 2 evaluate the impacts and potential transition drivers associated with local use of fuelwood along with improved ventilation and energy efficiency options and 3 assess the potential decarbonization of the electric power sector to provide economic benefits and secure access to energy services in ways that enhance the manufacturing sector as well as community and household well being in terms of air quality public health and energy  Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final research reports Other expected deliverables include reports and journal publications documenting results of the research Expected outcomes include improved understanding of 1 the air quality impacts of WPPT energy production for underserved communities 2 impacts of current energy services provision on indoor air quality and potential drivers to increase energy efficiency and use of wood products in ways that do not have negative public health impacts and 3 potential drivers of a transition in forest product use that can support just energy services access as well as economic well being for households communities and industries that enhance employment opportunities in underserved communities Direct beneficiaries of this project include rural communities and Tribal Nations in forest dependent areas in the Great Lakes region as researchers working with similar communities to address environmental concerns associated with large scale changes in the energy systems Subrecipient Subawardee Center for Energy and Environment will contribute to protocol development in all aspects of indoor air quality research and residential energy audit and energy assessments 135 000

project_title: Renewable Energy, Environmental , and Public Wellbeing (RENEW) - Evaluating Biogas Transformation in Eastern NC
event_timeline:
- 2023-05-31: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,124,999
- 2025-05-09: End date cut off from 2027-06-30 to 2025-05-09
project_description: Description The goal of the project is to characterize the environmental public health economic and environmental impacts of a large scale swine waste to energy SWE operation in eastern North Carolina Activities The project will 1 use stakeholder surveys interviews and economic analyses to quantitatively and qualitatively assess risk perceptions and social economic andconsiderations related to SWE 2 collect air private well water and surface water samples before and during construction and after completion of a planned SWE operation 3 spatiotemporally evaluate impacts of SWE operations on air and water quality of adjacent communities and compare SWE with other alternative energy sources and 4 use the findings to facilitate multisectoral dialogue and educational activities related to SWE Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final research reports as well as an easy to use interactive tool designed to help community stakeholders consider how SWE operations affect climate air quality and other environmental goals Expected outcomes include environmental social and economic findings that will be of interest to communities withconcerns as well as environmental health practitioners and decision makers Direct beneficiaries of this project include residents in Sampson and Duplin counties in eastern North Carolina decision makers concerned about the impacts of swine waste to energy SWE operations and the general public Subrecipient Subawardee Environmental  Community Action Network EJCAN will assist in the community sampling efforts establish an EJCAN community laboratory for analysis of water samples and coordinate community led stakeholder workshops The requested amount is 233 410 Subawardee University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill UNC will be involved in conducting the analysis of community and other stakeholders risk perceptions and assist with site selection and data analysis of environmental monitoring data The requested amount is 299 839

project_title: Evaluating the Environmental, Behavioral, and Financial Benefits of Electrification and Energy Efficiency for Underserved Communities
organization: Board of Trustees University of Illinois - Urbana-Champaign
event_timeline:
- 2023-07-05: Grant awarded; Obligation of $991,796
- 2025-01-07: Other amendment
- 2025-05-12: End date cut off from 2026-06-30 to 2025-05-12
project_description: Description The purpose of this project is to develop an energy  model for freight vehicle electrification in an urban environmental  community that is responsive to community needs while advancing science in air quality public health socioeconomic organizational and institutional factors that play a role in assessing benefits and costs of transitioning into freight vehicle electrification Activities The specific objectives are 1 analyze the sociotechnical regime in which a transition to electrified freight vehicles will occur 2 evaluate potential scenarios for such a transition in terms of their reduction in air emissions and 3 determine the health benefits of such a transition for a community that is heavily impacted by freight vehicle traffic Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final research reports Other expected deliverables include a community Air Monitoring and Exposure Assessment Plan AMEAP community air monitoring guidance materials for low cost sensors a data repository that contains a variety of environmental and traffic data collected by the project a holistic environmental impact analysis tool kit and an online mapping tool for community stakeholders Expected outcomes are improved ability to predict the potential public health and air quality risk tradeoffs in underserved communities due to the freight electrification related energy transitions and enhanced socioeconomic cultural and behavioral insights that can inform future electrification scenarios Direct beneficiaries of this project include the residents of the Little Village neighborhood in southwest Chicago and similar communities situated near freight rails as well as researchers working with similar communities to address environmental concerns associated with large scale changes in energy and transportation systems Subrecipient Subawardee University of Illinois Chicago will lead the work on baseline exposure assessment electrification scenario analysis of emission modeling air dispersion modeling and exposure and health impacts assessment University of Illinois Chicago will also be involved in recruiting community participants mobile sensor training and baseline air monitoring data collection

project_title: Evaluating the Environmental, Behavioral, and Financial Benefits of Electrification and Energy Efficiency for Underserved Communities
event_timeline:
- 2023-07-05: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,124,959
- 2023-09-08: Other amendment
- 2024-12-04: Other amendment
- 2025-05-02: End date cut off from 2026-06-30 to 2025-05-02
project_description: Description The goals of this project are to 1 investigate how electrifying and weatherizing homes reduces energy usage while providing energy security ameliorating the indoor air quality of residential dwellings and improving comfort and productivity of occupants and 2 identify the barriers to adopting electrification and weatherization in low income homes Activities The project will focus on the tri state ten county area of Greater Cincinnati and will 1 analyze the effects of combined electrification and energy efficiency and energy efficiency alone on household energy consumption security and behavior in low income multifamily dwelling units 2 estimate the benefits of electrification and energy efficiency technologies on indoor air pollution emissions in low income multifamily dwelling units and 3 evaluate the factors that drive and inhibit household municipal and regional decisions about whether to adopt electrification and energy efficient technologies respectively and to do so specifically for underserved populations Outcomes Deliverables include annual progress and final reports as well as journal publications documenting the research findings The expected outcomes include extensive socioeconomic and behavioral insights that can be used to understand and advance the diffusion of low carbon and efficient technologies among low income households Direct beneficiaries include multifamily home residents in underserved communities in Cincinnati OH local governments and the general public Subrecipient Subawardee Indiana University 278 190 will lead the design implementation and analysis of the household surveys and energy diaries Subawardee Carnegie Mellon University CMU 129 674 will lead the analysis of the energy efficiency benefits of electrification and weatherization CMU will also lead the analysis of air quality changes after electrification Subawardee Over the Rhine Community Housing OTRCH 466 800 will support the project by leading the building and unit selection as well as tenant recruitment and ongoing engagement efforts OTRCH will also conduct the procurement process to secure contractors to complete building interventions and oversee the execution of the work

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: Implementation of Cost-Effective Techniques for the Monitoring & Reduction of Indoor Air Pollutant Exposures in Classroom Environments through a Service-Learning Framework
event_timeline:
- 2023-04-27: Grant awarded; Obligation of $24,131
- 2024-05-22: End date extended from 2024-07-31 to 2025-07-31
- 2025-04-23: End date cut off from 2025-07-31 to 2025-04-23
project_description: Description The purpose of this project is to monitor indoor concentrations of particulate matter volatile organic compounds VOCs carbon dioxide CO2 ozone O3 and airborne pathogens in a classroom setting utilizing inexpensive cloud based air quality sensors This project also aims to design and introduce a non invasive indoor air pollutant solution to mitigate exposure Activities The specific objectives are to 1 examine exposure to indoor air pollutants employing cost effective approaches for observation in real time 2 evaluate classroom pollutant data to record pollution source and loss processes 3 employ a viable engineering design process to develop a cost effective mitigation strategy based on portable air filtration technology 4 compare air filtered by the newly developed strategies with unfiltered air to compile multipollutant datasets and 5 implement new service learning opportunities for students to learn Outcomes Deliverables of this project include a final report and the development of a cost efficient framework for indoor air pollutant monitoring and mitigation using modular portable air filtration devices Direct beneficiaries of this project include Lafayette Indiana school faculty and students human health the environment and the general public Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: MINTS: Multi-scale Intelligent Sensing
organization: The University of Texas at Dallas
event_timeline:
- 2023-05-23: Grant awarded; Obligation of $24,999
- 2024-07-25: End date extended from 2024-07-31 to 2025-07-31
- 2025-05-07: End date cut off from 2025-07-31 to 2025-05-07
project_description: Description The purpose of this project is to build a network of low cost calibrated air quality sensors that can be distributed at scale and used sustainably across predominant Black and Brown Dallas Fort Worth neighborhoods The network of low cost sensors will be related to real time remote sensing observations from the geostationary GOES R satellite that will provide scientifically valid information for data driven decisions by communities and residents Activities The goals of this project are to 1 Calibrate each individual low cost sensor by co location using real time machine learning to link and continuously calibrate a network of sensors 2 Partnering with Paul Quinn College and Downwinders at Risk to identify most urgent locations for sensors 3 Develop and deploy inexpensive solar powered sensors that can communicate using Long Range Wireless Area Network and 4 Disseminate data in an open source platform to the West Dallas communities Outcomes Deliverables will include a final report and develop an open sensor design and open source paradigm for using machine learning for the calibration of both low cost sensors and remote sensing satellite observations from NOAA GOES R so that they can readily and sustainably be deployed across communities and provide scientifically useful and societally beneficial monitoring Direct beneficiaries include state and local environmental regulators state and local governments local community groups the Dallas Fort Worth area and the general public Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: Physicochemical Degradation of Microplastics
event_timeline:
- 2023-05-03: Grant awarded; Obligation of $25,000
- 2024-07-24: End date extended from 2024-07-31 to 2025-07-31
- 2025-04-23: End date cut off from 2025-07-31 to 2025-04-23
project_description: Description The purpose of the project is to measure the release of microplastics from synthetic textiles during washing and examine the nanoscale degradation mechanisms under simulated environmental exposure that microplastics encounter upon release to natural water bodies Activities The specific objectives of the project are to investigate the release of microplastics from synthetic textiles observe mechanistic breakdown of the released plastics under environmentally related conditions and quantify nanoscale degradation using a quartz crystal microbalance Outcomes Deliverables will include a final report as well as documenting the findings of release pattern of microplastics during washing degradation behavior under visible light and hydrolysis in the aquatic environment and mass change during degradation at the nanoscale level Direct beneficiaries of the program include state and local governments wastewater treatment plant personnel human health the environment and the general public Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: Enhanced Detection and Removal of GenX from Water Supplies
event_timeline:
- 2023-05-10: Grant awarded; Obligation of $25,000
- 2024-07-29: End date extended from 2024-07-31 to 2025-07-31
- 2025-05-10: End date cut off from 2025-07-31 to 2025-05-10
project_description: Description The purpose of this project is to develop a more effective and sustainable method for detection and removal of GenX from water Activities The activities performed will address decreased sensitivity of GenX detection due to background levels in sample blanks and effective disposal of waste produced by the cleansing of anion exchange resins used in the removal of GenX at wastewater treatment plants The recipient will perform the following activities 1 Treat water used in LC MS MS blank samples using photocatalytic degradation to remove any background contaminants that would decrease instrument sensitivity 2 Treat the waste product obtained from cleansing of anion exchange resins using photocatalytic degradation and 3 Assess the success of removal using LC MS MS to detect changes in levels of GenX pre and post treatment for both the blank samples and waste products Outcomes Deliverables will include a final report documenting the effectiveness of photocatalytic degradation treatment in reducing levels of GenX in blank samples and waste products Direct beneficiaries of this project include wastewater treatment plant operators researchers contaminated site managers human health and the environment and the general public Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: Urban Water Pollution Extent and Impact on the Village Creek in Birmingham, AL - Analysis and Mitigation Strategies
event_timeline:
- 2023-05-04: Grant awarded; Obligation of $25,000
- 2024-06-14: End date extended from 2024-07-31 to 2025-07-31
- 2025-05-09: End date cut off from 2025-07-31 to 2025-05-09
project_description: Description The purpose of the project is to analyze the movement of pollutants around the Village Creek River study the vulnerability of the communities living along the river and in the flood risk zones and promote the inclusion of Low Impact Developments and green infrastructure to mitigate the issue Activities The specific objectives are to 1 provide a platform for the public to access information regarding the pollutant exposure and high risk areas in an easily understandable format and 2 propose modified mitigation strategies such as floating gardens pollution absorbing rain gardens and bioswales in the impacted communities Outcomes Deliverables will include a final report along with a vulnerability hazard map that will identify the communities at risk of exposure to pollutants an informative website providing information regarding the type of pollutants in the area and modified Low Impact Developments and Green Infrastructure design Direct beneficiaries of this program include community members near the Village Creek River city planners human health and the environment Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: Three-Way Removal of Per- and Polyfluoroalkyl Substances from High-Strength Landfill Leachate Utilizing Simultaneous Foaming and Humic Acid Precipitation During pH Adjustment
event_timeline:
- 2023-05-23: Grant awarded; Obligation of $24,982
- 2024-08-22: End date extended from 2024-07-31 to 2025-07-31
- 2024-11-04: Other amendment
- 2025-04-25: End date cut off from 2025-07-31 to 2025-04-25
- 2025-07-07: End date extended from 2025-04-25 to 2025-07-31
project_description: Description Landfill leachate is one of the major sources of per and polyfluoroalkyl substances PFAS to the environment The objectives of this project are to i evaluate the effect of simple pH adjustment on PFAS removal due to humic acid precipitation and foaming at low pH ii evaluate the performance of a membrane electrochemical reactor to remove PFAS in precipitated humic acid and foam at low pH in the anode chamber and iii evaluate preliminary treatments of coalesced foam humic acids and the remaining fraction of leachate for PFAS destruction Activities The student team will develop quantitative data of reagent and energy requirements and treatment performance for the proposed technologies A complete understanding of the effect of PFAS chemical properties e g headgroups chain length the extent of fluorination on the separation and removal during treatment will be developed The mechanistic understanding of the impact of chemical properties on removal will help researchers develop proper treatments for PFAS compounds based on their properties The team will also identify the effective conditions for thermal treatment of PFAS containing humic acid Outcomes The project expects to produce a complete understanding of the treatment mechanisms and chemical properties of PFAS within landfill leachates to improve environmental health Specifically the results will include a comparison of the treatment performance among high strength leachate foam and defoamed leachate in the GAC UV Sulfite process a complete mass balance of PFAS species in the treatment system and an understanding of the byproducts formed during destructive treatments i e thermal MER UV ARP Direct beneficiaries of this work include communities impacted by PFAS contamination landfill and waste management officials and state and local water resource managers Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: Modelling Outdoor Comfort with UAV-based Digitization Technique and a Comfort Tracking System for Underserved Communities.
event_timeline:
- 2023-05-10: Grant awarded; Obligation of $25,000
- 2024-06-18: End date extended from 2024-07-31 to 2025-07-31
- 2025-05-09: End date cut off from 2025-07-31 to 2025-05-09
current_fiscal_year_outlays: No outlays reported in this fiscal year
project_description: Description The purpose of this project is to create a tracking system that combines heat and air pollution effects at the near surface or localized microclimatic conditions to measure a comfort index value within vulnerable communities Activities To create a comfort index the project will 1 deploy drone mapping of the built environment in selected neighborhoods most at risk from air pollutants and high temperatures 2 use modeling tools to simulate the urban micro climate including heat and air pollution for real time simulation of conditions that individuals experience and 3 engage community members to monitor pollution data using small pollution monitoring devices that travel through the selected neighborhoods Outcomes Deliverables will include a final report as well as a better understanding of the near surface impact of increased temperature and air pollution on the health of the city of Birmingham Alabama Direct beneficiaries include the community members of Birmingham urban planners and designers and state and local government Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: Natural Approach in Antifouling Protection: Remedy for Safer Water for Fisherman, Boaters, and Cargo Ships
event_timeline:
- 2023-05-08: Grant awarded; Obligation of $24,958
- 2024-07-29: End date extended from 2024-07-31 to 2025-03-31; Program manager changed from Victoria Volkis to Joseph Pitula
- 2025-03-17: End date extended from 2025-03-31 to 2025-09-30
- 2025-05-13: End date cut off from 2025-09-30 to 2025-05-13
project_description: Description The purpose of the project is to demonstrate the efficacy of natural extracts formulations in antifouling protection using a custom model aquarium which will contribute to the environmental health of marine environments by reducing the transmission of biofilm generating bacteria by boats and ships beyond their natural habitat to areas where it is invasive and causes uncontrolled algae bloom and contributes to fish and crab mortality Activities The specific objectives are to 1 build pilot aquariums for long term testing of new antifouling formulations on different types of submerged surfaces 2 demonstrate the effectiveness and conduct a pilot study of the concept of use of natural extracts encapsulated into biocompatible polymers for antifouling protection of submerged surfaces and 3 evaluate in long term experiments how water type and parameters as well as type of plant materials polymers and solvents influence the ability of the coating to protect against biofouling Outcomes Deliverables will include a final report as well as improve human well being by avoiding contamination of marine environments from products of biofouling and invasive bacteria and help to avoid uncontrolled algae blooms Direct beneficiaries include rural fishermen small farmers recreational boaters human health the environment and the general public Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

project_title: Integrated Portable Raman and Electrochemical NanoSystem (I-PRENS) for Neonicotinoid Detection and Remediation in Rural Drinking Water Supplies
event_timeline:
- 2023-06-14: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,362,435
- 2025-05-08: End date cut off from 2026-07-31 to 2025-05-08
project_description: Description The purpose of the project is to develop a portable Raman and electrochemical nanosystem I PRENS to be deployed for onsite detection and degradation of neonicotinoid pesticides in rural drinking water supplies in Alabama s Black Belt region Activities The project will apply the best available nanotechnology enabled sensing and treatment technologies into a field deployable prototype designed for long term monitoring and chemical supply free remediation of neonicotinoid impacted drinking water supplies The specific objectives are to 1 develop a hot spot normalized surface enhanced Raman spectroscopic HSN SERS sensing module for real time quantification of neonicotinoids 2 develop a nanobiochar enabled pre treatment module for neonicotinoid pre concentration 3 develop a sensor controlled catalytic advanced oxidation process AOP module for neonicotinoid degradation and 4 develop and deploy a small scale I PRENS prototype in rural Alabama Outcomes Deliverables will include annual and final reports documenting the progress toward developing the technology and results from field deployment Direct beneficiaries include the rural Alabama community communities that depend on pesticide impacted drinking water supplies private community well owners researchers and the general public Subrecipient Subaward of 490 241 to Yale University will support the development of a sensor controlled catalytic advanced oxidation process AOP module for neonicotinoid degradation Subaward of 379 206 to Auburn University will support the development of a nanobiochar enabled pre treatment module for neonicotinoid pre concentration and the deployment of a prototype

program: Office of Research and Development Consolidated Research
project_title: Winning the Race Against Competing Risks: Optimizing Drinking Water Disinfection to Minimize Opportunistic Pathogen & DBP Risks
event_timeline:
- 2023-07-19: Grant awarded; Obligation of $2,123,000
- 2024-08-22: Project description changed; Obligation of $127,000
- 2025-05-12: End date cut off from 2026-07-31 to 2025-05-12
project_description: Description The goal of this project is to better understand and predict occurrence of disinfection byproducts opportunistic pathogens and the associated health risk tradeoffs posed by them in drinking water distribution systems DWDS across the continental U S Activities This project will develop a strategic monitoring program through partnership with public health departments and water utility managers and analysis of historic data to sample water for regulated and unregulated disinfection byproducts DBPs and pathogens The research will also conduct a chemical and quantitative microbial risk assessment and evaluation of risk risk tradeoffs considering temporal spatial and population dynamics Outcomes Deliverables include publications risk models and data to inform decision support tools This project will also host workshops and online communications to engage stakeholders as well as develop toolkit for communications outreach The outcome of this work will enable movement away from routine monitoring for these hazards towards tools for more comprehensive water system evaluation risk based and prioritized monitoring strategies based on drinking water distribution system characteristics and the biological chemical and physical parameters most likely to lead to elevated risks Intended Beneficiaries of this project include residents of New York state and local government agencies water utility managers and site managers and operators Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: Office of Research and Development Consolidated Research
project_title: Innovations in Sampling, (Bio)analytical Chemistry, and Analytics to Characterize Disinfectant Use Tradeoffs in U.S. Water Systems for Minimizing Exposure to Opportunistic Pathogens and DBPs
organization: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA
event_timeline:
- 2023-07-10: Grant awarded; Obligation of $2,122,997
- 2023-08-11: Other amendment
- 2024-08-20: Project description changed; Obligation of $166,302
- 2025-05-12: End date cut off from 2026-07-31 to 2025-05-12
project_description: Description This application proposes a highly innovative project to assess the tradeoffs between opportunistic pathogens OPs and disinfection by products DBPs and develop strategies for limiting exposure to both classes of water contaminants via U S drinking water distribution systems Activities This project will quantify and assess OPs regulated DBPs and unregulated DBPs Outcomes Deliverables include annual progress and final reports peer reviewed publications and conference presentations Direct beneficiaries include water utilities and communities served by water distribution systems throughout the U S Subrecipient Towson University 31 865 EPA will perform DBP analyses Johns Hopkins 57 827 EPA will perform non target DBP analysis and toxicity testing University of Alaska Fairbanks 37 634 EPA will perform data analytics and modeling

program: Office of Research and Development Consolidated Research
project_title: Integrated Water Microbiome and Disinfection Byproducts Monitoring and Management to Advance Drinking Water Quality
event_timeline:
- 2023-06-28: Grant awarded; Obligation of $2,123,000
- 2024-07-25: Project description changed; Obligation of $114,169
- 2025-05-09: End date cut off from 2026-07-31 to 2025-05-09
project_description: Description The overall goals of this project are to develop an integrated framework to quantitatively monitor the drinking water microbiome including waterborne pathogens WPs and disinfection byproducts DBPs and holistically manage WP and DBP risks in drinking water storage and distribution systems DWSDSs using inclusive and actionable risk metrics Activities This goal of an integrated framework will be realized through two research objectives 1 enacting comprehensive spatial temporal monitoring and characterization of water chemistry and microbiology of multiple full scale DWSDSs in different regions of the country and 2 formulating an integrated and actionable risk assessment and management framework to mitigate WP and DBP risks and identify the underlying trade offs to optimize drinking water quality in DWSDSs Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports as well as a unique dataset that concurrently quantifies WPs and regulated and unregulated DBPs in a diverse range of DWSDSs and puts this data in rich context with a thorough characterization of water chemistry and microbiology Additionally they will develop an integrated framework to quantitatively monitor the drinking water microbiome including WPs and DBPs They will also develop a risk management toolkit publications and conferences to disseminate their findings The intended beneficiaries include water utility managers and communities who get their water from public drinking water distribution systems Subrecipient The Water Tower Institute TWTI 10 000 federal plus 3 200 cost share 13 200 total will serve on the project as the utility liaison for the team TWTI plans to provide support for quality assurance quality control data management sampling and shipping logistics Northeastern University 35 000 federal plus 7 000 42 000 total will conduct niche sampling with utility partner in Massachusetts

program: Office of Research and Development Consolidated Research
project_title: Co-DOWN: Consortium on Disinfection By-Products and Opportunistic Pathogens in Water Networks
event_timeline:
- 2023-07-19: Grant awarded; Obligation of $2,123,000
- 2024-07-25: Project description changed; Obligation of $99,997
- 2025-05-07: End date cut off from 2026-07-31 to 2025-05-07
project_description: Description This project aims to achieve a nationwide study of the prevalence of opportunistic pathogens their free living amoebae vectors and regulated and unregulated disinfection byproducts across a wide variety of sizes and types of drinking water distribution systems DWDS Activities Multi tiered partnerships across approximately 100 drinking water distribution systems will be developed to achieve the objectives including educational components that will be used to provide direct application of the research to other utilities Utility partners will assist with performing one sampling event per year from 5 10 locations in their drinking water distribution systems Outcomes Deliverables of this project include annual progress and final reports a survey of the pathogens and vectors in the sampled water systems mitigation strategies and learning modules The project will also develop a risk framework and a plan to communicate risks as well as guidance for a modified system flushing program Intended beneficiaries include drinking water utilities and consumers whose drinking water comes from public drinking water distribution systems Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

project_title: LID Surface Water-Groundwater Interaction Study
event_timeline:
- 2023-07-06: Grant awarded; Obligation of $2,000,000
- 2024-11-19: End date extended from 2026-07-31 to 2027-07-31
- 2025-04-25: End date cut off from 2027-07-31 to 2025-04-25
project_description: Description The objective of this project aims to research the effectiveness of stormwater best management practices BMPs used for Enhanced Aquifer Recharge EAR to better understand the quantity and quality of urban stormwater recharging groundwater supplies Activities The project will examine the impact of lateral exfiltration of stormwater runoff coupled with vadose zone stratification and the impact of lateral flow on pollutant transport into groundwater The project will perform the following activities a monitor flow paths and characterize soil characteristics to evaluate infiltration rates b using highest flow pathways identify critical sampling locations of pollutant transport and assess human health risk and c calibrate the OpenHydroQual model by inputting field monitoring data Outcomes The deliverables of this project will be a free and open source modeling tool for evaluation of performance of EAR BMPs in addition to annual and final reports Engineers planners and other users will be able to input parameters of their specific BMP systems and be able to assess the long term performance of BMPs used for EAR including identifying any risks of pollutant hazard risks to groundwater The intended beneficiaries are water resource managers communities dependent on groundwater supply LA county water users and the general public Subrecipient Southern California Coastal Water Research Project 275 539 will serve as the lead of water quality investigation will conduct a survey of bioretention type BMP practices across LAC to identify and catalog design and maintenance conditions preventing or promoting effective operation of the BMP in terms of physical ability to capture runoff Catholic University of America 235 450 will commit infrastructure support and a variety of resources and Dr Arash Massoudieh will serve as the modeling lead for the project Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory 1 074 011 will serve as geophysical investigation lead for the project

project_title: Protecting Water Quality during Enhanced Aquifer Recharge
event_timeline:
- 2023-09-06: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,250,000
- 2024-07-19: Obligation of $595,583
- 2025-05-13: End date cut off from 2026-09-30 to 2025-05-13
- 2025-07-14: End date extended from 2025-05-13 to 2026-09-30
project_description: Description The purpose of this project is to develop a geochemical compatibility framework for enhanced aquifer recharge EAR suitability assessments that evaluates contaminant metals salts pesticides mobilization from source waters Activities The specific objectives are 1 to evaluate the quantity and quality of excess surface water and wastewater discharge that is available for recharge 2 to assess geochemical surface and hydrogeologic conditions for recharge suitability 3 to calculate contaminant risk scores based on spatial data modeling tools and potential shifts in geochemistry during enhanced recharge and 4 to determine regional site suitability for enhanced recharge using a combination of source water availability aquifer hydrogeology and contaminant mobilization risks Outcomes Deliverables of this project include a final technical report framework guidance for enhanced aquifer recharge operations and an interactive web based mapping tool for recharge suitability sites Intended beneficiaries of this project include water regulating officials the general public and human health and the environment Subrecipient University of California Davis 316 845 will lead research Task 1 Assessment of various source waters which is focused on evaluating the quantity and quality of excess surface water stormwater floodwater and wastewater discharges available for recharge in the watersheds overlying key regional aquifers across the United States US Dr Dahlke rsquo s lab will also contribute to research Task 2 Assessment of ambient aquifer conditions which focuses on assessing ambient geochemical conditions relevant surface conditions e g agrochemical use and hydrogeologic suitability of key regional aquifers across the US University of Texas Austin rsquo s 309 000 Dr Bridget R Scanlon will lead the evaluation of ambient aquifer conditions for the proposal This work will leverage the research she previously led for the U S Geological Survey USGS under the Powell Research program relating aquifer status to GRACE satellite data focusing on spatiotemporal variability in water storage Ground Water Protection Council 171 099 will be to manage the communications and engagement processes in three key areas 1 Provide Guidance Document and dashboard publication assistance 2 Provide three facilitated communication opportunities via online seminar and or face to face meetings with the targeted community to introduce project and gather feedback on design and content provide an opportunity to allow for feedback on the development of the dashboard tool and provide for opportunities to disseminate the results of the research and communicate availability and use of the dashboard tool 3 Provide public access to the Guidance Document dashboard tool data and reference information developed for this project online via the GWPC ASR MAR Workgroup rsquo s Online Library

project_title: Development of Innovative Monitoring and Analysis Strategies for Rural Enhanced Aquifer Recharge Structures
event_timeline:
- 2023-07-18: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,250,000
- 2024-06-13: Obligation of $741,613
- 2025-05-02: End date cut off from 2026-07-31 to 2025-05-02
project_description: Description This project aims to evaluate several methods of modification of rural basins to enhance recharge while monitoring the efficacy of each approach Activities In partnership with the local stakeholders and the site owner City of Ada OK this project will employ microbiological geochemical sedimentological groundwater gas monitoring geophysical and groundwater modeling tools to test the effectiveness and impacts of rural EAR structures to determine if these structures can be deployed as part of rural land management strategies to safely increase groundwater supplies in fractured and karstic aquifers Outcomes Deliverables include a guidance document for the siting and assessment of rural EAR as well as a literature review and monitoring tools developed to manage recharge pulses through fractured and karstic aquifers and guidance on monitoring biogeochemical changes The outcomes include providing land and water managers the ability to safely and economically implement rural EAR The beneficiaries include residents of Oklahoma whose water supply comes from Arbuckle Simpson Aquifer local and tribal government industrial and agricultural users the aquatic environment of connected streams and the general public Subrecipient Texas State University 443 592 will contribute to the Groundwater Model and Gas Transport Development Task E including travel to research sites and project meetings East Central University Oka Institute 294 482 will contribute to the Collaboration and Engagement Plan host the stakeholder meetings and manage the marketing and educational product development

project_title: Risk and Performance Evaluation of Enhanced Aquifer Recharge in the Coastal Plain
organization: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
event_timeline:
- 2023-07-31: Grant awarded; Obligation of $2,000,000
- 2025-05-13: End date cut off from 2026-07-31 to 2025-05-13
project_description: Description The objective of this project is to develop a web based decision support tool to guide communities agencies and practitioners in the implementation of EAR in deep confined aquifers Activities Four experiments are proposed combined with model development and application to address multiple research objectives Experiments are designed to reveal relationships between the outcomes of several risk factors and to promote synergies in the research findings Outcomes The web based decision support tool will be designed to advance best practices and assist users in a careful evaluation of risk and performance factors to ensure EAR projects are effective sustainable and protective of groundwater resources Intended beneficiaries include water quality managers and residents of the East Coast Subrecipient Old Dominion University 356 731 will actively participate in data collection and sample analysis conducted at the PARML laboratory and are responsible for contributing to project deliverables ODU researchers will participate in regularly scheduled meetings remotely

project_title: Next-Generation Landfill Monitoring: A Multi-Scale Approach to Measuring Emissions for Evaluating and Financing Interventions
organization: Regents of the University of California, The
event_timeline:
- 2023-10-16: Grant awarded; Obligation of $437,500
- 2024-12-16: Obligation of $562,500
- 2025-04-29: End date cut off from 2026-10-31 to 2025-04-29
- 2025-07-11: End date extended from 2025-04-29 to 2026-10-31
project_description: Description The goal of the project is to develop and demonstrate an integrated multi scale and multi sensor approach that will allow landfills to more effectively monitor emissions at lower cost and be used to quantify the emissions impact of interventions Activities The project will 1 test the hypothesis that continuous air monitoring of municipal solid waste landfills is feasible and cost effective through an integrated multi scale approach e g coordinated observations with multiple sensors deployed on flux chambers Unmanned Aerial Vehicles UAVs aircrafts and satellites and 2 explore how this approach can establish the efficacy of interventions and create financial incentives to reduce emissions by serving as the basis for robust landfill emissions reduction quantification protocols Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final research reports Other expected deliverables include a dataset of emissions at targeted landfill facilities protocols for field measurements as well as more robust offset protocols that will enable and encourage greater use of interventions to reduce landfill air emissions and a multi sensing multi temporal dataset that will quantify the impact of weather climate landfill conditions and management practices Expected outcomes include 1 improved approaches for monitoring and quantifying emissions of methane and other gasses from landfills 2 increased data to inform the development of landfill emissions models and emissions inventories 3 reduction of methane and HAPs emissions through mitigation strategies e g diversion and composting programs and waste management practices 4 improved ability to quantify methane and co pollutants 5 better understanding of factors that affect landfill emissions that will inform strategies to reduce emissions and 6 mitigation of HAPs and methane emissions from landfills in and near neighboring communities Direct beneficiaries of this project include residents affected by hazardous air pollutants emitted from landfills being studies in Yolo County CA Alameda County CA and City of Midland MI as well the general public human health and the environment Subrecipient Carbon Mapper 111 979 will coordinate sensing using satellite based approach and work with the research team on sensing technologies comparison and integration PSE Healthy Energy 68 000 will perform hazardous air pollutant HAP testing from gas samples to supplement field sensing GTI Energy 55 000 will work with the research team to create formal and equitable protocols for methane emissions especially for disadvantaged communities and the influence on methane model prediction results

project_title: Analysis of Continuous Monitoring Data with Inverse Atmospheric Models to Improve Landfill Gas Emissions Data and Elucidate Drivers of Emissions
event_timeline:
- 2023-06-21: Grant awarded; Obligation of $998,049
- 2025-05-08: End date cut off from 2026-08-31 to 2025-05-08
project_description: Description The purpose of this project is to demonstrate and standardize existing inverse modeling and spatial mapping methods for identifying hotspots of methane and other health impacting gases released from landfills and to monitor and quantify these emissions Activities The specific objectives are 1 deploy high sensitivity laser based sensors to measure methane at strategic locations for two full years at downwind locations of four landfills in the United States 2 deploy sensors to measure landfill gas releases that impact local air quality including ammonia hydrogen sulfide and odors for two full years at the same sites as the methane sensors 3 collect complementary data on carbon dioxide ammonia and hydrogen sulfide with the laser based methane sensor to demonstrate the application of the methods to other landfill gases 4 use parallel drone based mapping methods to map methane concentrations above and around landfills to identify hot spots and identify the location of fugitive emissions and 5 apply the monitoring data in an inverse atmospheric transport model to quantify landfill emissions and for calculating the impact from environmental variables and landfill operations on emissions Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final research reports The anticipated outputs include advancements in methods for monitoring landfill gas emissions advancements in drone based approaches for identifying hot spots and processes that lead to high emissions and identification of factors that affect landfill emissions and effectiveness of mitigation strategies to reduce emissions Direct beneficiaries of this program include residents affected by hazardous air pollutants emitted from landfills the general public and human health and the environment Subrecipient St Louis University 199 701 will complete the drone measurements and the meteorological analyses that will be used in the project St Louis University will also conduct the inverse modeling analysis data analysis and the preparation of report publications and presentations cover the project results and findings

project_title: Evaluation and Control of Emissions from MSW Landfills: Direct Measurement and Modeling
event_timeline:
- 2023-09-08: Grant awarded; Obligation of $450,000
- 2025-02-05: Obligation of $549,831
- 2025-05-02: End date cut off from 2026-08-31 to 2025-05-02
- 2025-07-14: End date extended from 2025-05-02 to 2026-08-31
project_description: Description The goal of the project is to evaluate the accuracy of new emissions estimation methodologies for emissions of methane and hazardous air pollutants from landfills and provide guidance on their use when calculating annual emissions Activities The project will 1 determine how the eddy covariance method and tracer correlation method can capture effects of atmospheric conditions and landfill cover type on emissions 2 use atmospheric modeling to assess the accuracy of existing and emerging methods including fixed point automated drone and flux curtain measurements for measuring landfill methane emissions 3 use Bayesian inversion with Weather Research and Forecasting output to obtain whole landfill methane emission estimates from satellite data 4 evaluate the utility of automated gas well control to reduce landfill gas emissions and 5 examine variability in landfill emissions under future climate conditions Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final research reports Other expected deliverables include datasets of landfill emissions Expected outcomes are improved estimates of landfill emissions and evaluations of the utility of landfill cover design and automated control of gas collection to reduce emissions Direct beneficiaries of this project include residents affected by hazardous air pollutants emitted from landfills being studies in Yolo County CA and Turkey Run GA as well the general public who are affected by methane s contribution to climate change Subrecipient The subaward to University of California Davis will be for 235 615 They will lead and coordinate all Yolo County Central Landfill field activities including collecting primary and secondary data from gas collection sampling and testing standard surface emission sampling placement of eddy covariance towers and fixed point sensors tracer correlation method measurements operation of remote controlled drones for aerial gas measurements and operation of the automated landfill gas collection system The subaward to University of California Berkely will be for 510 075 They lead and conduct all activities related to atmospheric dispersion modeling including the configuring and running the Weather and Research Forecasting WRF model evaluation of model outputs and estimating emissions uncertainty

project_title: Integrating Measurements Across Platforms to Feasibly Assess Emissions and Mitigation of Methane and VOCs from Landfills
organization: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO
event_timeline:
- 2023-08-15: Grant awarded; Obligation of $542,935
- 2025-01-07: Obligation of $457,065
- 2025-04-30: End date cut off from 2026-08-31 to 2025-04-30
project_description: Description The overarching goal is to assess the performance and feasibility tradeoffs of integrating measurements across measurement platforms to assess emissions and mitigation of methane and volatile organic compounds VOCs from landfills Activities The project will 1 assess the uncertainty in landfill methane emissions at a representative set of three landfills using a combination of ground based aircraft and satellite tools 2 develop methane emissions data for three different landfills from interannual down to an hourly temporal resolution and use it to improve methane emissions models 3 develop a landfill VOC emissions data set that can be used to estimate speciated emissions based on waste and environmental parameters 4 assess inexpensive ground based systems to routinely monitor VOCs and 5 assess the ability of various measurement systems to observe the performance of real world emissions mitigations Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final research reports Other expected deliverables include datasets of temporally and spatially resolved methane and VOC species concentrations spanning 0 5 1 5 years for three landfills as well datasets of methane and VOC species Expected outcomes include advancements in approaches of quantifying landfill emissions and improved understanding of factors that affect emissions Direct beneficiaries of this project include residents affected by hazardous air pollutants emitted from landfills to be studies as well the general public who are affected by methane s contribution to climate change Subrecipient The subaward to Fort Lewis will be for 50 000 They will be involved in the design fabrication and application of dynamic flux chambers for use in measurement landfill gas fluxes

project_title: Integrating Multi-Source Data for Landfill Methane Emission Quantification
event_timeline:
- 2023-07-05: Grant awarded; Obligation of $594,550
- 2025-05-09: End date cut off from 2026-07-31 to 2025-05-09
project_description: Description The purpose of this project is to improve the use of low cost sensors and ambient air monitoring to better quantify spatiotemporal variations of landfill methane emissions Activities The specific objectives are 1 develop low cost air quality sensors to capture methane variation spatially and temporally 2 integrate sensor data from fixed locations mobile sampling and drone surveys to map pollution distribution and estimate emission fluxes and 3 correlate the spatiotemporally resolved methane emission data with multiple environmental factors for evaluating methane reduction techniques Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final research reports The anticipated outputs include integrating sampling technologies for methane emission quantification The datasets will inform landfill operations methane emission models and methane reduction techniques Direct beneficiaries of this project include communities affected by air pollutants emitted by the landfill study sites in in Miami Florida as well the general public who are affected by methane s contribution to climate change Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

project_title: Children’s Environmental Health Center in U.S. Southern Great Plains
event_timeline:
- 2023-09-19: Grant awarded; Obligation of $910,000
- 2024-10-10: Obligation of $988,738
- 2025-04-30: End date cut off from 2027-09-30 to 2025-04-30
project_description: Description The goal of this project is to develop a center to characterize the environmental stressors that affect children s school absenteeism and evaluate new intervention methods Activities The objective of this research is to assess children s health impacts of early life stage stressor exposure and to introduce affordable interventional methods to reduce health effects relating to environmental chemical and non chemical stressors 1 The environmental factors which relate to health issues and cause school absenteeism will be identified and categorized 2 Intervention technologies will also be compared for efficiency in mitigating child health impacts 3 This project will also establish a data driven Children s Health and Social Vulnerability Index to guide future decision making and assess the health disparities and environmental  of rural schools Outcomes Deliverables of this project include annual and final reports documenting the characterization and evaluation of the chemical and non chemical stressors that affect school absenteeism and the effectiveness of individual and combined intervention methods Data will also be collected to produce a public child health vulnerability index to predict the school absenteeism caused by gastrointestinal and respiratory diseases Direct beneficiaries include rural agricultural communities state and local governments environmental health and the general public Subrecipient The total cost for subawards is 1 223 932 with 552 166 to University of North Texas 597 341 to University of Oklahoma ndash Tulsa and 74 425 to University of Oklahoma ndash Norman The University of North Texas will lead research to characterize and intervene chemical and non chemical stressors to reduce school absenteeism caused by gastrointestinal and respiratory diseases using mixed methods The University of Oklahoma Tulsa will be leading the Translation Core OU Norman will develop microclimatic data collection and determine socioeconomic factors

project_title: Integrating and Informing Actionable Agricultural Community Tools (II-ACT): Using Risk-Based Approaches for Evaluating Cumulative Early Life Environmental Stressors
event_timeline:
- 2023-11-15: Grant awarded; Obligation of $910,000
- 2024-10-09: Obligation of $986,439
- 2025-05-02: End date cut off from 2027-11-30 to 2025-05-02
project_description: Description The purpose of this project is to develop an exposome based approach that characterizes chemical and non chemical stressors to provide data on early life stage vulnerabilities in agricultural communities Activities The objectives of this project are the 1 assessment of pesticide data to characterize child exposure genetic polymorphisms hazard values 2 integration of cohort biomarkers into the exposome based framework 3 identification of cumulative exposure impacts in children and 4 quantified comparisons of both nationwide and state specific environmental  mapping tools Outcomes The expected outcomes of this project will be a developmental Center based on early life stage health stressors and new scientific understandings of the effects of exposure to chemical and non chemical stressors through an exposome based approach Deliverables will include annual and final reports documenting the children s agricultural cohort integrative biomarker assays in response to environmental stressors characterization of cohort exposome detailed state and region specific maps comparing mapping tools and recommendations for improved future cumulative impact mapping frameworks Direct beneficiaries of this project include rural and agricultural communities farm workers state and local governments and the general public Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

project_title: The Bioecological Center for Rural Children’s Health (BeRCH)
event_timeline:
- 2023-07-13: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,900,000
- 2025-05-09: End date cut off from 2027-08-31 to 2025-05-09
project_description: Description The purpose of this project is to develop a transdisciplinary approach to evaluate and mitigate the cumulative health consequences of chemical and psychosocial stressors to children s health through a community driven participatory framework Activities The objective of this research is to asses the impacts of early life stage health stressors and create new models and language to encompass the data driven insights This project will 1 document and evaluate the cumulative impact of children s low dose chronic pesticide exposure 2 compare early life microbiome with environmental stressor exposures and 3 develop a statewide cumulative impact assessment to mitigate chemical and non chemical stressor exposure Outcomes Deliverables will include annual and final reports detailing the correlations between environmental stressors and childhood development evaluations of microbiome effects and a public health cumulative impact assessment Intended beneficiaries of this project include agricultural communities farm workers and state and local public health officials Subrecipient The project will provide the Farmworker Association of Florida FWAW with a subaward 116 649 to serve the Translation Core with community engagement and public health outreach to the farmworker population in Immokalee Florida

program: Office of Research and Development Consolidated Research
project_title: Work on Aquatic Toxicology and Ecology Research (CTP-WATER)
organization: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

- 2025-01-07: Obligation of $392,021
- 2025-04-30: End date cut off from 2028-11-15 to 2025-04-30
project_description: Description The goal of the project is to bolster the pipeline of environmental scientists who are dedicated to chemical risk management and water quality protection by providing authentic trainee research experiences with EPA scientists in conjunction with university faculty and their graduate programs and resources Activities The specific objective is to provide unique co mentored research experiences to fifteen undergraduate students eight M S students three Ph D students and four postdoctoral investigators over five years This experience will advance trainee careers increasing the number and preparedness of environmental scientists entering the workforce Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports Additional outputs include scientific and technical publications Additionally project reports theses and dissertations will be produced that fulfill the requirements for undergraduate and advanced degrees Excepted outcomes include increasing in the number and diversity of environmental scientists who can productively contribute to understanding and managing environmental risks particularly in relation to aquatic toxicology and ecology Direct Beneficiaries of this program include the trainees program participants and the general public by growing the environmental scientist workforce Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: Office of Research and Development Consolidated Research
