- 2025-05-13: End date cut off from 2029-10-30 to 2025-05-13
current_fiscal_year_outlays: No outlays reported in this fiscal year
project_description: Description The goal of this project is to provide unique educational opportunities for the next generation of Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics STEM on emerging topics in the field of environmental engineering and science Activities The specific objective is to provide unique co mentored research experiences to ten university students graduate and undergraduate per year over five years This experience will advance the trainee careers and increase the number and preparedness of environmental scientists entering the workforce Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports Additional outputs include scientific and technical publications Additionally dissertations symposium presentations and publications in conference proceedings and refereed journals will be produced that fulfill the requirements for undergraduate and graduate degrees Expected outcomes include increasing the number and diversity of trained environmental scientists and engineers who can productively contribute to solving contemporary environmental problems Direct Beneficiaries of this program include the trainees program participants and the general public by growing the environmental scientist workforce Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: Production of Lithium Carbonate from Geothermal Brine by Selective Extraction of Lithium Using a Novel Ion Sieve Method
event_timeline:
- 2023-12-20: Grant awarded; Obligation of $75,000
- 2025-05-13: End date cut off from 2025-12-31 to 2025-05-13
project_description: Description The goal of this project is to design and develop a novel method to efficiently extract lithium from a geothermal brine with minimal water loss Activities Specifically researchers propose to develop a novel zirconium doped compound that as the potential to increase the adsorption capacity of lithium from brine The research objectives are to 1 synthesize and characterize the lithium ion sieve Li4Mn4 9Zr0 1O12 2 convert the lithium ion to the manganese ion which is the adsorbent material for the lithium extraction and conduct adsorption desorption process and 3 purify the salt precipitates to produce lithium carbonate Outcomes Deliverables will include annual and final reports as well as journal articles on efforts to synthesize the novel zirconium compound and investigate the effectiveness of using as an adsorbent for the process of lithium extraction Direct beneficiaries of this project include the lithium mining and battery industries electric vehicle manufacturers water quality managers and communities currently affected by lithium mining pollution Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: Office of Research and Development Consolidated Research
project_title: Environmental Monitoring and Remediation Technology Assessment Initiative (EMRTAI)
event_timeline:
- 2024-03-08: Grant awarded; Obligation of $215,000
- 2024-07-31: Obligation of $670,601
- 2024-09-10: Obligation of $309,061
- 2025-08-13: Deobligation of -$1,194,662
project_description: Description EPA is soliciting applications from qualified non profit entities that have an interest and experience in conducting assessments or tests of new or existing environmental monitoring and remediation technologies for identifying and recovering critical minerals CMs at contaminated legacy mining sites Applicants must have the ability and knowledge to conduct assessment testing and quality assurance support for new SBIR Phase 2 and 3 and commercial environmental monitoring and remediation technologies Ability and knowledge can be illustrated in a number of ways including but not limited to having conducted the same or similar activities in the past as those described here Familiarity with Federal cooperative agreement or grant operation and management would also be helpful for applicants to highlight Displaying and describing productivity under these or other Federal agreements would also benefit in the solicitation process Activities Activities and responsibilities of the recipient must include bull Establishing a stakeholder group and technical panels to help in prioritizing technical monitoring and recovery needs i e categories of technology to assess and or test bull Developing and submitting a Scientific Data Management Plan SDMP see Section I F and IV D 6 and a post award Initiative Quality Management Plan QMP and operating the Initiative in accordance with their QMP bull Providing outreach workshops bull Preparing and developing technology testing protocols that include stakeholder needs bull Developing performance metrics for assessing and testing new or existing technologies as well as sustainability metrics for evaluating long term and cross media impacts of the characterization or recovery technologies bull Potentially managing subawards contracts as needed with organizations for managing assessment testing and data collection and write progress and summary reports Recipient may conduct but are not limited to CM identification monitoring and recovery projects that provide bull Outreach on the Initiative rsquo s activities and track outcomes for impacts bull Technology and process evaluations or demonstrations bull Technical assistance outreach and or training to model or accelerate solutions bull Feasibility studies bull Expanding acceptance of monitoring or reclamation technologies at mining sites through technology demonstration projects or training and technical assistance or bull Demonstration training or technical assistance projects for developing or improving existing technologies for lsquo alternative use rsquo bull Help make technology assessments more relevant to stakeholders through such activities as establishing relationships with other organizations that conduct technology assessment and performance testing similar to that undertaken by the Initiative Technology demonstrations must involve new or experimental technologies methods or approaches where the results of the project will be disseminated so that others can benefit from the knowledge gained in the demonstration project A project that is accomplished through the performance of routine traditional or established practices or a project that is simply intended to carry out a task rather than transfer information or advance the state of knowledge however worthwhile the project might be is not a demonstration These activities relate generally to the gathering or transferring of information or advancing the state of knowledge Recipient should emphasize this ldquo learning rdquo concept as opposed to ldquo fixing rdquo an environmental problem via a well established method To the extent practicable recipient rsquo s work must embody innovation Innovation for the purposes of this RFA is defined as the process of making changes a new method custom or device Innovation can take the form of wholly n

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: Sensor on Wheels (SOW): A Field-Deployable Environmental Pathogen Detection Tool
event_timeline:
- 2023-12-15: Grant awarded; Obligation of $75,000
- 2025-04-24: End date cut off from 2025-12-31 to 2025-04-24
project_description: Description The goal of this project is to develop a field deployable rapid sensitive and affordable Sensor on Wheels SOW device which will be capable of detecting multiple bacteria targets Activities The objectives of the project are to 1 design and set up the SOW system with a portable Raman spectrometer and microfluidic chip 2 validate the performance with bacteria standards and spiked environmental samples 3 optimize the performance for local field testing and 4 field test the SOW system in Florida and Louisiana before and after flooding hurricanes Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports The expected outcome of this project is the development an affordable sensitive rapid and field deployable system for detecting viable bacterial pathogens and indicator bacteria in various field settings Direct beneficiaries of this project include populations in flood hurricane prone regions human health and the environment and the general public Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: 2D MoS2-Based Field Effect Transistor Sensors for Airborne PFAS Detection
event_timeline:
- 2023-11-28: Grant awarded; Obligation of $75,000
- 2025-04-25: End date cut off from 2025-12-31 to 2025-04-25
- 2025-07-07: End date extended from 2025-04-25 to 2025-12-31
project_description: Description This project will develop a novel design for electronic sensors that detect airborne per poly fluoroalkyl substances PFAS Activities This project s activities include 1 assessing the scalability of sensor fabrication 2 evaluating the performance and accuracy of PFAS detection and quantification in developed air sensor and 3 demonstrating the operation of PFAS air sensors in application via deployment in existing air quality stations Outcomes Anticipated deliverables include publications demonstrations and annual progress reports The expected outcome of this project will be an innovative and scalable air sensor technology for the purpose of airborne PFAS detection and new insights into nanotechnology enabled smart sensors Intended beneficiaries include state and local air monitoring regulators manufacturing facilities and communities affected by airborne PFAS pollution Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: Understanding and Predicting Disparities in Organic Contaminant Levels in Blood Among the U.S. Population
organization: Board of Regents of the Nevada System of Higher Education
event_timeline:
- 2024-01-29: Grant awarded; Obligation of $74,999
- 2025-05-09: End date cut off from 2026-02-28 to 2025-05-09
project_description: Description The goal of this project is to improve and utilize PROTEX an advanced computational model to investigate the variations in blood chemical concentrations among individuals and any disparities among different sexes and racial ethnic groups The team will collect data from past NHANES ndash National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey to predict interindividual variability in blood concentrations of chemical contaminants based on individual specific diets physiological factors and anthropometrics across Americans Activities Research aims 1 Upgrade the exposure and toxicokinetic model PROTEX in order to calculate chemical blood concentrations with the ability to consider inter individual variability in the gut metabolism rate of chemicals 2 Develop databases of demographics physiology anthropometrics and diet composition for NHANES participation and 3 estimate the variations in blood concentration of three case study phthalic acidic esters to examine disparities between sexes and races ethnicities Outcomes Deliverables will include annual and final reports on their efforts to use the PROTEX model to understand the variations of the blood concentrations of chemical contaminants among the U S population and to predict such disparities between subgroups of the population This project is important because it will provide data to inform how specific chemicals impact different populations thereby addressing chemical disparities to improve health especially in disadvantaged and overburdened communities Direct beneficiaries of this program include risk assessors regulatory entities water quality managers chemical and pharmaceutical companies human health and the environment and the general public Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: Developing Reusable and Antiviral Face Masks from Plastic Waste
event_timeline:
- 2023-12-20: Grant awarded; Obligation of $75,000
- 2025-04-25: End date cut off from 2025-12-31 to 2025-04-25
project_description: Description The goal of this project is to develop an antiviral reusable face mask concept from recycled polystyrene and discarded single use face masks Activities 1 This project will collect and characterize plastic waste 2 develop and evaluate reusable nanofiber filtration systems and 3 fabricate and evaluate a 3d printed face mask design Outcomes Deliverables of this project include a novel multi use face mask concept that is similar or exceeds N95 mask performance and nanofiber filtration scientific data through publications reports and conferences The outcome of this project will be a novel design of a reusable antiviral face mask that promotes human health and environmental sustainability Direct beneficiaries include communities with poor air quality state and local governments environmental health and the general public Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

project_description: Description The goal of the project is to optimize and test the biofiltration module in order to understand the mechanisms controlling the enhanced nutrient removal in runoff from urban and agricultural watersheds Activities The specific objectives are to 1 optimize the biofilter media topology with multiple objectives e g max SSA and void ratio 2 characterize the microbial biofilm and 3 deploy the optimized biofilters in situ in small scaled watersheds Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports The potential outcomes include a set of ultra high surface area designs a better understanding of the biofilm structure an increased capacity of stormwater treatment systems and a set of sustainability guidelines for advanced media designs based on life cycle assessment Direct beneficiaries of this project include rural municipalities communities and individuals in areas affected by per and polyfluoroalkyl substances contamination human health the environment and the general public Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: Office of Research and Development Consolidated Research
project_title: A Multistate Study to Establish A Risk Assessment Framework for the AMR in Surface Water Attributable to Municipal Wastewater and Biosolids
organization: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA
event_timeline:
- 2024-08-07: Grant awarded; Obligation of $2,374,999
- 2025-05-12: End date cut off from 2027-07-31 to 2025-05-12
- 2025-07-14: End date extended from 2025-05-12 to 2027-07-31
project_description: Description The purpose of the project is to establish a risk assessment framework that can estimate human health risks based on measurements of antibiotic resistant bacteria ARB and antibiotic resistant genes ARGs in source waters under the influence of municipal wastewater and biosolids The research will generate field data collected from surface water which will be used to calibrate and validate mechanistic fate and transport models for ARB and ARGs in runoff and rivers Once developed these models will inform development of an exposure assessment model for ARB and a semi quantitative risk characterization model for ARGs to improve stakeholders rsquo abilities to understand risks and develop prioritize mitigation strategies Activities The project will start by collecting samples from a variety of wastewater discharging facilities located in New Jersey Nebraska California and Hawaii Including point and non point AMR sources water reuse scenarios de facto non potable potable and environmental settings treatment plant flow water age average precipitation Water samples will then be collected from receiving water bodies at multiple distances downstream during both dry and wet weather conditions from AMR discharges A separate effort will focus on sampling AMR levels in land applied biosolids using field plots in NE to estimate and model concentrations of ARB and ARGs in runoff Using the above information fate and transport models will be calibrated to model ARB and ARGs in each of the selected rivers to predict concentrations downstream explore relative significance of various point and non point sources and provide information for risk assessment modeling Last a risk assessment framework will be developed to evaluate the relative importance of exposure pathways and risk from wastewater originated ARB and ARG levels in rivers Outcomes Key deliverables include new information on ARB and ARG levels and source attribution of AMR from wastewater and non wastewater sources A calibrated and validated mechanistic model will be developed to estimate the significance of AMR loads in surface water to increase the ability of water resource managers to evaluate ethe significance of AMR from land applied biosolids and wastewater A risk exposure assessment model will then be developed to evaluate multiple exposure pathways for ARB and exposure routes for ARGs Key outcomes from the project include improved ability for water resource managers to assess the significance of AMR from wastewater and biosolids along with the ability for stakeholders to quantify the exposure and risk of wastewater originated ARB and ARGs in rivers Beneficiaries include the public state and local regulators wastewater utilities and water quality program managers Subrecipient University of Aawaii at Manoa Yan ndash Objective 1 Generate data from field and laboratory studies 251 124 cost share 63 176 314 300 University of California Riverside Meng ndash Objective 1 Generate data from field and laboratory studies 278 327 cost share 69 626 347 953 Rutgers University Fahrenfield ndash Objective 1 Generate data from field and laboratory studies 421 553 cost share 105 391 526 944 Iowa State University Ikuma and Rehmann ndash Objective 4 Fate and transport modeling for rivers 273 866 cost share 68 629 342 495

program: Office of Research and Development Consolidated Research
project_title: Prevalence, Abundance, and Fate of Antibiotics, Antibiotic-Resistant Bacteria, and their Determinant Genes in U.S. Wastewater Systems
event_timeline:
- 2024-07-29: Grant awarded; Obligation of $2,350,211
- 2025-05-07: End date cut off from 2027-08-31 to 2025-05-07
project_description: Description The purpose of the project is to quantify the fate of antibiotic resistant bacteria ARB genes ARGs and antibiotics in wastewater treatment utilities across the U S 40 wastewater treatment facilities representing varied geographical conditions population demographics and wastewater sources will be sampled with both culture and molecular methods as well as suspect screening to identify antibiotic compounds A meta analysis using existing metagenomic data in wastewater in the literature will be conducted to understand the impacts of seasonal regional variations and create a comprehensive library on the resistome of wastewater Activities 40 wastewater treatment utilities from 5 regions across the U S accounting for varied geographical conditions population demographics and wastewater sources will be sampled for two years Samples will be collected throughout the wastewater treatment train to include biosolids Both culture and molecular methods will be used to quantify ARB and ARGs in the samples and suspect screening will be used to identify antibiotic compounds in the samples A systematic review of metagenomic data in the literature will create a library which will be used to conduct a meta analysis providing a better understanding of the seasonal regional and treatment process effects on ARB and ARG levels in wastewater Outcomes Key deliverables include data on the abundance of ARB and ARGs as well as antibiotics in wastewater samples to include sampling influent secondary effluent tertiary effluent final effluent raw sludge and treated biosolids Separate reports on each project aim will be developed including details on results sampling testing and data analysis A systematic review of the literature will be conducted and a metaanalysis will identify seasonal regional and treatment process effects on antimicrobial resistance Two webinars will be developed to guide utilities and regulators on effective treatment process and operational conditions for AMR removal Workshops will be held at regional and national conferences to disseminate results and a project website will be developed to share project information and deliverables Beneficiaries include the public state and local regulators wastewater utilities and water quality program managers Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: Office of Research and Development Consolidated Research
project_title: Understanding The Role of Wastewter Treatment for Mitgating Antimicrobial Resistance: Leveraging Historical Trajectories, Current Day Mass Balances, and Clinical Relevance
event_timeline:
- 2024-07-31: Grant awarded; Obligation of $2,038,572
- 2025-04-23: End date cut off from 2027-08-31 to 2025-04-23
project_description: Description The purpose of this project is to quantify the effectiveness of wastewater treatment on the removal and or selection of antimicrobial resistant bacteria and genes The project will evaluate the process for removing antimicrobial resistant bacteria and genes throughout the wastewater treatment train including measuring concentrations loads entering and being discharged from wastewater treatment The project will provide an understanding of the fate and transport of antimicrobial resistant bacteria and genes in effluent discharge by monitoring a river that is set to receive wastewater treatment plant discharge for the first time A key focus of the project is on the clinical relevance of resistant genes and bacteria that are discharged from the treatment process so that risks can be put into perspective with other industrial and agricultural sectors connected to antimicrobial resistance AMR Activities Activities to achieve project objectives include breaking down the wastewater treatment process into unit operations and determining changes in AMR quantities among system components and in relation to treatment facility operational parameters Research framework will integrate antimicrobial resistance gene and resistant bacteria quantification and genomic and metagenomic based DNA sequencing to determine AMR mass balances and changes in clinically relevant genotypes from treatment facility influent through the treatment train and ultimately to facility outflows Outcomes Key outputs include annual and final technical reports publications as well as 1 information on the temporal dynamics of AMR into two wastewater treatment plants using historical data over a ten year period to understand how influent loads have changed over time 2 new information on what unit operations are most successful in removing AMR and 3 new information on the impact of treatment plant discharge into surface waters Intended beneficiaries include state and local regulators wastewater utilities water quality program managers and the communities served by public water systems Subrecipient The project team plans to collaborate with Florida Gulf Coast University 19 882 and Washington State University 29 197 cost share of 7 837 for the total of 37 034 for wastewater treatment sample collection The team additionally plan to collaborate with Marquette University 288 872 cost share of 72 221 for the total of 361 093 for additional wastewater treatment sample collection and mass balance calculations through unit operations

program: Office of Research and Development Consolidated Research
project_title: Quantifying Wastewater Sources of Antibiotic Resistance to Aquatic and Soil Environments and Associated Human Health Risks
event_timeline:
- 2024-08-01: Grant awarded; Obligation of $2,374,575
- 2025-04-24: End date cut off from 2027-07-31 to 2025-04-24
project_description: Description The purpose of the project is to characterize exposure potentials of antibiotic resistant bacteria ARB and antibiotic resistant genes ARGs and create a comprehensive risk assessment modeling framework tailored to the unique aspects of AMR allowing potential mitigation options The project will quantify ARB ARGs from wastewater treatment plant effluent and biosolids and will assess their fate in soil and aquatic environments as well ashow ARB ARGs attenuate or amplify in the enviromnent Research findings will build upon a database of ARB ARG occurrence around the world and will support the development of a human health risk assessment for wastewater effluent and biosolid sources Activities Field studies will be conducted to measure antimicrobial resistant bacteria and gene mass loading ranges in wastewater treatment plant effluents in a variety of communities across the US Wastewater sources of resistant genes and bacteria will then be compared with other sources in areas with different wastewater effluent and management approaches An AMR tailored human health risk assessment for wastewater treatment plant effluent will then be developed to inform management options Stakeholders will be engaged throughout the project to translate research findings into actionable solutions Outcomes Expected deliverables include annual progress and final reports and publications as well as new information on estimated amplification attenuation persistence rates of ARB ARGs in receiving waters and soils subject to land application of biosolids A comparison of environmental metagenomic and whole genome sequencing data covering multiple wastewater management scenarios will also be developed along with a risk assessment framework for wastewater sources of AMR Data will also be entered into a publicly available database and search tool for estimating ARB ARG outputs from wastewater treatment plants along with identification of operating conditions that influence ARB ARG levels Reports peer reviewed publications and webinars will be used to engage stakeholders at the end of the project Intended beneficiaries of this program include the wastewater utilities state and local regulators water quality program managers and communities effected by the spread of antimicrobial resistance downstream of wastewater treatment plant discharges Subrecipient Virginia Tech 990 000 cost share of 820 074 WRF match of 75 000 for the total of 1 885 074 Arizona State University 799 999 cost share of 128 242 WRF match of 75 000 for the total of 1 003 241 and University of South Florida 275 000 cost share of 57 231 WRF match of 25 000 for the total of 357 321 will conduct field sample collection and analysis West Virginia University 250 000 cost share of 63 166 WRF match of 25 000 for the total of 338 166 will conduct geospatial mapping and analysis

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability - Phase II
project_title: Smartphone-Based Colorimetric Lead Sensor for Household Detection

project_description: Description The goal of this project is to develop an affordable and easy to use sensor for highly selective and sensitive detection of lead in tap water Activities The specific objectives are to 1 optimize the selectivity and sensitivity of the Janus gold nanorod AuJNR based colorimetric sensors for lead analysis in tap water 2 quantify the influence of tap water matrices on lead sensor performance and 3 unveil patterns of lead pollution with affected communities via citizen science Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports The results of this project will result in uniquely engineered sensors featuring a Janus like structure and selective quenching of longitudinal localized surface plasmon resonance demonstrate superior stability and sensitivity in tap water matrices compared to previous plasmonic colorimetric sensors and determine the impact of various tap water matrices on sensor performance Direct beneficiaries of this project include will be communities and individuals affected by lead contaminated drinking water including households and children in Milwaukee WI human health the environment and the general public Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

project_description: Description The goal of the project is to create highly active catalysts for Fenton like reactions with tunable surface charge for enhanced adsorption of Per and Polyfluoroalkyl Substances PFAS in drinking water Activities The specific objectives are to 1 synthesize mixed metal ndash iron based nanostructured catalysts following an iron replacement reaction in aqueous media 2 investigate adsorption capacity and mechanisms of PFOA to the nanostructured iron oxide materials iron and mixed metal and 3 evaluate the continuous filtration degradation reaction process for removal of PFOA by ceramic membranes coated with nanostructured iron oxide materials iron and mixed metal Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports The potential outcome of the project is improvement in drinking water quality for the affected population by testing a prototype for a hybrid filtration reaction membrane system that is capable of removing PFAS from drinking water Direct beneficiaries of this project will be rural municipalities communities and individuals in areas affected by per and polyfluoroalkyl substances contamination human health the environment and the general public Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

project_description: Description The goal of the project is to address the need for a better understanding of the presence and removal of microplastics in wastewater treatment process Activities The specific objectives are to 1 further improve the testing procedures of microplastics with a specific emphasis on refining the steps of eliminating organic matter OM content 2 continue sample collection and correlate the temporal patterns of microplastics with climate season and water use patterns 3 train undergraduate and graduate students in STEM research and 4 disseminate the results including the creation of a final report intended to guide fellow researchers Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports The potential outcomes include finding the best digestion dosage reagent ratio and reaction time to eliminate OM in wastewater Direct beneficiaries of this project will be water quality managers wastewater treatment plants local community partners within Indiana people and ecosystems in areas affected by microplastics human health the environment and the general public Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

project_description: Description The goal of this project is to significantly reduce the water and oil resistant coating on fully biodegradable coated paper from 30 wt to below 10 wt which will lower the cost and enhance the viability of the developed coated paper Activities The specific objectives are 1 Use poly butylene succinate blends PBS blends for paper coating applications and 2 using a dual layer strategy to reduce the overall coating load Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports The results of this project will create environmentally low impact packaging solutions as alternatives to non biodegradable options The initiative provides a greener alternative to conventional plastics and perfluoroalkyl and polyfluoroalkyl substances PFAS coated paper which are major sources of microplastics and fluorochemical pollution Direct beneficiaries of this project would include communities impacted by PFAS contamination industries that utilize single use packaging and environmental managers Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

project_title: Multimodal Nanosensor for Field Detection and Degradation of PFAS Contamination in Ground Water and Wastewater

- 2025-07-02: End date extended from 2025-04-24 to 2027-07-31
project_description: Description The project will develop and validate nanosensing technology integrated with a nano remediation platform to monitor and completely degrade per and polyfluoroalkyl substances PFAS in water Activities The specific activities to be performed are 1 validate the technology using standard methods for measuring PFAS 2 integrate the nano catalytic degradation platform with nanosensor technology and test the integrated performance and 3 deploy the prototype and demonstrate sensing and degradation capabilities in groundwater wastewater and surface water Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final project reports as well as a field ready technology to quantify reduce and mitigate PFAS contamination in groundwater wastewater and surface water The expected outcome of the project is a comprehensive laboratory study to test robustness and adaptability of the novel nanosensing technology followed by field scale deployment to generate necessary performance data for broader implementation Direct beneficiaries of this project include water users in the Saint Regis Mohawk Tribe and the wider rural New York region industrial and municipal wastewater treatment plants human health and the environment and the general public Subrecipient Subaward of 300 000 to Stevens Institute of Technology will support the development of quantum Raman qRaman detection and optimization of surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy for qRaman Subaward of 150 000 to University of Buffalo will support the testing of electrochemical and Raman systems on samples from wastewater treatment plants using validation with LC MS MS analysis and testing of PFAS degradation products from the photochemical degradation Subaward of 300 000 to University of Nebraska Lincoln will support the development and characterization of photocatalytic materials and its efficiency of photocatalytic degradation of PFAS

project_title: Developing Effective Assessment Approaches for Cumulative Impacts and Driving Environmental Health Equity in Underserved Communities
organization: Regents of the University of California, The
event_timeline:
- 2024-12-13: Grant awarded; Obligation of $500,000
- 2025-04-29: End date cut off from 2027-12-31 to 2025-04-29
- 2025-07-11: End date extended from 2025-04-29 to 2027-12-31
project_description: Description The purpose of this project is to create comprehensive cumulative impact indices that encompass the effects of chemical and non chemical stressors at the community level throughout the state to advance environmental health equity and  Activities The specific objectives are to 1 investigate the cumulative impacts of both chemical and non chemical stressors on respiratory conditions cardiovascular diseases and lung cancer within underserved communities 2 engage community members to enhance the relevance and accuracy of cumulative impact assessments and ensure alignment with community needs and perspectives 3 conduct economic burden analysis to estimate the economic costs associated with health outcomes and leveraging these costs to adjust the calculated marginal effects of stressors in health outcome modeling and 4 develop evidence based recommendations for programs policies and decisions aimed at mitigating environmental health disparities and promoting equity Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports The results of this project include will develop a comprehensive stressor assessment report blueprints for evidence based practical programs state and local policy recommendations and an innovative cumulative impact indices Direct beneficiaries include the underserved Oakland San Leandro and Hmong ethnic communities human health the environment and the general public Subrecipient Regional Asthma Management and Prevention RAMP 120 000 RAMP will lead the development of program policy and decision recommendations based on the outcomes of the research RAMP will recommend evidence based programs and policies aimed at tackling specific health outcomes and cumulative impacts within underserved communities Hmong Community Center of Butte County HCCBC 20 000 HCCBC will in this project translate a focus group instrument into Hmong recruit participants for Butte County focus groups conduct 3 focus groups in language facilitate any focus group or meeting needed with local people in Hmong and English transcribe and translate recorded content from Hmong into English deliver 3 de identified transcripts from groups in English and check results for any needed translation for a community meeting Alameda County Department of Public Health ACDPH Community Health Services rsquo CHS Asthma Start Program 25 000 The Asthma Start Program will utilize Medical Social Workers to design two survey questions pre and post in English and Spanish collect data through pre and post surveys and other methods recruit 50 survey participants from Oakland and San Leandro with a focus on Black and Hispanic communities and participate in monthly quarterly meetings to inform the group on task progress The MSW I II will stay abreast of research discoveries and provide information findings for an annual report

project_title: Community-Driven Assessment of Cumulative Impacts on Health, Food, and Water Security in Vieques, Puerto Rico
event_timeline:
- 2025-01-30: Grant awarded; Obligation of $500,000
- 2025-05-02: End date cut off from 2028-01-31 to 2025-05-02
project_description: Description The goal of this project it to develop a mixed methods approach for collecting environmental social food and health data which will be used to evaluate changes in contaminant exposure from climate change stressors Activities The specific objectives are to 1 develop a community centered framework to assess the cumulative impacts of environmental exposures climate change and food and water insecurity on the health and wellbeing of adults over the age of 55 with chronic illnesses in Vieques 2 establish the relationship between food and water insecurity contaminant exposure and how climate change may impact this relationship and 3 develop community outreach to strengthen local food production and safety on Vieques a Superfund site and model small island impacted by climate change Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports The results of this project will create a network that address food and water insecurity in Vieques The primary outcome of the project is demonstrating how an innovative Cumulative Impacts Risk Assessment framework can be applied to communities which have experienced long term exposure to chemical contamination Direct beneficiaries of this project are the residents of Vieques residents of small island communities affected by climate change the general public human health and the environment Subrecipient Isla Nena Composta 120 500 Technicians from Isla Nena Composta will work with Phase II participants to identify mitigation alternatives for environmental impacts and climate change triggers in the frequently visited ldquo special riparian zones rdquo and elder trees ecosystems trees 40 years and over They will use Phase II and III findings to develop a site work guide including maps of the elder tree forest ecosystem and citizen science methods for restoring and monitoring ecosystem services to mitigate existing environmental impacts and climate change triggers They will also organize public presentations and colloquia to share the research results with communities and researchers University of Puerto Rico Rio Piedras UPR RP 430 000 UPR RP will create a technical guide with practical tools to address ecological disturbances They will also create a water monitoring station network that the community can use to monitor the ecosystem s health over time as well as assess the impacts of the management actions at a large scale by evaluating vegetation dynamics in the watersheds using the greenness index of Enhanced Vegetation Index EVI derived from satellite images University of Puerto Rico Medical Campus UPR MC 90 199 UPR MC will manage and oversee project activities including instrument development sampling design and implementation for survey interviews training and supervising interviewers dataset development management They will develop the curriculum and execute a health promotion campaign to empower Promotoras de Salud The campaign will include workshops and experiences to help families make healthy decisions to reduce contaminant exposure and improve food security within a changing climate through knowledge experience and community

project_title: Achieving Change for Cumulative Impacts on Neighborhoods (ACCION II)
event_timeline:

- 2025-04-30: End date cut off from 2028-01-31 to 2025-04-30
project_description: Description The goal of this project is to elucidate the policy making process to mitigate environmental exposures and elevate resident voices to address legacy pollutants and ongoing contaminants that result in negative health outcomes Activities The specific objectives are to 1 develop models of the cumulative health burden experienced by marginalized communities to address whether the relationships between cumulative social and environmental exposures and health outcomes are consistent across communities and diseases along Colorado rsquo s Front Range and 2 facilitate roundtables where residents have a deliberate and meaningful opportunity to engage the state and local policy making process regarding environmental exposures promote their concerns and develop solutions in concert with public and private agencies Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports A framework will be developed that will assess the cumulative burden attributable to multiple simultaneous chemical and non chemical stressors in Colorado and to create sustainability in the Commerce City North Denver neighborhoods through meaningful opportunities for engagement advocacy and leadership of residents elevation of health and environmental issues in state and local policy and decision making processes Direct beneficiaries include residents of the Commerce City North Denver neighborhoods human health the environment and the general public Subrecipient The University of Illinois will receive a subaward for 347 608 They will provide data and analysis support for both the health and environmental exposure data along with providing support for development of presentations and manuscripts associated with this research

project_title: Mixed-Methods Cumulative Impacts Research and Health Analysis to Inform Policy Proposals in Bernalillo County, New Mexico and Richmond County, Georgia
organization: PHYSICIANS, SCIENTISTS, AND ENGINEERS FOR SUSTAINABLE AND HEALTHY ENERGY, INC.
event_timeline:
- 2025-01-16: Grant awarded; Obligation of $500,000
- 2025-04-29: End date cut off from 2027-01-31 to 2025-04-29
project_description: Description This research project aims to fill existing gaps in cumulative burden analysis including air and water pollution burdens and to better inform locally tailored policies and strategies to mitigate environmental health disparities in selected partnering underserved communities in Georgia and New Mexico Activities The research project will develop a statewide cumulative burden index CBI for Georgia and New Mexico using a novel health impact analysis method The project will then integrate community driven priorities to develop local high resolution CBIs for Bernalillo County NM and Richmond County GA Finally the project will apply the analysis to case study that facilities in each county to inform local policy recommendations and identify best practices for similar efforts nationwide Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final research reports peer reviewed journal publications and scientific reports as well as educational materials and policy recommendations for state and local public health agencies environmental managers health professionals and community planners and leaders Expected outcomes include a reduction of harmful pollutant exposures and a general improvement in environmental health among residents in the underserved communities in Georgia and New Mexico Intended beneficiaries include state and local public health agencies environmental managers health professionals community leaders and vulnerable populations in the underserved communities in Georgia and New Mexico Subrecipient University of New Mexico 389 429 UNM will provide legal and policy analysis and support engagement with community groups and oversee the engagement activities and qualitative data collection and analysis tasks working with Dr Nunez and other co investigators on analyses for AIM 2 Los Jardines 389 454 Los Jardines will engage community leaders and host grassroots community workshops to disseminate research and to describe broader resident rsquo s perspectives on cumulative burdens conducting community focus groups and host public convenings to vet qualitative research findings and solidify recommendations for integrating local data Georgia Wand 313 820 Georgia Wand will engage community leaders and host grassroots community workshops to disseminate research and to describe broader resident rsquo s perspectives on cumulative burdens conducting community focus groups and host public convenings to vet qualitative research findings and solidify recommendations for integrating local data

project_title: Community-Based Research in Hispanic Neighborhoods for Sustainable Solutions in Indoor Environmental  Impacted by Air Pollution, Climate Change, and Social Environments

project_description: Description The goals of the project are to examine the cumulative exposure to chemical and non chemical stressors in Hispanic environmental  neighborhoods implement and evaluate a practical and effective intervention program to improve indoor home environmental quality and reduce health disparities for low income Hispanic populations and develop a sustainable action plan to reduce cumulative environmental exposure for Hispanic populations Activities The research team will characterize indoor home environmental quality using environmental  screening tools and community participatory indoor exposure assessment and will also evaluate individual health well being and quality of life through validated questionnaires Furthermore the team will evaluate the effectiveness of portable air purifier use to improve indoor environmental quality and health Finally they will work with community engaged focus groups to provide best practice recommendations and tailored educational campaigns for both residents and policymakers Outcomes Anticipated deliverables include a unique cumulative exposure index integrating environmental burden social vulnerability and indoor home pollution measured by community members as well as annual and final technical reports and publications An anticipated outcome of the proposed intervention is to improve indoor environmental quality by reducing exposure by at least 50 among this vulnerable Hispanic population Direct beneficiaries of this program include the Hispanic community in Norristown PA where the project is taking place similar communities human health and the environment and the general public Subrecipient Villanova Total 367 943 has a subaward to coordinate with local organizations and other Co PIs to measure indoor air quality in participating households Villanova University is also responsible for data analysis preparing reports such as presentations and publications CCATE Total 165 000 will recruit households visit participating households for field sampling take environmental health measurements and install home based intervention methods air purifiers CCATE will also help organize focus group interviews and dissemination activities during the study period

project_description: Description This agreement provides funding under the Inflation Reduction Act The recipient will provide financial and technical assistance to low income and disadvantaged communities to deploy and benefit from residential serving distributed solar energy and storage projects These programs will ensure low income households receive residential distributed solar by providing program beneficiaries household savings community ownership energy resilience and other meaningful benefits Activities Solar projects receiving financial assistance from the recipient may receive assistance for associated energy storage and upgrades that either enable project deployment or maximize the benefits of the project for low income and disadvantaged communities The recipient will also provide project deployment services to enable low income and disadvantaged communities to deploy and benefit from residential solar Outcomes The anticipated deliverables will include steps and milestones to implement the strategies and plans for the Solar for All Program a distribute solar market strategy the financial assistance strategy the project deployment technical assistance strategy and an equitable access and meaningful involvement plan The expected outcomes include climate and air pollution benefits equity and community benefits and market transformation benefits The intended beneficiaries include households in low income and disadvantaged communities Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: 3D-Printed Floating Photocatalyst Structures that Mimic Natural Objects to Combat Harmful Algal Blooms
event_timeline:
- 2024-02-06: Grant awarded; Obligation of $74,881
- 2025-05-12: End date cut off from 2026-01-31 to 2025-05-12
project_description: Description This project aims to design a sustainable and affordable strategy to treat harmful algal blooms HABs using sunlight driven photocatalysts that will degrade the cyanobacteria Researchers will develop 3D printed floating structures coated with photocatalysts which can be deployed in water bodies that frequently experience cyanobacteria dominated HABs such as the Indian Lake in Worcester MA Activities The team will design and fabricate 3D printed floated systems which 1 have high specific surface area for high efficiency 2 are coated with a fully exposed uniform layer of photocatalyst on the surface for high number of exposed active sites 3 are intentionally designed to be in the shape of locally occurring n local wildlife 4 can breakdown cyanobacteria 5 can be quickly deployed at the site of concern and 6 can be retrieved by swimming robots and reused when where needed Outcomes Deliverables will include annual and final reports Additionally the project is expected to produce multiple peer reviewed publications in journals The expected outcome of this project will be a reusable prototype prepared by modified 3D printing process which can be deployed into water bodies when needed to control HAB outbreaks efficiently and recovered after treatment Direct beneficiaries of this program include water quality managers human health and the environment and the general public Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: 100% Compostable Packaging Film
event_timeline:
- 2023-11-30: Grant awarded; Obligation of $75,000
- 2025-04-23: End date cut off from 2025-12-31 to 2025-04-23
project_description: Description The goal of the project is to develop a cost effective environmentally friendly food packaging system which will reduce environmental waste Activities The project activities include 1 developing packaging film with similar or higher oxygen and water vapor barrier performance to meet food protection requirements 2 evaluating film production processes that may fit into existing infrastructure 3 assessing chemical safety of packaging film and 4 evaluating cost efficiency of film Outcomes Deliverables for this project include annual and final reports Additionally the project is expected to produce journal manuscripts detailing characterization results of film nanocoating and parameter optimization and a website which will educate the public on how current packaging film technology affects our environment and promote the importance of alternative solutions The expected outcome of this project will be the development of a new biodegradable packaging film that aims to alter current plastic packaging and waste management conventions Direct beneficiaries include plastic manufacturers packaging industries state and local governments the environment human health and the general public Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: Zirconium-Modified Mica Coupled with Nanobubbles for Enhanced Phosphorus Removal, Recovery, and Reuse
event_timeline:
- 2023-12-11: Grant awarded; Obligation of $75,000
- 2025-04-25: End date cut off from 2025-12-31 to 2025-04-25
project_description: Description The goal of this project is to develop an integrated treatment system that couples novel sorbents with oxygen nanobubbles to achieve phosphonate degradation and phosphate adsorption simultaneously in order to capture phosphorous from wastewater and reuse as a slow release fertilizer Activities The project will 1 design and develop zirconium modified mica minerals to be coupled with oxygen nanobubbles 2 assess the adsorption and degradation efficacy of phosphonate on the zirconium modified mica mineral and oxygen nanobubble system and 3 assess the attributes of phosphorous laden mica minerals as slow release fertilizer Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports as well as peer reviewed journal articles on an innovative integrated system for removal recovery and reuse of phosphorous resources from wastewater Direct beneficiaries of the project include water treatment utilities natural resource managers and communities affected by eutrophication Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: Solar-Driven Photodegradation of MC-LR Using a Novel Au-Decorated Ni Metal-Organic Framework (Au/Ni-MOF)
event_timeline:
- 2023-12-06: Grant awarded; Obligation of $75,000
- 2025-05-10: End date cut off from 2025-12-31 to 2025-05-10
project_description: Description This project aims to develop a cost effective method to degrade harmful algal blooms HABs such as microcystin leucine arginine MC LR in recreational and drinking water sources Activities Researchers will use an innovative gold Au decorated metal organic framework MOF where the gold nanoparticles provide the solar function for the photocatalyst The project rsquo s three research objectives are 1 design and fabricate an Au decorated Ni MOF 2 characterize and evaluate optimal parameter conditions and 3 conduct a life cycle analysis for MC LR removal Outcomes Deliverables will include annual and final reports on their effort to design and fabricate a gold decorated photocatalyst Au NI MOF for its ability to advance sustainable water treatment methods for the removal of MC LR while eliminating the need for chemical and post treatment associated with conventional treatment methods Direct beneficiaries of this program include source and drinking water managers and communities that experience MC LR blooms Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: An Open-Source Droplet Digital PCR (ddPCR) System for the Rapid and Accurate Detection of Bacteria from Environmental Water Samples
event_timeline:
- 2023-11-16: Grant awarded; Obligation of $75,000
- 2025-04-25: End date cut off from 2025-12-31 to 2025-04-25
project_description: Description The goal of this project is to develop and validate an open source Droplet Digital Polymerase Chain Reaction ddPCR system to rapidly detect specific waterborne bacteria from environmental water samples Activities The project will 1 develop the ddPCR assays to detect bacteria from environmental water samples 2 develop a new sampling and filtering procedure to boost the bacteria recovery rate from environmental water samples 3 develop an integrated and open source ddPCR system from field workers and environmental engineers 4 collaborate with environmental non profit organizations high schools and Native American tribes on community outreach regarding the importance of water resource protection Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports as well as an open source ddPCR system and supporting water quality data The expected outcome of the project is improved water quality monitoring and cleaner and safer waterbodies Direct beneficiaries include state local and tribal water resource managers and communities affected by surface water pollution Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: Developing Geopolymer Cement using Sewage Sludge Ash as Precursors
event_timeline:
- 2023-12-19: Grant awarded; Obligation of $74,809
- 2025-05-13: End date cut off from 2025-12-31 to 2025-05-13
project_description: Description This project aims to use sewage sludge ash SSA an industrial byproduct from wastewater treatment to develop sustainable low carbon cement Activities The team will develop low carbon geopolymer cement The research objectives are to 1 thoroughly characterize the sewage sludge ash both physically and chemically and 2 investigate various influencing factors such as the activator binder ratio and activators coupled with curing conditions to determine the optimal set of factors that yield competent mechanical and engineering properties Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports on their efforts to develop a low carbon geopolymer cement using the waste product SSA Direct beneficiaries of this program include solid waste disposal and landfill managers specifically in Pennsylvania water quality managers and the cement industry Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: Cellulose-Metal Organic Frameworks Hybrid Adsorbent for PFAS Removal from Water
event_timeline:
- 2023-11-28: Grant awarded; Obligation of $75,000
- 2025-05-10: End date cut off from 2025-12-31 to 2025-05-10
- 2025-07-03: End date extended from 2025-05-10 to 2025-12-31
project_description: Description The goal of this project is to develop an innovative cellulose metal organic frameworks Cello MOFs hybrid adsorbent for a practical column removal process to remediate aquatic per and polyfluoroalkyl substances PFAS pollution Activities The specific objectives are to 1 synthesize nanocellulose templated MOFs Cello MOFs hybrid sorbents 2 test for efficient removal of long and short chain PFAS adsorption and 3 demonstrate efficient aquatic PFAS removal using Cello MOFs packed column Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports as well as the tested technology for Cello MOFs for removal of PFAS The expected outcome of the project is to develop a sustainable and practical solution for PFAS pollutant removal from drinking surface and groundwater environments Direct beneficiaries of this project include human health the environment and the general public Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: Navigating the Food-Energy-Water Nexus through the Conversion of Food Waste to Biocrude
organization: MercerUniv - The Corporation of Mercer University
event_timeline:
- 2023-12-07: Grant awarded; Obligation of $74,999
- 2025-05-10: End date cut off from 2025-12-31 to 2025-05-10
project_description: Description The goal of this project is to evaluate the environmental performance of second generation biofuels produced via hydrothermal liquefaction HTL conversion of food waste using a range of experimental methods and life cycle and cost assessment techniques Activities The objectives of the project are to 1 characterize and optimize food waste feedstocks and their corresponding post HTL products i e biocrude biochar and aqueous co product ACP and 2 perform life cycle assessment LCA and life cycle cost LCC assessment of hypothetical regional collection and conversion systems for biocrude and post HTL products recovered from food waste streams Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports The expected outcome of this project is to assess feasibility and sustainability of waste to energy systems via HTL conversion and disseminate findings from a full scale LCA and LCC assessment model Direct beneficiaries of this project include food waste streams the renewable energy sector the environment human health and the general public Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: Biochar-Enabled Platform for Enhanced Destruction and Defluorination of Short-Chain Per- and Polyfluoroalkyl Substances (PFAS) in Water
event_timeline:
- 2024-11-20: Grant awarded; Obligation of $73,089
- 2025-05-10: End date cut off from 2026-12-31 to 2025-05-10
- 2025-07-08: End date extended from 2025-05-10 to 2026-12-31
project_description: Description The purpose of this project is to develop a novel biochar based treatment platform to deconstruct and defluorinate Per and Polyfluoralkyl substances PFAS from drinking water Activities The objectives of the research are to 1 synthetize characterize and select the best biochar enabled platforms 2 investigate the effects of water matrices on the destruction and defluorination of C4 C6 PFAS by the best biochar enabled platforms and 3 regenerate and reuse the biochar enabled platforms for PFAS degradation to further lower down the treatment costs and achieve sustainability while minimizing environmental footprint of the treatment platform Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports as well as peer reviewed articles degradation platform operation manuals and demonstrations Outcomes include the potential to destruct short chain PFAS at high defluorination rates which will have the ability to supply the public with clean and safe drinking water in a cost effective manner through the innovative use of agricultural wastes Direct beneficiaries of the program include state and local governments human health the environment and the general public The Fiscal Line Details for this action are shown in whole dollars The actual costs to be increase are in dollars and cents as shown below Req No 242631M006 FY 2324 Appropriation Code C BO Code 2631000 PRC 000FK8 Object Class 4141 Amt 73 089 42 Subrecipient Tuskegee University will receive a subaward for 24 994 Dr Jafarinejad will recruit two undergrad students who will spend one summer working at the PIs lab to learn PFAS destruction technology Tuskegee University will then facilitate the PFAS destruction technology to the Alabama Black Belt region

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: Enhancement of Per- and Polyfluoroalkyl Substances (PFAS)-Contaminated Organic Wastes Treatment in Anaerobic Digestion by Carbon Materials.
event_timeline:
- 2023-12-14: Grant awarded; Obligation of $75,000
- 2025-05-13: End date cut off from 2025-12-31 to 2025-05-13
- 2025-07-02: End date extended from 2025-05-13 to 2025-12-31
- 2025-10-02: End date extended from 2025-12-31 to 2026-12-31
project_description: Description The goal of this project is to improve upon anaerobic digestion technology with the addition of carbon materials that can be recycled and reused and to address potential per and polyfluoroalkyl substances PFAS leaching from digested biosolids Activities The project will 1 assess the performance of anaerobic digestors fed with PFAS contaminated food wastes and sewage sludge with and without granular activated carbon GAC addition 2 determine distribution of PFAS in different components i e liquid biosolids and GAC after digestion and explore biotransformation of PFAS 3 study leaching potential of different PFAS from digested biosolids with and without GAC after digestion 4 evaluate the feasibility of recycling the PFAS sorbed GAC for multiple cycles of digestion Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports as well as an integrated sustainable and efficient anaerobic digestion technology for treating PFAS contaminated organic wastes to improve the quality of recovered biosolids The outcome of this project will prevent PFAS pollution during the use of biosolids for land application improve the quality of digested biosolids and protection of environmental and human health Direct beneficiaries of the project include the food industry waste management treatment facilities farmers the environment and general public Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

- 2025-01-08: Project description changed
- 2025-08-07: End date cut off from 2029-04-30 to 2025-08-07
project_description: Description This agreement provides funding under the Inflation Reduction Act The recipient will provide financial and technical assistance to low income and disadvantaged communities to deploy and benefit from residential serving distributed solar energy and storage projects These programs will ensure low income households receive residential distributed solar by providing program beneficiaries household savings community ownership energy resilience and other meaningful benefits Activities Solar projects receiving financial assistance from the recipient may receive assistance for associated energy storage and upgrades that either enable project deployment or maximize the benefits of the project for low income and disadvantaged communities The recipient will also provide project deployment services to enable low income and disadvantaged communities to deploy and benefit from residential solar Outcomes The anticipated deliverables will include steps and milestones to implement the strategies and plans for the Solar for All Program a distribute solar market strategy the financial assistance strategy the project deployment technical assistance strategy and an equitable access and meaningful involvement plan The expected outcomes include climate and air pollution benefits equity and community benefits and market transformation benefits The intended beneficiaries include households in low income and disadvantaged communities Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

project_description: Description This agreement provides funding under the Inflation Reduction Act The recipient will provide financial and technical assistance to low income and disadvantaged communities to deploy and benefit from residential serving distributed solar energy and storage projects These programs will ensure low income households receive residential distributed solar by providing program beneficiaries household savings community ownership energy resilience and other meaningful benefits Activities Solar projects receiving financial assistance from the recipient may receive assistance for associated energy storage and upgrades that either enable project deployment or maximize the benefits of the project for low income and disadvantaged communities The recipient will also provide project deployment services to enable low income and disadvantaged communities to deploy and benefit from residential solar Outcomes The anticipated deliverables will include steps and milestones to implement the strategies and plans for the Solar for All Program a distribute solar market strategy the financial assistance strategy the project deployment technical assistance strategy and an equitable access and meaningful involvement plan The expected outcomes include climate and air pollution benefits equity and community benefits and market transformation benefits The intended beneficiaries include households in low income and disadvantaged communities Subawards The Florida Solar for All coalition is comprised of SELF along with coalition partners Solar United Neighbors SUN and The Nature Conservancy in Florida TNC Subawards will be provided to these partners to support their work in community outreach education technical assistance and direct project implementation SUN rsquo s role will focus on organizing and mobilizing the deployment of solar projects while TNC will provide expertise in program outreach and program monitoring and evaluation These partnerships will be critical in achieving the program rsquo s goals and ensuring long term sustainability Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

project_description: Description This agreement provides funding under the Inflation Reduction Act The recipient will provide financial and technical assistance to low income and disadvantaged communities to deploy and benefit from residential serving distributed solar energy and storage projects These programs will ensure low income households receive residential distributed solar by providing program beneficiaries household savings community ownership energy resilience and other meaningful benefits Activities Solar projects receiving financial assistance from the recipient may receive assistance for associated energy storage and upgrades that either enable project deployment or maximize the benefits of the project for low income and disadvantaged communities The recipient will also provide project deployment services to enable low income and disadvantaged communities to deploy and benefit from residential solar Outcomes The anticipated deliverables will include steps and milestones to implement the strategies and plans for the Solar for All Program a distribute solar market strategy the financial assistance strategy the project deployment technical assistance strategy and an equitable access and meaningful involvement plan The expected outcomes include climate and air pollution benefits equity and community benefits and market transformation benefits The intended beneficiaries include households in low income and disadvantaged communities Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement
