project_title: Novel, Bio-Enabled Strategies to Prevent Per and Polyfluoralkyl Substances Accumulation in Crops and Food Webs
organization: t6438 - RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA
event_timeline:
- 2024-08-14: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,599,999
- 2025-05-13: End date cut off from 2028-08-31 to 2025-05-13
- 2025-06-17: End date extended from 2025-05-13 to 2028-08-31
project_description: Description The goal of this project is to understand how and to what degree contamination of farmland by PFAS can bioaccumulate in native plants and animals of cultural significance to Tribal communities in Maine Activities This project will 1 quantify PFAS uptake into soil and crops from contaminated irrigation water chemicals and environmental conditions 2 develop on farm tools to identify unexpected PFAS sources 3 determine how PFAS can spread to culturally important plants to tribal communities 4 quantify PFAS bioaccumulation in animals and insects in food webs Outcomes The outcomes of this project include annual and final reports peer reviewed publications as well as protocols and cultivars for growers to reduce PFAS bioaccumulation in crops technologies for on farm direct detection of PFAS during the growing season and an understanding of how tribal and rural communities are exposed to PFAS contamination through its bioaccumulation in animals insects and native plants of cultural significance Intended beneficiaries include the Mi rsquo kmaq Nation in Aroostook County Maine and other indigenous communities in the U S state local and Tribal resource managers and local communities affected by PFAS contaminated agricultural products Subrecipient Central Aroostook Soil and Water Conservation District CASWCD University of Maine 207 196 will provide equipment supplies and labor for cultivation of crops irrigation and sample collection on site at the farm location in Aroostook County Maine CASWCD will also perform outreach efforts to growers in Aroostook County as well as provide chemicals and plant cultivars for testing Connecticut Agriculture Experimental Station CAES 239 953 will provide guidance on field trial design and sampling and process field samples to perform LC MS MS analysis for PFAS compounds Mi rsquo kmaq Environmental Laboratory 180 000 will provide guidance on trial design and support for field sample collection for foraging crops and animal tissue samples They will also lead outreach efforts to Mi rsquo kmaq and other Tribal Nations in Maine affected by PFAS contamination

project_title: Developing Integrated Mitigation Strategies to Help Farmers Reduce PFAS Risks in Forage and Livestock Systems
event_timeline:
- 2024-07-31: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,599,998
- 2025-05-10: End date cut off from 2027-08-31 to 2025-05-10
- 2025-06-05: End date extended from 2025-05-10 to 2027-08-31
project_description: Description The overall goal of this project is to equip farmers with a set of integrated and scalable PFAS mitigation strategies targeting key points of PFAS transfer to reduce the risks associated with producing forages milk and meat on PFAS contaminated soil Activities This research will 1 identify PFAS reduction methods that significantly affect PFAS uptake in forage crops 2 evaluate PFAS mitigation effectiveness of livestock feed binder alterations and 3 develop outreach to support the adoption of PFAS mitigation strategies by forage dairy and meat producers Outcomes Anticipated deliverables include annual and final reports fact sheets videos podcasts webinars peer reviewed journal publications and actionable information on PFAS contamination The expected outcome of this research is new PFAS management strategies which will be beneficial to farmers farm advisors state and local policy makers meat and dairy consumers and communities affected by PFAS contaminated soil Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

project_title: PFAS in Land-applied Biosolids in Agricultural Settings: A Mechanistic Understanding on Fate and Mitigation
event_timeline:
- 2024-08-13: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,598,849
- 2025-04-24: End date cut off from 2027-09-30 to 2025-04-24
- 2025-07-02: End date extended from 2025-04-24 to 2027-09-30
project_description: Description The goal of this project is to understand the sewage sludge treatment processes contributing to PFAS partitioning unto biosolids PFAS accumulation in agricultural soils and potential mitigation strategies Activities This project will 1 sample wastewater treatment plants WWTPs nationwide and study the PFAS loading as a factor of biosolid characteristics and treatment process configuration to explore whether there is a correlation between biosolids characteristics and PFAS sorption 2 leverage an existing dataset and new data to identify critical parameters and bioprocesses in WWTPs that define the partitioning of PFAS in biosolids 3 explore the effectiveness of biochar amendments by modifying biochar to develop adsorptive capacity to remove PFAS chemicals from biosolids and soil mitigate PFAS accumulation and leaching and develop adsorption isotherms 4 conduct a PFAS plant uptake study with modified biochar real compost and biosolids collected from participating WWTPs and under varying conditions 5 evaluate the effect of standard soil management practices on PFAS accumulation and fate and 6 integrate the outcomes from the national survey and other results into a mechanistic understanding to communicate findings to the community members research community stakeholders and WWTPs Outcomes The project is expected to deliver 1 annual and final progress reports 2 an open access database with statistical analyses and accompanying manuscripts and 3 a final report to supporting utilities on the study rsquo s outcomes and recommendations The expected outcomes of this project include improved knowledge of the behavior of PFAS in WWTPs biosolids soils and plants collaboration between WWTP operators and agricultural producers to initiate synergism for further management of PFAS in biosolids and the development of process based and in field mitigation strategies to minimize the discharge leaching and plant uptake of PFAS in agricultural settings The intended beneficiaries of this project are agricultural producers who apply biosolids and WWTP operators who produce biosolids as well as communities and consumers affected by PFAS contamination Subrecipient The University of Albany 264 945 will conduct the plant uptake of PFAS studies with different plants and biosolid compost types The University of Illinois 200 165 will design the biochar synthesis and sorption and leaching tests Utah State University 193 087 will lead the educational outreach to farmer and conduct the field scale cover crops research Western Michigan University 200 426 will carry out the Michigan WWTPS sampling and analyze the existing data set for more than 195 WWTPs The University of South Florida 62 679 will carry out the bioinformatics tasks

project_title: PFAS Accumulation in Finfish and Shellfish Species within the Coastal and Inland Waters of the Peskotomuhkati (Passamaquoddy) Homelands.
event_timeline:
- 2024-09-04: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,558,555
- 2025-05-12: End date cut off from 2028-11-30 to 2025-05-12
- 2025-07-07: End date extended from 2025-05-12 to 2028-11-30
current_fiscal_year_outlays: No outlays reported in this fiscal year
project_description: Description The objective of this project is to assess local watersheds and food sources in the Peskotomuhkati Passmaquoddy homelands for PFAS accumulation This research aims to identify and mitigate PFAS contamination in Tribal lifeway practices Activities This project will 1 quantify the amount of PFAS and heavy metals within local water sources and fish species 2 evaluate the distribution of PFAS and heavy metals with aquatic environments and 3 translate the findings to local Tribal community members Outcomes Anticipated deliverables include outreach materials project reports and journal publications The project outcome includes new scientific knowledge on PFAS fate in local Peskotomuhkati homelands and support for Tribal state and federal resource managers to make decisions to facilitate pollution prevention measures Beneficiaries include Passamaquoddy Tribe policy makers human health and the environment Subrecipient Bigelow Laboratory 253 102 with its expertise in PFAS analysis chemistry and trace metals will train Sipayik Environmental Department SED staff in sampling and sample preparation and collaborate with SED and Indian Health Services staff in data evaluation interpretation and outreach Pleasant Point Health Center 12 401 will develop research finding pamphlets and collaborate with the project team in community engagement and outreach efforts

project_title: Plant Uptake and Mitigation of PFAS Associated with Sewage Effluent and Biosolids Application in Tile-Drained Fields
event_timeline:
- 2024-07-18: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,599,522
- 2025-05-13: End date cut off from 2027-09-30 to 2025-05-13
- 2025-07-07: End date extended from 2025-05-13 to 2027-09-30
project_description: Description The goal of this project is to enhance the understanding of Per and polyfluoroalkyl substances PFAS uptake and accumulation in plants grown in subsurface tile drained fields irrigated with rural sewage effluent explore the physical and molecular mechanisms that govern PFAS uptake and accumulation in plants grown in biosolids amended soils and develop innovative and efficient techniques to mitigate PFAS plant uptake and thereby reduce their entry into the food chain Activities This project will carry out a series of field and laboratory experiments to 1 monitor and measure PFAS in irrigation water groundwater drainage water soils and crops and evaluate the potential PFAS contamination and bioaccumulation through sewage effluent irrigation 2 understand uptake translocation accumulation and transformation of PFAS in a soils plant system with biosolids amendment and 3 develop innovative mitigation techniques using unique biochars to prevent PFAS plant uptake from sewage sludge effluent irrigation and biosolids soil amendment Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports The result of this project will provide useful and vital information concerning the occurrence of PFAS in tile drained agricultural fields irrigated with rural sewage effluents The expected outputs include a comprehensive profile of PFAS in contaminated biosolids understanding of PFAS plant uptake and accumulation in biosolids soil plant systems and two innovative PFAS mitigation techniques Direct beneficiaries of this project will be agricultural producers state and local policy makers and regulators the general public human health and the environment Subrecipient The University of California ndash Riverside 300 000 will be responsible for detection of PFAS in biosolids and plant tissues as well as the analysis of potential products using high resolution MS MS

project_title: Investigating the Effects of Irrigation Water, Compost and Biosolid Qualities on PFAS Uptake by Edible Crops in Urban Gardens and Farms
organization: TEMPLE UNIVERSITY-OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION
event_timeline:
- 2024-08-21: Grant awarded; Obligation of $800,051
- 2025-05-13: End date cut off from 2027-08-31 to 2025-05-13
- 2025-07-03: End date extended from 2025-05-13 to 2027-08-31
project_description: Description The goal of this project is to examine the baseline PFAS levels in typical supplies and resources for urban farming and gardening and to examine the bioavailability of PFAS in edible crops Activities This project will 1 quantify the impact of soil nutrient amendments and irrigation water on crop uptake using raised beds supplemented with biosolids or compost 2 sample local freshwater resources and rainwater for a baseline of PFAS 3 quantify PFAS in the edible plant parts and surface soils after urban crop harvest and 4 measure other vital plant functions such as photosynthesis oxidative stress levels and seed viability Outcomes The expected outcomes of this project include an improved understanding of the bioavailability of PFAS in urban crops and how urban resources such as rainwater biosolids and homemade compost impact the PFAS levels in those crops The project is expected to deliver annual and final progress reports and peer reviewed publications Intended beneficiaries of this project include urban community gardeners in Philadelphia and across the country Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

project_title: Evaluating and Mitigating Bioaccumulation of PFAS in Plant, Mammalian, and Aquaculture Systems
event_timeline:
- 2024-07-16: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,600,000
- 2025-05-02: End date cut off from 2028-08-31 to 2025-05-02
- 2025-07-08: End date extended from 2025-05-02 to 2028-08-31
project_description: Description This project will evaluate the bioavailability of per and polyfluoroalkyl substances PFAS in agricultural environments research PFAS transport into secondary animal products and identify previously uncharacterized sources of PFAS Activities This project will 1 characterize PFAS partitioning in plant cultivation and compare with soil type and residual treatment 2 evaluate PFAS uptake in fish through dietary sources 3 measure PFAS distribution through drinking water and food and 4 develop mitigation strategies for PFAS accumulation Outcomes Anticipated deliverables include inventories of PFAS sources at agricultural facilities models to predict PFAS elimination final reports and peer reviewed articles Expected outcomes of this research includes the development of on farm PFAS management practices for PFAS Intended beneficiaries include farms agricultural facilities state and local regulators and consumers of agricultural products Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

project_title: Comprehensive evaluation of fate, transport, bioaccumulation and management solution of PFAS on a crop and livestock farm that received biosolids
event_timeline:
- 2024-08-28: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,600,000
- 2025-05-08: End date cut off from 2027-09-30 to 2025-05-08
- 2025-07-07: End date extended from 2025-05-08 to 2027-09-30
project_description: Description The goals of this project are to evaluate the fate transport and bioaccumulation of Per and Polyfluoroalkyl substances PFAS in a crop livestock farm that utilizes biosolid land application The project also aims to quantify PFAS precursor accumulation within on farm resources to assess farm management methods to mitigate PFAS contamination Activities The project will 1 examine the relationships between PFAS distribution and soil properties 2 measure and rank PFAS accumulation in different field crops vegetables and livestock forages 3 elucidate environmental fate transport and plant uptake of PFAS at the nexus of soil water and crops on the PFAS impacted farm 4 measure PFAS accumulation in livestock and 5 develop protocols to screen and map PFAS accumulation in agricultural settings Outcomes Deliverables include annual and final reports The results of this project will produce new scientific data and improve the basic knowledge on PFAS and precursor fate plant uptake bioaccumulation in livestock cycling process in typical Midwest crop livestock farms The expected outcome is to improve the knowledge of the PFAS life cycle in a farm setting Direct beneficiaries include farmers agricultural advisors human health and the environment Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

project_title: PFAS-MAPS: PFAS Mitigation and Monitoring in Amended Plant Systems
event_timeline:
- 2024-07-30: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,600,000
- 2025-05-07: End date cut off from 2028-08-31 to 2025-05-07
- 2025-07-08: End date extended from 2025-05-07 to 2028-08-31
project_description: Description The goals of this project are to comprehensively understand PFAS uptake and bioaccumulation in plants across various nutrient condition to advance strategies for PFAS remediation in biosolids soil minimize PFAS uptake by plants and develop real time monitoring tools for PFAS in biosolids biosolids amended soils and irrigation water Activities To achieve its goals this project will 1 develop and assess integrated PFAS remediation methods to prepare biosolids for land application 2 develop and assess technologies to prevent PFAS uptake by plants in biosolids amended soils 3 screen design and develop plant based biosensors for PFAS detection in biosolids soils and water and 4 demonstrate the effectiveness of technologies in remediating PFAS in biosolids reducing PFAS bioavailability in plants in biosolids amended soils and evaluating the sensitivity of developed biosensors in monitoring PFAS contamination Outcomes The anticipated outcome of this project is the empowerment of agricultural communities wastewater professionals and state and federal regulatory agencies to increase their ability to manage PFAS risk associated with the beneficial uses of biosolids and reclaimed water The project is expected to deliver 1 annual and final progress reports 2 peer reviewed publications 3 novel strategies to remediate PFAS and reduce PFAS bioavailability and 4 scalable biosensors to monitor PFAS bioaccumulation in plants on site The direct beneficiaries of this project are agricultural communities and wastewater professionals Other beneficiaries include state and federal regulatory agencies the general publics human health and the environment Subrecipient The University of Michigan 638 675 will lead the work on the biosensor design and generation and PFOS phytoremediation of bio sorbent amended soil and wastewater

project_title: Practical Management of PFAS Contaminated Agricultural Soil Using an Innovative Platform Developed through Integrated Experimental Research and Machine Learning Approaches
organization: t4553 - RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE
event_timeline:
- 2024-08-19: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,600,000
- 2025-04-24: End date cut off from 2028-08-31 to 2025-04-24
- 2025-07-02: End date extended from 2025-04-24 to 2028-08-31
project_description: Description This project aims to test the overarching hypothesis that proper engineering control will allow continued and beneficial use of biosolids on agricultural soil and that this practice can sustain marketable and PFAS free products from such soil Activities This project will 1 model PFAS solid water coefficient and soil properties with without powdered activated carbon 2 develop machine learning to build models for PFAS accumulation predictions 3 evaluate the binding between PFAS soil and biosolids and 4 verify newly developed models Outcomes Anticipated deliverables include new understanding of the relationship between PFAS and biosolids project reports machine learning based predictive models and peer reviewed publications Beneficiaries includes farmers state and local policy makers environmental managers and communities affected by PFAS contaminated agricultural products and or groundwater Subrecipient Subawardee Western Reserve University will receive 412 511 to develop machine learning models for the project Subawardee University of Florida will receive 87 836 to help evaluate bound residues formed between PFAS biosolids soil with or without powdered activated carbon PAC

project_title: Build Reuse - Reducing Embodied GHG for Salvaged Materials FR
event_timeline:
- 2025-01-15: Grant awarded; Obligation of $6,703,990
- 2025-04-30: End date cut off from 2029-12-31 to 2025-04-30
project_description: Description This agreement provides funding under the Inflation Reduction Act IRA to Building Materials Re use Association This program is to support the development enhanced standardization and transparency and reporting criteria for environmental product declarations EPDs which include the measurement of embodied greenhouse gas emissions associated with all relevant stages of production use and disposal in conformance with international standards The recipient will develop a digital LCA EPD generator software tool enhance its capabilities as a program operator and create a sub category PCR for salvaged and reprocessed construction products The project will generate data on ldquo average rdquo use quality service lifespans past uses and end of life in key product group categories for use in product circularity activities such as design for reuse and materials passport development Activities The activities include capacity building and education such as openLCA software training seating members of a Technical Committee for quality assistance and governance as a Program Operator Activities also include developing a PCR for Salvage and Reuse Construction Products a digital LCA EPD Generator and Environmental Product Declarations approx 300 from 100 different salvage and reuse establishments Outcomes The anticipated deliverables for Task 1 Capacity Building and Education include hosting a two day workshop and sessions at annual conferences dedicated to LCA EPDs and carbon labeling training for openLCA software for staff declare and publish Program Operator status and information on website and proposed presentation and paper at annual ACLCA conference The anticipated deliverables for Task 2 PCR for Salvage and Reuse Construction Products include an RFP for PO PCR Specification contracting a PO for PCR Committee soliciting and contracting an Expert Review panel and conducting PCR development The anticipated deliverables for Task 3 Digital LCA EPD Generator Development include open Excel based digital LCI data collection templates software design digital generator testing refinement and instructional guidance for generator The anticipated deliverables for Task 4 EPD Development include EPD program webinars establishing solicitation and program guidelines developing LCA models for principal salvage and reuse processes conducting LCI data collection processes in partnership facilities third party verification of EPDs and publication of EPDs The expected outcomes include openLCA trained staff dedicated LCA EPD session at each annual conference for purposes of cross grant coordination one or more online education products one report and roadmap documenting workshop and reporting five papers presentations to national ACLCA conference development of one Core PCR an EPD generator tool and approximately 300 EPDs The intended beneficiaries include architecture engineering and construction professionals LCA practitioners academia and material manufacturers and suppliers Subrecipient Build Reuse will provide a subaward for USDA Forest Products Laboratory for peer reviews and publications

project_title: Discovering Reaction Pathways and Designing Processes for a Sustainable, Circular, and Just Chemical Industry
event_timeline:
- 2025-01-13: Grant awarded; Obligation of $157,667
- 2025-04-29: End date cut off from 2028-02-29 to 2025-04-29
project_description: Description This project will develop new models methods and software tools for discovering and designing novel reaction networks and processes that are essential for transforming the US chemicals industry toward greater sustainability and circularity Activities Specific activities include developing i an open access model of the current US chemicals industry ii innovative methods for discovering novel circular chemical reaction networks iii approaches for engaging with local communities and quantifying impacts of current and prospective chemical industries at specific locations iv a framework for efficiently guiding the selection and design of better reaction networks and processes and v applications to industrially relevant products such as methanol and polyethylene and user friendly software tools Outcomes Anticipated deliverables and expected outcomes of this work include a model of the U S chemicals production and manufacturing industry novel methodology and framework for developing reaction networks hierarchical screening processes and user friendly software tools that promote sustainability and circularity Intended beneficiaries include the chemicals manufacturing industry communities affected by environmental exposure to toxic chemical products the general public and environmental health decision makers Subrecipient The subaward to Unlimited Potential 100 000 is to develop and implement educational presentations focus groups and train community leaders on environmental education

project_title: High-Throughput Method Development to Acquire Chemical Data Needed to Inform Environmental Molecular Lifecycles That Guide Sustainable Chemical Assessment
event_timeline:
- 2025-01-29: Grant awarded; Obligation of $157,667
- 2025-05-01: End date cut off from 2028-02-29 to 2025-05-01
project_description: Description This project aims to develop a predicted reaction network using experimental and computational data generated by the work to describe the environmental lifecycle of persistent biological transformation products TP of chemicals The purpose of this award is to improve the chemical products manufacturing industry and improve understanding of biological transformation products and how chemicals act at different stages of their lifecycle Activities The activities to be performed in this project will integrate new approach methodologies and supplement experimental data with computational techniques leveraging Carnegie Mellon s CloudLab and machine learning methods Using these processes the projects will select critical and stable biological transformation products and develop reaction network to better assess the environmental fate and bioaccumulation potential of transformed chemicals or chemical products at different stages of their lifecycles Outcomes The project will utilize experimental and computational data to develop predicted reaction networks for chemical products and their subsequent biological transformation products The work seeks to utilize existing chemical alternatives that do not result in harmful or environmental accumulative biological transformation products This information can be leveraged for use in open access chemical databases and user friendly web tools Anticipated deliverable of this project is a predictive tool that will evaluate the sustainability of alternative chemical products and identify potential biological transformation products of concern relevant to that chemical product The intended beneficiaries of this project include chemicals industry waste management industry the general public public and environmental health decision makers and communities affected by environmental pollution Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: Electrochemical Process for Recovering Nitrogen and Phosphorus from Source-Separated Urine to Reduce Nutrient Loads to Domestic Wastewater Treatment Plants
event_timeline:
- 2025-02-21: Grant awarded; Obligation of $75,000
- 2025-04-30: End date cut off from 2027-02-28 to 2025-04-30
project_description: Description The goal of this project is to develop a novel approach of concomitant stabilization of fresh source separated urine with preferential struvite precipitation using a sacrificial Mg anode and carbon based gas diffusion cathode Activities The activities include developing and testing a pilot scale novel electrochemical treatment system to stabilize urine waste and separate and recover nutrients such as nitrogen and phosphorous The team will evaluate performance of continuous recovery system by conducting life cycle and techno economic analysis Outcomes The anticipated deliverables include annual and a final report Additionally the project will provide results across several scales relevant to developing electrochemical processes for treating source separated urine The expected outputs include a development and design of an electrochemical process to 1 prevent the transformation of fresh source separated urine to the putrid liquid that results from urea hydrolysis and microbial growth 2 stabilize and precipitate the recoverable nutrients N and P from urine in a form that may be recovered for recycling in agriculture and 3 reduce N and P released to the environment degrading quality of natural water bodies Direct beneficiaries of this program include residents of the communities in South Carolina state the general public and the environment Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: P3 Award: National Student Design Competition for Sustainability
project_title: Development of a Simple Enzyme Inhibition Biosensor for Lead in Drinking Water
event_timeline:
- 2025-01-30: Grant awarded; Obligation of $75,000
- 2025-04-30: End date cut off from 2027-02-28 to 2025-04-30
current_fiscal_year_outlays: No outlays reported in this fiscal year
project_description: Description The goal of this project is to design a simple single use test strip made of an enzymatic biosensor that can be used by general public to detect lead in drinking water at the faucets Activities The objectives include 1 designing building and testing simple enzymatic biosensors to detect lead contamination in drinking water 2 investigating a range of economic and environmental inputs to ensure the device s long term viability and widespread distribution and 3 disseminating findings at regional and national levels Outcomes Deliverables will include annual and final reports Additionally deliverables include a simple and affordable testing strip made of enzymatic biosensor to detect lead and potentially other contaminants in drinking water at household faucets The expected outcomes include 1 identify produce and purify a family of PBGS variants 2 characterize the inhibition by lead activity and stability of the PBGS mutants 3 develop colorimetric chemistry for signal transduction 4 develop and test a simple prototype device and 5 characterize the impact of common chemical contaminants found in drinking water on the prototype sensor response Direct beneficiaries of this assistance agreement include residents of the communities in Ohio and the general public Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

program: Environmental Justice Government-to-Government (EJG2G) Program - Implementation Projects
project_title: Assisting communities in identifying, preventing and eliminating blighted properties and associated health and environmental risks through education, training, civic engagement and community planning.
organization: Municipio de Vega Baja - MUNICIPIO DE VEGA BAJA
event_timeline:
- 2024-08-27: Grant awarded; Obligation of $1,028,353
- 2025-03-28: End date cut off from 2027-08-31 to 2025-03-28
current_fiscal_year_outlays: No outlays reported in this fiscal year
project_description: Description The agreement provides funding to Municipality of Vega Baja Specifically the recipient will assist communities in identifying preventing and eliminating blighted properties and associated health and environmental risks The project will enable communities to identify and map assets challenges and opportunities participate in planning activities to create a Reuse Plan and conceptualize assess the viability of and execute pilot mitigation projects from the Reuse Plan Activities The activities include education training civic engagement community mapping and reuse planning and small scale acquisition and mitigation Interactive trainings on community mapping and the identification of and risks related to blight will be delivered Training participants will work with project partners to map potential nuisance properties and their environmental and health risks Follow up mapping will be conducted throughout the project period Community planning workshops will be held to review mapping results consult with the community draft a Reuse Plan seek feedback and publish a final Reuse Plan Trainings on best practices for reduction prevention and reuse as well as capacity building for Reuse Plan implementation will be delivered Pilot projects selected from the Reuse Plan will be carried out and may include deconstruction demolition rehabilitation clean up or abatement The appropriate environmental review and construction crosscutters will be addressed prior to starting any construction activities Outcomes The anticipated deliverables include trained residents pre and post evaluations community maps one Reuse Plan meetings with policymakers and advocates an anticipated five deconstructions or demolitions sixteen clean up or abatement interventions six rehabilitated affordable housing units for climate resiliency and adaptation six small scale nature based projects and semi annual and final reports The expected outcomes include an increase in the number of health and environmental risks identified and mapped in communities increased knowledge and awareness of blight and its risk reduction and prevention among residents increased mapping knowledge and skills among community members increased resident commitment to and meaningful engagement in blight reduction and prevention and increased capacity and resilience in overburdened and underserved communities The project is expected to increase intervention for nuisance properties through mitigation of findings and implementation of recommendations in the Reuse Plan thereby decreasing environmental and health risks in the community The intended beneficiaries include the Municipality of Vega Baja as well as its residents and project partners Subrecipient The Center for Habitat Reconstruction is a subrecipient Day to day operations of the project will be executed by Center for Habitat Reconstruction which includes supporting the Municipality of Vega Baja in facilitating outreach and education trainings community mapping and planning and capacity building trainings Center for Habitat Reconstruction will also execute nature based pilot projects and nuisance clean up and abatement and complete required environmental review and construction crosscutter compliance before any construction activities take place
gs_org: Ofc Of The Regional Administrator R2

program: Environmental Justice Collaborative Problem-Solving Cooperative Agreement Program - Surveys, Studies, Investigations, Training & Demonstrations
project_title: Terra Ay Ay Environmental Action Group
organization: St. CFCD - ST CROIX FOUNDATION FOR COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT INC
event_timeline:
- 2022-09-30: Grant awarded; Obligation of $200,000
- 2024-08-01: End date extended from 2024-10-01 to 2025-09-30
- 2025-03-28: End date cut off from 2025-09-30 to 2025-03-28
project_description: Description The purpose of this American Rescue Plan ARP funded cooperative agreement is to provide financial assistance to the St Croix Foundation for Community Development for a community driven project that will provide the community with data and information on health and environmental risk and risk mitigation best practices Also with a partnership with the Marine Biology program and Eco School Club at St Croix Central High School the Eco School Club at the St Croix Educational Complex and Undergraduate researchers in cooperation with Chemistry Department at the University of the Virgin Islands Albert A Sheen campus in St Croix this project will train students for to conduct monitoring sample collection and public education in accordance with federal statutes Clean Air Act Section 103 b 3 and Clean Water Act Section 104 b 3 Activities This project will establish Air Quality Asthma monitoring system and support the ongoing water quality monitoring and establish a Community Steering Committee of local community advocates and concerned residents to guide project activities Establish an innovative community air monitoring network of monitors throughout the target areas of the island The project will develop an Air monitoring program that produces data that are scientifically valid and useful to the community The project will determine the technology to be used based on need costs and user capacity such as PurpleAir monitors Grab samples bucket brigade Fenceline monitoring Temporary stationary monitoring Mobile monitoring or a CAMN network This project will result in real time local air quality data that can also be used in scientific analysis Education and outreach to the community utilizing various media including print social media website publishing and distribute printed brochures and townhall meetings The long term goal is to establish a network of air monitors that are installed at buildings or other sites within the selected community The monitors continuously measure levels of specific air pollutants and send that information over the internet to a server where the data are stored in a database Outcomes Anticipated deliverables include report and two brochures on local air and water quality Expected outcomes of this project are the development of new air quality ordinances and policies enacted by local government decrease in the number of asthma related hospital visits among community residents and an increase in community dialogue about environmental impacts and public health Direct beneficiaries of this project are predominantly residents located in low income high density neighborhoods of St Croix Subrecipient The recipient intends to issue subaward agreements to its partners in compliance with Appendix A of EPA rsquo s Subaward Policy The sub awardees will provide coordination for project activities provide technical assistance and lead the air monitoring education and training program
gs_org: Ofc Of The Regional Administrator R2

project_description: Description The non profit organization Center for Habitat Reconstruction will provide three pilot low income communities in Puerto Rico with education training meetings and community planning geared towards the identification prevention and elimination of blighted properties and their environmental and health risks Activities Project activities include creation of a comprehensive plan development of nuisance remediation strategies appropriate for the most common nuisance situations and collaborative work with municipalities to address code enforcement gaps foster municipal community partnerships strengthen local legal frameworks leverage private and public resources for continued work and provide a replicable model for other Puerto Rican communities Outcomes Expected outcomes are an increase number of community stakeholders committed to the fight against blight a decrease in number of environmental and health risks in the community increased number of new nuisance abatement and code enforcement ordinances enacted by local government and an increased number of reuse and placemaking projects that converted nuisances for disaster resiliency within a three year period Direct beneficiaries of this project are residents of the three target communities of Cag uuml itas Aguas Buenas R iacute o Piedras San Juan and San Isidro Can oacute vanas that are made up of a mix of low income rural urban and informal neighborhoods The recipient does not intend to issue any subawards Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement

project_title: Environmental  Collaborative Problem-Solving - Vallejo Food Rescue Project
organization: FOOD BANK OF CONTRA COSTA AND SOLANO
event_timeline:
- 2024-10-31: Grant awarded; Obligation of $154,982
- 2024-11-14: Other amendment
- 2025-05-01: End date cut off from 2025-10-31 to 2025-05-01
project_description: Description The purpose of this Environmental  Collaborative Problem Solving EJCPS cooperative agreement is to provide funding under Section 8001 a of the Solid Waste Disposal Act to the Food Bank of Contra Costa and Solano Food Bank to connect organizations and stakeholders in Solano County with a focus on Vallejo CA to offer a robust replicable collaborative local food rescue operation improving access to food for low income individuals while also reducing greenhouse gas emissions in the target community This agreement provides full federal funding in the amount of 154 982 Preaward costs are approved back to 10 1 2024 Refer to Terms and Conditions Activities Project activities include program management metrics tracking and documentation to facilitate replication development of the Food Rescue Toolkit outreach to and engagement of food distribution partners outreach to and engagement of food donors and feedback and documentation Outcomes The project outputs will be food rescued from landfill one Toolkit with educational and promotional components engaged community partners and survey data from partners Our outcomes will include the increased capacity of Vallejo community to address environmental  concerns through self sustaining community based partnership increased communication and collaboration among partners in target community Vallejo partners have increased access to fresher more varied foods thereby improving service to the community increased access and decreased food insecurity among low income Vallejo community members including those disproportionately impacted by COVID 19 increased diversion of edible food from landfills resources and readiness to expand the program to other jurisdictions and an evaluation of the project based on feedback from partners The Vallejo Food Rescue Project will benefit the residents of zip codes 94589 94590 94591 and 94592 in the City of Vallejo California Subrecipient No subawards are included in this assistance agreement
gs_org: Ofc Of The Regional Administrator R9
